  168. I'm sixty one years of age, fair skinned (moderately sensitive skin), and grow an average density beard. Because I dislike shaving I wore beard for most of my adult life only shaving my neck to keep hairs from getting snagged in my shirt collar. In October of last year I began shaving all of my face, leaving just a mustache. Obviously, this made the performance of my shaver a much more important issue than just shaving my neck. My electric shavers have always been foil type shavers, mostly Remingtons, and the most recent was a DA 307 purchased in March of 2010 at a cost of about $34.95. I have just re-learned that, yes, you get what you pay for in an electric shaver. Recently the DA 307 began making black streaks on my face. The shave quality was never very good, but as good as I had been used to through the years. The black was coming from the little black plastic bar that divides the foil heads. I cleaned the little bar daily but it continued to rub off on my face. Last week I decided to do some research and buy my first GOOD electric shaver. My research led me to the Panasonic ES 8243 A. I paid $104 for it on Amazon, and I bought it because one of the reviews I read claimed it to be the best value for the dollar, and I was not about to spend $250 on a shaver (Braun). The ES 8243 can be used in the shower (which I most likely will not do). It has a good sideburn trimmer, a shave head that can be set to either \\"float\\" or be \\"fixed\\", and a nifty display that tells me the status of the charge time on the battery, which recharges fully in merely one hour. It is extremely easy to clean, and it is very lightweight. How about shave quality? Well, I had no inkling that I could shave in under two minutes, and I'm talking about a very smooth, irritation free shave! I had no idea shaving could be like this. I have NEVER gotten a more stubble-free shave. It'll be awhile down the road before I can report on how well it holds up and how well it continues to deliver these perfect shaves, but I am very optimistic. At this point I can highly recommend this shaver. Oh, another thing; it's actualy very quiet.

  171. I'm loving this razor! I've had Brauns before and have been using Mach III and Edge gel for the last year. Bought a Norelco at Costco and took it back after 1 try. Felt cheap and not very high rpm. It doesn't lose its charge until after a week and I like the fact that the razor on day 7 is as fast as on day 1. It doesn't lose any speed by unplugging it either. With my Brauns, you could hear the rpm loss as you unplugged it from the wall, so I always was tethered to the sink. Not with this one. Got this one and absolutely get the best shave I've had. Doesn't leave any strays on my neck or anywhere. I'm also a fan of Aubrey Organics' products and use the North Woods face scrub first, then shave with their North Woods shave cream. It's not a gel so it won't muck it up. Just run a little water in the shaver and it foams it up. Makes the chore of shaving a much better experience.
  172. Have owned this for about a month and this is the best shaver I have ever owned. It shaves closer and is less irritating than anything else I've had. I've preferred Remington screen shavers over the Norelco rotaries due to the closer shave that the screen gives me, but this shaver can shave closer than I thought was possible with an electric. I would say that most of the time, 5 hours after I shave with this, my beard feels about the same as it did immediately after shaving with my Remington.<br /><br />Panasonic claims that these are the sharpest blades they've ever made and I believe them. While shaving, there is less drag than I've had with other shavers and that along with the cutting sound definitely leads me to believe that these blades are slicing through the hair much easier than my old shaver. Additionally, I've noticed that it cuts longer hair much easier as well. Previously, if I skipped a day, shaving with my other shavers was a bit tough. If I skipped more than that I would either have to use the sideburns trimmer or use a blade - the other shavers either wouldn't cut at all or hurt like crazy. If I skip a day with this shaver, it still cuts well, just takes a minute longer or so to finish. I tried skipping 2 days to see what it would do. It worked, it didn't hurt and I only had to use the trimmer on a few hairs that just wouldn't stand up. That was pretty amazing!<br /><br />I'm impressed with the linear motor. Its light and it definitely sounds like it is moving much faster than other shavers with traditional motors. This shaver sounds much different than anything else I've used.<br /><br />The build quality seems good and fairly solid. The only two complaints I would have about this shaver at this point is that I only get about 20 shaves per charge (Remington MS-5500 went nearly 40) and you can't run the shaver from the charger. It does have a 1 shave quick charge, but I would have preferred that they made the body a little larger, addanother battery and a large enough charger to run off of. That being said, I'd buy it again in a heart beat and I like it enough that I'll replace the battery when it dies in a few years.<br /><br />Previous shavers I've owned: Remington MS-5500 (3 years+), Remington MS3-4700 (2 years), various Norelco rotaries.<br /><br />Edit Jan 2013: It is nearly 3 years later and this is still bar none the best shaver I've ever owned. I shave for 2 to 3 minutes a day, 9 out of 10 days and I've still never replaced the blades and I don't think I've seen any change in battery life. The next shaver I purchase will definitely be a Panasonic, but it looks like that is not going to be anytime soon.

  178. I recently switched to this shaver after having used a Braun 7526 for about the last four years. Although the Braun was decent, I never relied on it as my sole means of shaving -- I would periodically use a razor. After seeing high reviews on the Panasonics (and feeling that it was time to see if technology had evolved), I got the Panasonic ES8243A. I have a fairly heavy beard, unfortunately combined with sensitive skin. This is part of the reason why I alternated between different methods of shaving. The aforementioned Braun could give me a close shave, but it required me to spend about 12-15 minutes going over the same areas numerous times. This sometimes led to irritation, especially on the neck. After reading that the Panasonic ES8243A has a much faster motor than the Braun (and most other electric shavers), I hoped to reduce my shaving time while getting a closer, more comfortable shave. I also liked the idea of shaving in the shower, which was not recommended for the Braun. Ultimately, I have concluded that this Panasonic is considerably better than my old Braun, and is overall an excellent shaver. It does indeed allow me to shave more quickly. I have had the best experience using this shaver in the shower with a small amount of non-foaming shave gel or cream. I recommend King of Shaves Alpha Gel. (Neutrogena Sensitive Skin also works well, but because it's a white cream rather than a clear gel, it can make it a little harder to see what you are doing compared). I can use this shaver in the shower for 5 or 6 minutes and get a closer shave than twice as much time spent with my old Braun -- and I have yet to have a problem with irritation. I'm very pleased so far. I will say that the advertising claims are nonsense. The box claims that you will get a close shave with \\"one pass.\\" Well, maybe if you have a very light beard... For me, the notion of a one-pass, close shave is still an electric shaving fantasy. I can get a very close shave with this Panasonic, but I still have to do a lot more than one pass -- particularly on the neck area. Nonetheless, as far as electric shavers go, this is the best I've used. Other positives are: -Very easy to clean; doesn't require a cleaning system and expensive liquid cartridges (as my Braun did). You clean this Panasonic by putting a little liquid soap on the head, turning it on \\"turbo mode\\" (which cuts off automatically after 20 seconds), and it self-cleans. -Ergonomically-designed; it's easy to grip this shaver. -Nice appearance; has a high-tech look. -It charges up quickly. I find that ten minutes of shaving will run down the charge 20%, so you get about 5 shaves on each full charge. The very fast recharging is helpful. -Made in Japan, not in China. Minor negatives: -There is no charging stand; after cleaning, I lay it on a small, folded towel. -The included case is adequate, but it's not a leather case as was sometimes provided with shavers in the \\"good old days.\\" Overall, an excellent shaver but I'm withholding a fifth star because it still requires going over some areas multiple times -- no \\"one pass\\" miracles!
  179. I had a Braun shaver before this Panasonic - this thing is great! The Braun required cleaner fluid and a base (takes up space, always plugged in, had to buy this insane plastic cartridges with fluid ($10 a pop)). This thing feels great to me, and I have a considerably closer shave with no irritation. The Braun was fine, but in the end this is one step up in terms of closer shave. I like the weight, the head flexibility, and the power charge by % (it also posts time used, sort of interesting in a way). Great shaver - I heartily recommend it!
  180. I purchased the ES8243A shaver to replace my aging Braun. I liked the Braun and owned 4 before going with something different. In my experience, all the Brauns provided a close shave, but couldn't cut my difficult neck area. My first impressions after I used it was that it was well-built, quieter than expected, and cut my facial hair much faster than my 5 year old Braun and even tackled my neck area pretty well after I used a circular pattern. I have used it in the shower several times and it performed about the same wet or dry. I prefer to use it wet to reduce skin irritation. I don't even have to use after shave lotion when I use it in the shower. The shaver holds the charge fairly well, but to be honest I leave it charged most of the time. The only negative was that it didn't provide a closer shave than the Braun. With that said, I have very sensitive facial hair and it does much better not to irritate my face. Overall, I am very pleased with the purchase. I can actually bring this shaver on travel and leave the razor blade behind....really!
  181. Does everything it claims to do, Had mine for almsot one month and am very pleased.
  182. Works great not much else to say
  183. I have owned Norelco & Remington shavers for over 30 years. I am a dry-shave guy. I purchased the Panasonic ES8243A after researching which Panasonic models claimed to do well with dry shaving. This one did not work for me. I have a normal beard, but have some extra thick beard hairs scattered here and there. After the Panasonic got below 1/2 charge, it would jam on these thick hairs. After removing the head and blowing it out, the razor would continue -- at least this worked for awhile into the shave. About 1/2 way through the shave, the razor just stopped and went dead, like a circuit breaker was tripped. It didn't reset itself until 8-10 hours later. On top of this, the razor never gave as close a shave as my Remington. And the \\"four cutting heads\\" claim is a sham. There are four rows on the head, but only two cutters. Also, the width of the four rows made the head difficult to manuever in the hollows under the chin or on the upper lip. The only reason I did not give this razor a single star is because I didn't try it as a wet shaver. Perhaps it works well in that mode, but personally, the reason I have an electric is to do away with wet shaving -- the lather and the mess.
  184. Purchased this shaver to replace a Braun with design or manufacturing defects. This was available for a reasonable price via a lightning deal and Amazon even shipped this the same day that it was ordered. This shaver is quieter but higher pitched than what I was used to but with the higher speed tends to also shave more quickly although not quite as close. The difference is not enough to be a concern although the difference in foil/blade prices is. Panasonic is designed for a twelve month replacement schedule with the foil/cutter running about double those for Braun that is designed for an eighteen month schedule. However, the Braun 360 complete foils fail within two months due to splitting of the foil which are usually detected because of the slicing and cutting of the user's face (P&G denies that the problem exists). I avoided anything that used the Panasonic cleaning system because of numerous complaints and reviews about the residue from the soap. Liquid hand soap as per the owner's manual works well for periodic cleaning and weekly is fine as long as the stubble is emptied say every other shave or so. Wish that this had included a small brush as the stubble tends to stick. I shave dry to get a closer shave and no problem with this at all and the design works great for me for the neck. The beard/mustache trimmer is a little narrow but acceptable. Contrary to a previous report, I do not have any problem with the spreading of stubble but the foil needs to be correctly attached to ensure proper closure and retention of stubble. Overall am pleased with the performance and use although I will not be as pleased when I have to replace the foil/cutter due to the higher price.
  185. Bought it to replace my old Panasonic, which was great. This is better. Pros: Slides smoother over my face. I don't need to go over each spot several times. Average shave is less than 4 minutes and uses about 10% of it's battery. Recharge is quick. Would buy again Cons: Lighter weight construction than old shaver. Expensive.
  186. Bought this razor for my Dad for Christmas. He wanted something that would give him a close shave--he'd been using the same electric razor for over ten years. He has mentioned to me twice now that he loves the close shave.
  187. I was a Norelco user for over 30 years and always liked them. I received a Braun foil shaver as a gift a couple of years ago and I never liked it due to missed hairs and being noisy. I decided to finally replace my Norelco Spectra with the Panasonic ES8243A based on all the reviews. I was going to order this a couple of times but just couldn't pull the trigger. Earlier in the week I made the decision and am glad I did. I never write reviews and not sure many of them are honest. I can say this is the best shaver I have ever owned. I never even knew Panasonic made a quality shaver. It is easy to clean and comes with a lithium ion battery unlike some others. I shave in the shower with liquid soap and the shave is so much better than the rotary type. Don't hesitate like I did... Go ahead and get this one.
  188. I have owned many shavers over the years. I started out with Norelco models and then switched to Brauns. The Norelco's never shaved good enough for my beard. I would have to go over the same areas on my face multiple times and sometimes I would feel the hairs getting tugged. Also the flip-up trimmers of the newer Norelco's were absolutely worthless. The Braun's performed better, but I was still left with wanting a better shave. I have neck hairs that grow sideways and even the top of the line (ridiculously expensive) Braun's couldn't cut them satisfactorily. Also, the Braun's still use the antiquated Ni-Cd and Ni-Mh batteries that after 6-12 months can barely hold a charge more than a couple mornings worth of use. It was time for a change and that is why I chose the Panasonic. Positives: The Panasonic shaver has a lot of positives over the other shavers I have owned. 1) The contoured body is very easy and comfortable to hold. 2) The shaver is water proof, so I can frequently clean the blades under the faucet without worry. 3) The shaver uses a Li-Ion battery that lasts all week and recharges quickly. 4) Most importantly, the shaver does the best job I have experienced with neck hairs. It can still be a challenge to catch them all, but there is a noticeable improvement in how quickly I can shave my neck. Also, there is less skin irritation compared to what I felt with the Braun's and I have never felt the hairs being pulled like I did with the Norelco's. I have to say, the Panasonic is the best performing shaver I have used and ironically the least expensive (my Brauns and Norelcos cost in the 150 - 190 range [note, cleaning/charge kits are a waste of money]). Negatives: There are two negatives that I feel could have been avoided in the design department. 1) The shaver has a weak trimmer, just like the Norelco's. I'm not sure why companies feel like they can cheapen a feature that gets used on a daily basis. TheBraun's are the only shavers that have a consistently strong trimmer. The weak trimmer on the Panasonic can clean up the edges of sideburns, but it does not trim down a 3-day weekend beard that you prepare to shave. This is quite frustrating for me because I still need to use my old Braun for this purpose. 2) The other source of frustration is a design flaw that is so ridiculous, I'm not sure why it even exists. You cannot use the shaver while it is plugged into the wall. I understand that Li-Ion batteries (like any other rechargable battery) have a limited number recharge cycles in their lifetime (think laptop battery). Thus, it is important to use an entire charge before you recharge the battery because frequent recharging will lead to a shortened life. Problem is, if you are accustomed to shaving until the battery reaches 0%, you may find yourself with a half shaven face while you wait for the battery to recharge. Not only that, but what happens down the road when the battery gets older and loses its charging capacity? With my Braun's, at least I can still plug them into the wall and they will work like new for as long as I want. In conclusion, I can shave my face and neck faster with the Panasonic than with any other model I have used--and with less skin irritation. This is important to me. Also the price is more reasonable than the Braun's and Noreclo's I have tried. Overall, I recommend this shaver and I think you will enjoy it--just be aware of the design limitations mentioned above.

I just ordered another one for my second home.

I have been using this shaver wet with a small amount of shave cream and it is unbelievable. I get the closest shaves I have ever had and can use it every day. After shaving, I simply run it under water to rinse and then put a drop of normal hand soap on it and let it run for 30 seconds. It basically cleans itself. It also tracks the battery life and time used, so it's really easy to see when it needs a charge, which isn't too often. Great product!

The wet-dry usability and ease of cleaning make shaving a welcome daily activity. Panasonic's return policy and warranty are good and the entire unit packs easily for trips. I have a mid level beard and use the shaver daily, normally dry and have had no rash or burn.   199. Shaving with an electric can leave your face, and especially your neck, red and raw and you without the smooth results you want. At least this is my experience with them. In the last few years, I've owned and tried several, including Braun and their latest 790cc, a few by panasonic including the ES7037, and a few others. None of them were very impressive so I approach buying a new shaver with caution. I had a choice to make recently when I left my ES7037 power adapter at a hotel. I could get a new one or get a new shaver. I opted to take my chances with a new shaver. I got the most expensive one Best Buy had to offer (not recommended since its a lot cheaper here) in part because it had good reviews here. I ripped it open in the parking lot and began to shave my 2 day old scruff. It had only 10% charge so I seriously doubted I could finish shaving. After about 5 minutes or less I was done and my face and neck were smoother than I can ever remember. Not only was it fast but it was extremely effective and didn't redden my neck like some do. I have to say that this is the best shaver I have ever owned. Oh, and it still had 10% charge left when I was done so it seems to be pretty efficient as well. There are a lot of rave reviews on the 790cc, but it doesn't work so well for me... it might for you. If you've tried it and weren't impressed then the Panny might be what you're looking for.
  200. I may not be the ideal person to give a review, but I'll try. This is my first electric shaver, and after many years of using a single blade, yes, a single blade, I moved to this thing. I have soft skin and have had a slow-growing beard my whole life until the last year. That's why I've finally moved to an electric. I've always wanted one, but saw no use for it. Heck, I didn't need double blades until last year. Well, like all Panasonic products, this thing works as it claims to. I have strong chin and jaw lines and didn't think this would work so great but the first time I used it , it got everything but the hair on my neck and underchin. I used it wet with shaving cream in the shower. I noticed that the less the shave cream, the better. In fact, this thing cuts better without lather, but won't glide so well on your face, so a little bit of lather is better. Anyways, this shaver cuts well. As for the hair under your chin, you have to go over slowly, but it will get everything if you have a shower mirror to see what's left behind. The trimmer is pretty good, but could be more effective. I use it, but wouldn't suggest it for shaping anything. The shaver is easy to clean too. It looks great with the blue metallic finish. The reasons I got this one are that the others were too expensive, had a cleaning system I didn't want, or weren't of a good enough quality in my opinion. For the $125 I spent, I felt this was the best choice for me, and I feel I made the right decision. I've never been let down by a Panasonic product. Perhaps the top-of-line Braun is better, I wouldn't know, and I really don't care. What I do know is that anything more would be unnecessary for me and if a product has the quality I appreciate, then I'll just stick with it, rather than get something newer or more sophisticated. A great product overall and I'm very happy, but this thing can always perform better of course. For example, for thick beard hair like mine and most guys,you'll have to go over to make sure everything's cut. This happens on all electric shavers b/c some hairs simply will not fit easily through the foil's holes to get cut. But I'm sure this is better than pretty much every other shaver out there except that Braun or something. Still, I'm extremely happy and this is more than enough for the money. As for a product that IS perfect: if anyone who reads this is interested in a hair clipper that will crush pretty much anything else out there, or at the very least cuts just as well, try the Panasonic ER 153A. It's the sickest thing you'll own for grooming. It is cordless and is also of professional quality with ceramic and titanium-coated blades that slice right through hair. (I have thick hair that always gets comments by barbers and stylists.) It was the only professional cordless hair cutter I could find at the time (several years ago). It is also extremely lightweight and compact for a professional clipper, not to mention far easier to use with its attachments than American or European clippers. So easy to use that it can be used as a trimmer as well for beards or your crotch hair lol. It's that good. It is ridiculously easy to use and It still works as well as the first day I bought it, seriously. I've easily saved the $180 that cost from not having to go to a barber. I hope this shaver works just as long. If four foils are not necessary for you (for me it isn't, but it also didn't make the shaver more cumbersome or less precise), then the 8103S is your best bet with three foils. I probably would be just as happy with that one as well. The three models that cost more than this were simply too large and sophisticated for me so I passed on them.

  207. I've spent half my life shaving with Norelco razors, believing I was getting a good shave. But that was only until a few months ago, when my trusty Norelco broke and I found the parts for it can't be obtained any longer. I started searching out a new one, but I didn't care for the comments I was reading about the current Norelco (Phillips) and Braun models and I landed on this Panasonic. What appealed to me was that fact that it is simply cleaned with a little soap and water. I wanted to give it some time before giving any feedback and now that a few months have passed, I think I can give some qualified comments. The razor feels good in my hands. It's comfortable to hold and easy to maneuver around my face and neck. It's a slight bit noisier than I imagined it would be, but still not bad. It gives a close shave, even on my neck and around the Adam's apple, and is a closer shave than any Norelco rotary I ever had -- and possibly even better than a blade. I'm able to shave in 3 - 4 minutes if I shave every day or every-other day. If I go beyond two days, the razor doesn't get bogged down, but it does take 7 to 10 minutes to get the same great results. I wear a fu-manchu moustache and a soul patch. I was concerned that a shaver with such a large head couldn't shave around it as well as a 3-head rotary could, but I was pleasantly surprised. It gets right up close and I'm even able to use it to shave the space on either side of soul patch out to the corner of my mouth... and that's with the shaver head, not the retractable trimmer. The retractable trimmer has very fine teeth and does a great job on the side-burns. The battery on this shaver requires charging every 7 to 10 days. I expected more, but this is certainly good enough. After each shave, I remove the head cover and blow out the clippings. The \\"clean shaver\\" light seems to come on about once between each charge cycle and it's very simple to do. Follow the instructions in the booklet and the razor is clean and refreshed in just a moment or two. I love my new razor and wish I made the change from shaving with a rotary to foil shaving sooner. I get a clean and close shave from this shaver -- consistently across my cheeks, chin, and neck. And my girlfriend loves the smoothness of my cheeks on her thighs, too! Stay thirsty my friends!

Downside Braun appears to be better made with more metal. Pany is light and plastic almost everywhere. Don't drop it.

  223. Buy the Panasonic ES8243! Why shave over the same area 4 times to get a good shave? This razor really is a BIG step up from others I've owned. After 10 months, I'm looking to buy one for my 16 year old. I rarely write reviews, but this is a great product! Don't compromise on a cheap razor. PRO's + Razor head, not just the blades, adjust to my face. The spring action moves it up and down smoothly. It also swivels side to side, but you can lock it to be stiff. + Cut somewhat long hair going back-to-front on the blades and then a close shave going the normal front-to-back. + Get a grip that fits your hand and has textured, soft plastic to hold when wet. + Shave the back of your neck easily because of all the above. + Best trimmer I've owned on electric razors. It flexes without feeling flimsy. Nice cut too. + Cleaning is much easier than the old rotary razors I had. Hold the power and the head switches to a high vibration for a sonic-like clean with liquid soap and water. Easy to pop the top too. + Switches for power and the trimmer are placed for easy reach with your thumb. + Display tells you how much power is left. + Recharges very quickly and then flashes the display to tell you it's at 100%. Holds charge long enough that I don't take the charger on week-long trips. + Flat design packs easily. + Plug is thin enough to fit something in the plug receptacle next to it. + No pig tail cord that gets caught on itself, just straight wire. CON's - My difficult neck spot still takes more than one pass to cut hair. - The display turns off quickly. Either look at it quickly or read before turning off. - My son wants mine.
  224. I hate shaving. I purchased my first electric razor years ago on a whim. It was a Norelco rotary and I was suprised that it gave me an adequate shave. I used it until it wore out then I purchased an ancestor of this model a Panasonic wet dry shaver. Loved it but it slipped out of my hands in the shower one morning and the blade apparatus broke rendering the shaver useless. So I purchased a braun 360 model which seemed to work pretty well and has lasted me 4 years. It came time to puchase new blades for the braun along with new cleaning cartridges so I went online to see if I couldn't upgrade for just a few more bucks than the blades/refill would cost. The top of the line braun is outrageously priced. At under $100 bucks this razor is a steal. I also shave my head with the electric razor and my hair is tough so I am a demanding customer. I used this for a week dry shaving in the morning and it outperformed my braun. This morning I gave it a try by doing a wet shave using King of Shaves gel / oil and... WOW. This razor shaved as close as the gillette fusion blades!! Amazing shave!! Pros: The best shave out of all the electric razors I have used. As close as Gillette without spending a fortune on the fusion blades. Did an awesome job on my head as well as my neck - both tough areas. Cons: the fat head doesn't do too well shaving around a goatee / facial hair Consensus: This electric razor is a steal at under $100. If you are in the market for an electric razor buy it
  225. I have very sensitive skin, and after years of using blades, this is my second electric shaver. Previously I bought the Philips Norelco 7810 and it was cheap, but not good. I got razor burn constantly, I had to go over the same spots again and again to get all the hair. I decided it would be worth the money if I could find a better shaver, so I tried this one, and though it is twice as expensive it works much better. It works pretty well on my dry face, getting almost of the hairs quickly and painlessly, I have to go over a few spots on my neck multiple times. Like a lot of guys I have a lot of contours on my neck and I don't think any sort of shaving system will be created in my lifetime that can cut all of the hairs on my neck in one pass. I can only hope for my children. Anyway, the best way that I have found to use this shaver is to apply shave cream right after a shower (I have only tried Cremo Cream, which works fine) and it feels like I am massaging my face with a vibrating stick of warm butter. It doesn't hurt at all, no shave burn at all, just a mild feeling of heat. The only drawback (and the subtraction of a star) is that I have to go over the same area multiple times, then I have to wash off the cream, reinspect, and go over again without cream to get all the remaining hairs. The cream remaining on the shaver is enough, so I don't need to reapply cream to my face. This takes an extra minute, but the end result is a smooth face that feels moisturized, and no nicks, cuts, or burn. The shave is not as close as a blade, but good enough for me.
  226. I am 42, and have been shaving since I was 15 with nothing but Norelco electric shavers. My last Norelco was a top of the line model, purchased about 4 years ago. I thought having to go over my face 10 different times, using 10 different angles and spending 10 minutes doing so, was just the price of using an electric shaver...........That is until I bought the Panasonic Arc IV! Just like you, I read all of the reviews on this shaver, and I thought \\"What the heck, I'll give it a try\\". It is hands down the best shaver I have ever used. I have only used it dry, and I will probably only use it dry. I have \\"average Joe\\" stubble, and my shaves are all under 4 minutes long, and they are the closest shaves that I have ever experienced. I just cleaned it for the first time, and that too is the easiest, and most complete experience that I have had cleaning a shaver. Some dish soap, hot water and 3 minutes, and it looks just like new. I shaved for a week and the \\"clean shaver\\" indicator never came on, so I cleaned it anyway. Next time I will wait for the indicator to come on before I clean it. I could go on and on about this shaver, but if you are wondering if it is really as good as the hype, I say no, it isn't.........................It's better!!
  227. This shaver is excellent. I've only used it a few times but its the smoothest shave I ever got. Much better and more comfortable on the skin than my previous Panasonic, which was just OK. Price is great, value is excellent. Works great wet or dry but is really impressive with shaving cream. A great buy.
  228. Excellent, panasonic rules

Great, close shave and it even did a good job on those hard-to-get neck hairs. Of course, there were a few stragglers that took more than one pass. But on the whole it did a great job. And it didn't pull a single hair. This is a win-win for me, because now I know what to get my brother and dad for Christmas. Great product.

  232. I always used a Norelco...until now. It used to take me 30-40 minutes to shave, and now, it takes me 5! No more problems with my stubborn hairs, it just comes right off. The blades are super sharp, and it usually only takes 1-2 strokes to get all of the hair off.

I read previous reviews of this shaver and purchased it based on those reviews.After one month I have already had to return it to Panasonic because the enclosed literature said that you can get up to 14 shaves out of a single charge, I found that I was getting no more then 5.I have a light beard and a shave takes no more then 3 to 4 minutes.I also found that it could not get the hairs at the corner of my mouth.I will not buy another Panasonic shaver.
  234. It does not provide ultra close shave but it does what it does for the cost.
  235. I bought my first razor, the Norelco 5821XL, back in 1998. I have never replaced a part on it, and used it almost daily for 11 years. Eventually, the battery leaked, and shorted the razor, frying a resistor, and I was forced to move on to a new razor. After several months of research, I settled on the Panasonic ES8243A. The razor comes with a travel pouch and a wall charger. The display is nice, and probably one of the few improvements over the Norelco, which had a full LED and an empty LED. The time to reach 100% was several hours, which seemed reasonable from a Li battery. Shaving dry, I find that this does not perform as well as the Norelco. I have a light beard, and I had read that foil shavers are worse than rotary shavers on light bears, so that did not come as a surprise. I find that shaving wet is a nice option. If I have extra time on the weekend, then I will use colonel conk shaving soap, with a badger hair brush, and I don't need to have two separate shavers to maintain. Only 4 stars, because I expected more improvement in the last 11 years, but I would buy it again.
  236. My 8 year old Norelco that never had the cutters changed, shaved closer and with MUCH less irritation. The Panasonic does poorly on all areas. I have to pull and stretch and shave back and forth and upside down many times over and it still does poorly at the jaw line, neck area (especially) and with the chin and mouth area. Plus this razor actually draws blood! My Noreclo not once had ever cut me. With this razor I suffered cuts on several occasions in attempt to get it to actually shave. Oh well. It's going back and I'll just get another Norelco.
  237. This shaver is amazing. I used to shave with a Mach 3, and then the mid-range Panasonic ES7056 (which was quite good). My beard is *so* coarse, thick, and fast-growing that I would cut myself several times per shave with the Mach 3 (and yes, I do know how to use it properly). I then switched to the Panasonic ES7056 which gave me a decent shave without the cuts. Unfortunately, that broke after two years of use and I upgraded to shaver that I'm reviewing now (the Panasonic ES8243A Arc IV). There is a definite difference between my old Panasonic and this one. If my old Panasonic was good, this new one is hands down better, with the razor making short work of my very coarse hair. The four blades do not appear to be a gimmick--I definitely feel like I am able to shave more quickly with this razor. My old Panasonic razor came with a one year warranty. I am glad to see that this one comes with a two year warranty on battery and razor considering that my last Panasonic electric razor broke just before the two year mark. Pros: Probably the best shaver available, waterproof (can use in the shower, which I do regularly), very easy to clean (don't bother getting the more expensive version with the cleaning station...it cleans itself), two year warranty. This is a no fuss razor that does its job and does it VERY well. Cons: There are a couple small spots on my neck that I still have to go over multiple times in order to get everything (this has been a problem with every razor that I've owned in the past)...although, this problem is much improved with this new Panasonic (I guess no electric is perfect) , replacement blades / foil is expensive (they're around $40, I can't comment yet on how long the foil will last but if it's anything like my last Panasonic, it should go at least a year), at over $100, it's not cheap (but it is worth-it). Final thoughts: if you have a beard that is thick and/or tough to shave, I can't recommend this razor highly enough. It's notcheap, but if shaving with a non-electric razor causes many painful cuts (like they do for me), this electric gives a fantastic shave without the pain and embarrassment and for me has been money well spent. Note that if you're used to non-electric razors, it will take at least a few days and possibly a couple weeks for your face to adjust and for you to get the most out of this razor.
  238. Works great, but use shaving cream (or shave butter)
  239. After two years with the ES8243, I'm going back to a rotary. Here's why: - Takes about four minutes to shave each morning, which is about twice as long as with my rotary. - Battery lasts about a week, which is less than half of my rotary. This really decreases its value for travel because I have to take the charger for even short trips, and the charger is relatively huge and heavy. - Very poor shave below the jawline and on the neck (generally a good shave above). - Shaver \\"leaks\\" or sprinkles whisker dust everywhere while in use, which is annoying at the sink, but really eliminates its utility as a shaver you can use while driving/riding to work, or at work unless you don't mind cleaning your desk or the community sink. - After using it as a wet shaver, water drains out as it is moved to different positions, meaning that it's going to leave water in your shave kit when traveling. - High operating cost relative to my rotary. Replacement foils and blades are very expensive (one-half the cost of the whole shaver purchased new on sale) and supposed to be replaced regularly. On the plus side, the construction is good and it generally shaves well to very well (above the jawline), but not any better than my rotary.

The shave was noticeably closer than a dry-shave and considerably less-messy than I had envisioned.   244. Bought for the husband a couple of years ago. He hasn't complained.
  245. First off, I'm one of those guys who has a tough time shaving because my skin's sensitive, I get ingrown hairs, my facial hair grows in different directions depending on which part of my face is being looked at. Because of that, I have to shave against the grain, not in the direction the hair is growing like you see in commercials. I was a bit skeptical about buying another cordless because I owned a Braun before and it was a good product, but it couldn't get the job done as I had to finish my shave with a Gillette. So I saw that the Panasonic ES8243A received a lot of high ratings (many 5-star) and I decided to order it. OK, so this is a bit premature as I have only shaved once with it, but this shave was amazing. Remember, I have a tough time shaving with a normal razor and I typically still have a light darkness (if that makes sense) to my face after I shave as my facial hair is jet-black and I use a 5-blade Gillette, but it seems that no blade can shave me close enough. Well, I just finished charging the Panasonic and decided to test it out and it has been a revelation. It gave me a closer shave than any razor ever has. YES, I SAID IT!!! NO RAZOR HAS EVER GIVEN ME A CLOSER SHAVE!!! The timer is great as you can time your shaves and mine was just under 3 minutes which isn't bad considering how close the shave was and how comfortable it was. I just wet my face with warm water and proceeded with my shave. Also, I have a tough time with the neck area and although I had to go over it a few times with the Panasonic, it got all of the hairs. Not a single follicle was left behind. I checked about 4 times!!! My skin is baby smooth now and no 5 o'clock shadow directly after my shave. It's also a nice looking shaver and well designed ergonomically. So, in a nutshell, that's my first impression of the razor and I would highly recommend it. Take if from someone who dreads shaving everyday. This has actually made me look at my bathroom prep time as less of achore now. I will also follow up a month from now with a second review. Update - January 30, 2011 So I've used this shaver for two weeks now and my face has already adjusted. My first shave was amazing, but the following up until a few days ago were a little rough. Again, my skin's sensitive so I felt some irritation and my shave's weren't as close as I wanted. I tried the shave dry a few times and it doesn't seem to shave as close as I'd like compared to a wet shave. Wet shaves are, of course, really close. I used King of Shaves shave gel that I bought at Walmart for about 3 bucks and it's fantastic. I would highly recommend a wet shave or some sort of light shave gel when using this shaver. I'm amazed at how close a shave I get from the Panasonic ES8243A. It's definitely as close as a top of the line razor and causes way less irritation for me than a razor would. Remember, if you do buy this shaver, as with most or all shavers your face has to adjust so don't be disappointed if your first few shaves are very comfortable. Now that I'm two weeks in I can say that the battery life isn't as bad as most have commented on, but it isn't great, either. I probably get about 6-7 shaves between charges so you can expect about a week's worth of shaves at 3 minutes per between charges. Again, I would highly recommend this cordless shaver. It looks good, is light and ergonomically designed, and best of all gives a fantastic shave.

  251. Read a lot of reviews on this before buying. It lives up to it's promises. I had an electric before but a cheap get-me-by for $39 4 years ago (I procastinated) :) It worked OK and when this arrived my first few dry shaves did not really see an improvement unless I spent some extra time shaving and pressing harder. Even at 3 weeks the dry shaves really have not improved but they are perfectly acceptable. The only downside to it (for me), was gripping it, while comfortable, I find my thumb perfectly over the on/off button and I have turned it off accidently several times when putting on some pressure, although I am getting more sensitive to knowing when I am on it. It's just in the wrong place. I would suggest if they had made a thumb rest where you can get some grip and leverage without hitting the button on accident it would be great. The instructions say pressing harder does not mean a closer shave, I disagree, it does work better and this is where the thumb problem comes in when you want to apply more pressure, you grip harder. I have tried wet shaving and the difference is amazing. It feels like a blade shave on my face afterward, the neck still has some spots hard to get but that is always a problem only mostly solved by a blade. If you need that close shave do it wet, if ya just need a good shave dry is fine. I spend about as much time and make just as much of a mess as doing a blade shave when doing it wet, but it feels easier and you can't argue with no risk of nicking yourself and the blood trouble that comes with that on your way out the door with a white collared shirt :) It is easy to clean. I am at 3 weeks of daily use and it is just now telling me to recharge it, so it has gone way past 14 shaves as they advertise. Maybe I don't shave as long as the normal person. Overall I am very happy with it and would recommend it highly!

  254. I have used various excellent Norelco and Panasonic shavers for nearly 25 years, with my most recent being a Panasonic ES8103S. I have a very tough, fast growing beard, and my job requires frequent evening events. So, my measure of performance is whether or not I have to shave again before heading out for the night. After several Panasonic Linear shavers (which I use primarly wet with shaving cream), my wife gave me a Norelco 1150x for Christmas because of its similar ratings and wet/dry capability. After a few weeks of trial, it just could not match the closeness and comfort of my old Panasonic. So, I purchased the ES8243A in place of it. Astounding. Simply astounding is all I can say. The ES8243A is providing the closest, most comfortable and fastest shave I have ever had in my life when used in wet mode with a thin layer of shaving cream. It buried the Norelco 1150x for both closeness and comfort and beat my well-loved ES8103S. For me, it shaves more closely and comfortably than a blade. I have not even had to use a blade for touch up around my sideburns, which I have always had to do with other electrics. The shave is so superior that I have no need to shave before evening events, and my beard is noticably shorter when I wake up in the morning. And, I have found it equally efficient and effective for a quick dry shave on weekends. In other respects, the ES8243A is very good - comfortable to hold, good trimmer, quiet and decent battery life compared to my previous Panasonics. The LED readout is easy to read and lets you know exactly how much power and time you have left. I also like that the charger plugs directly into the shaver, eliminating the need for a bulky charging stand. It's also an incredible buy at around $100. An added improvement is the 2-year warrantee - a full year longer than my previous Panasonics. The Norelco's been returned, my beloved ES8103S is now my travel shaver, and this ES8243A is now my best friend in the morning. It is clearly the best shaver I have ever owned.

  269. I just turned 60 and have always used a straight-edge razor to shave. I was turned off by the price of the cartridges, so I decided to purchase my first electric razor.   271. This shaver is twice as fast as my two previous Norelco's - 15 minutes rather than 30. It has a high speed motor. My best results are with the head set for steady rather than floating. For an electric, this is the one to buy! Still, a safety razor does give me a faster shave, nicks and all.
  272. ive used this for a couple of months now. for me it works great. with a regular razor i get irritation when im working because of sweat. this razor causes very little irritation. almost as close as a razor. i can shave my whole face in about 3 minutes but i might miss a few. if u take your time and shave in a mirror you could probably shave in 5 minutes or so. if i could shave with it plugged in it would get 5 stars. this is my first electric razor and i love it. much easier and faster than regular razor. i cant cut any hair on my adams apple or it will cut me a little though.

This is my first Nano razor and it's quieter than my old one. I thought the high speed and bigger head would cut my shaving time in half, but it hasn't really changed much. It does a much cleaner job, so I guess I'm not checking for stray wiskers like I used to. This razor has a bigger shaving foil and it seems bulky compared to my old one. I have a hard time shaving around my mustache without making it uneven, but that will probably get better. I do like it!

  291. This is by far the best electric shaver I've owned and used. My previous electric shavers include bruan series 3, travel shaver, and remington. This is by far the runaway winner. I did tons of research before buying this shaver.I knew I would want to spend around 100 bucks and this was available for 94.99 at the time of my purchase. I chose this because of the excessive amount of good reivews and it did not disappoint! I believed this is the closest shave you can get with an electric shaver. (No electric shaver can compete with straight razor) Sure, you can try the best and the latest shavers such as the Braun Pulsonic or even the lastest 93k Panasonic Shavers for a lot more money. But this gets the JOB done. That's the main goal right? I thought Braun Pulsonic shavers were overhyped and overpriced and it operate only at 10k RPM. This shaver runs at 13 RPM. 93k Panasonic seems too bulky for my likings and extra 100 dollars is not worth it. You do not need to pay extra money for newer products when this ES8243A does the same job if not better. I use this Panasonic ES8243A everyday for about 3-4 minutes each time in the morning. It is convenient just like all electric shavers but it gives you the close shave and smoothness comparable to fusion pro-glide. I can grow about full beard in about 2 days and it gets every hair off of my face. I do not even get 5 o'clock shadow now because this shaver gets close as shaving with a razor. Also, I have sensitive skin and this shaver doesn't not give me any redness or irritation at all. Unless you are extremely lazy and have never wash anything in your life, you do NOT need its own cleaning device. All you need is remove the foil head and rinse under hot water for about 15-20 seconds. It has its own Turbo Mode used for cleaning running at 17k RPM. All in all, Pros - Closest and smooth shave you can get with an electric! Can compete with the latest electric shavers. - Powerful motor - No irritation- Compact Design - Around 100 bucks - Quick charge and last around 10-14 days Cons - Bad placement for the pop up trimmer. The 4 blades gets in the way. And the trimmer itself is too small.
  292. Excellent quality, great controls, great features, but it takes me so much longer to shave my face with this than it does a blade. I have to keep going over the same areas to get them smooth. Maybe all electric razors are like that? If they are, then this should get 5 stars. Maybe it's because it only has 2 coils instead of 3? I don't have anything to compare it to, unfortunately. If you've never used an electric, expect irritation for the first week or two, but then it goes away as your face gets used to it.

  298. I needed to replace my old Panasonic electric shaver, which lasted for 7 years, including a year-long combat deployment in Iraq. Having made a previous mistake of switching to a Braun shaver, which yielded a terrible shave, I researched reviews on Amazon and other websites to find the very best replacement. Bingo! This model, the ES8243A , equipped with cool-sounding \\"Nanotech Blades\\" is a marked upgrade from my old reliable version. \\"How so?\\" Well, I'm glad you asked...<br />1. Four blades are better than two. I know that this might provoke a \\"No Duh\\" response, but the added blade array cuts my average shave time in half.<br />2. \\"Silence is Golden\\". This razor is easily 50% quieter than my old one, even when my previous model was brand new. My Spousal Unit, who enjoys the perks of retirement such as sleeping in, while I'm up getting ready for work at Oh-Dark-Thirty, thanked me this morning for electing to shave on the drive to the office...then was surprised to find me clean-shaven. Nice dividend, though I ended up being late to work as a result...<br />3. Lighter weight shaver (hey, 6 oz is 6 oz!) makes it a better travel partner. The power cord is also much lighter and less bulky. For longer trips, that's a plus!<br />4. Cleans up nicely using liquid soap and running water, so I don't have to mess with that cumbersome cleaning base...which seemed like a good idea at the time, but in practice was about 10% Awesome.<br />5. The blue color matches my eyes, which for some reason my Spousal Unit finds irresistible.<br />6. The price was very reasonable, as I expect this sucker to last for at least 5 years.<br />7. Last, but definitely NOT least, this razor gives me a superb, close, comfortable shave! I plan to try it in the shower once our in-progress bathroom remodel is completed, using the highly-recommended \\"Billy Jealousy Shaving Gel\\". Spousal Unit has given two enthusiastic \\"thumbs up\\" for the scent, but we both think the name is goofy as hell.<br /><br />My only potential concern with the ES8243A is the lighter-construction of the shaver head, which is thin plastic. My old razor sported a metal head, which came in handy when my rucksack got dumped out of the helo 15 feet above the LZ.   335. I have a cat who, back when I had whiskers and a mustache, liked to settle on my chest just after I woke up and nuzzle my face, and then when I least expected it, would yank out a mustache hair. That's what it was like with the electric razor I inherited from my dad when he got a new one. Bzzz, bzzz, bzzz, bzzz, OUCH! As a result, I gave up on electrics and went to blades during the clean-shaven phases of my life.<br /><br />The disposables work well the first few times, but invariably let you know when to replace them by the amount of blood they draw. Plus, I have this scar on my upper lip from a flying piece of metal in the machine shop that's difficult to shave around, hence the long periods of facial hairyness.<br /><br />Now, however, I'm embarking on a new career which requires me to be clean-shaven. Tired of disposables, I read the reviews on Amazon and decided to give the Panasonic a try, primarily because I can use it in the shower to save a little time in the mornings. I'm pleased to say the shaver has lived up to its reviews. My face feels as clean as with a blade, but without the fear of cuts. I can even bear down a little on the upper lip scar; no problems and it's as clean as a whistle. After only two weeks, I'm VERY pleased with the shaver.<br /><br />I've tried it with just a wet face, but it does need a soap for smooth motion. When I used a blade, my choice of soap was a shaving gel. That works okay with the razor, and I got about the same results with a drugstore generic foam for sensitive faces, but the best results of all have been with a coconut oil based liquid soap called Dr. Bronner's that my wife uses. Just a couple or three drops rubbed between the hands then applied on a wet face gives me that blade-close shave. The daily morning chore is a chore no more.<br /><br />As to the battery life, I've been getting 9 shaves to the charge (I recharge it when it gets down to 10%). It is indeed waterproof, and the small cheapo mirror I hung in the shower makes it easy to see and get at all the areas of beard (if the mirror fogs, rub a couple of fingers on the soap bar then wipe the mirror with them to keep the fog off). You'll need to experiment for a bit for find the best motion pattern for making sure you get all the stubble off.the areas of beard (if the mirror fogs, rub a couple of fingers on the soap bar then wipe the mirror with them to keep the fog off). You'll need to experiment for a bit for find the best motion pattern for making sure you get all the stubble off.

  340. So I am a believer in razors getting a close shave. One thing that you have to understand about me is that I have a very rough beard. So if I wait to long it can horrible to shave. So I wanted to get an electric razor to try out. I didn't like the electric razors I have tried from friends. They were the circular kind. So i sent out to get a linear one. Well, I got this one and it has done me well. I actually used it today in the shower and it works well. I have tried to use it with shaving cream, conditioner, dry, and wet with water and for my face wet with water works best. Keep in mind that everyone's face is different and it will take a little time to find what works best. I would recommend this razor to anyone.
  341. I tried it dry, wet, with shaving cream and brush, I tried with hot water and after bath, tried different angles and ways.   342. It was a gift for my wife. She prefers a man's shaver. She believes they are more durable than a ladies. She has used it several times since Christmas and gives it rave initial reviews. She also likes the pop up trimmer feature.
  343. I purchased the Panasonic ES8243A about a month ago. I am absolutely satisfied with this product, use wet and dry method and get a close shave every time. If your looking at this razo..do not hesitate...BUY IT!
  344. I have had this shaver about a month now. I was not totally sold on it the first few shaves but after getting my face broken in on a elec shaver (I have used a blade several years)I am completely sold on it. Elec shavers I have used in the past would not cut my neck hairs and every several days I would have to get a razor after them, not now. This Panasonic does the job, I am completely sold on it. Oh yea, and my wife thinks my face is soft again.
  345. I have shaved my head since 1996 and have been through many devices since then. This is hands down the best electronic device to provide that service so far.<br /><br />I have sworn by Norelco® triple-headers for years and laughed at the thought of trying to shave my hard, round head with a rectangular screen, when the three 'floating' heads of the Norelco seemed to get every nook and cranny, scar and bump.<br /><br />Then I read reviews of this Panasonic® and convinced myself that it wasn't very pricey and thought I'd give it a try. The first time I used it, I made a pass on the side of my head above my right ear and then paused, felt the newly-shaved patch and marveled: That one was one close shave!<br /><br />This one is definitely louder than the Norelco, but the 13,000 RPM motor makes quick work and smooth shaving a breeze. (NOTE: I only get 4-5 days of shaving between charges if I do both head and beard; the Norelco provides at least double that).<br /><br />Yeah--I could get a little closer with a blade, but who wants to cut their head shaving AND pay Gillette an arm and a leg for a small package of Fusion® blades on what seems to be a way too frequent basis?<br /><br />My one complaint is the very flimsy 'traveling case' that is nothing more than a thin leather-like, zippered, razor-shaped bag -- that does not protect the razor in almost any way (unless you are worried about scratches). The first time I tucked it into my suitcase, I accidentally hit the 'on' button on the razor through the case. Good thing I heard its 13,000 RPM engine to alert me before I closed the lid!
  346. Very easy to use, and it holds a charge for about a week of shaving. When it does need to be recharged, you can get enough of a charge for a quick shave after 10-15 minutes of charging. The head snaps apart for easy cleaning. Have not tried using it in the shower, even though it says you can.
  347. I purchased this shaver (model 8243A) this past May 2009. It's my third Panasonic shaver. I've tried Brauns, Norelcos, and even a Grundig shaver over the years, but Panasonic seems to be the best - for me at least. I have sensitive skin, so shaving in the shower works best to keep the blades cool and delivers an irritation free, very close shave (try this shaver in combination with a little Billy Jealousy Hydroplane Shaving Cream for a truly close, irritation free shave). I would say an even better shave than the Gillette Fusion because I experience absolutely no minor cuts or irritation when using the Panasonic. (I only use the Gillette when I forget to charge my shaver!) Like I said, I purchased this shaver this past May, and five months later the LCD began displaying unintelligible readings. Then the shaver just died - it wouldn't turn on. I've never had that sort of problem with my Panasonics in the past, and since it was still well within the 2 year warranty, I contacted Panasonic by phone. I was instructed to ship the shaver to their service center in Texas. About 2 weeks later, I received a new replacement shaver in the mail, and get this, Panasonic sent me a brand spankin' new model ES8249K - the Arc 4 Nanotech shaver with the Vortex cleaning system. I was a little annoyed by the turn around time, but it was obviously worth the wait! The ES8249K shaves exactly the same as the 8243A - it's the same shaver but just can be used in the Vortex, whereas the 8243A can't. Thanks Panasonic for your awesome shaving product and awesome customer support! You've got a loyal customer in me, and like Ahhnold in The Terminator, \\"I'll be baaaack\\" when it's time to purchase my next shaver! :-)
  348. I bought this shaver, opened the box, turned it on and it was so loud that I didn't even want to put it near my face. It takes me about 7 to 10 minutes to shave and having this shaver next to my ear for that period of time was a scary thought. My previous shaver was a Norelco which was much much quieter. I also didn't like how big the head of the Panasonic shaver was. It looked too big to shave the area under my nose. I packed up the Panasonic shaver and returned it without even using it so I can't comment on how it shaves. I then bought the Norelco 8240XL which is 75% quieter than the Panasonic and I am happy with it.
  349. After fewer than 15 shaves I love the comfortable feel of the razor in my hand, the power of the razor, the close, smooth shave it gives, the quick, easy cleaning process, and the digital display that tells everything you need to know. The somewhat short battery life is more than compensated for by the fast recharge. At a little over $100, it's a bargain and the best razor I've ever owned in 60 years of shaving. --Steve DeWolf Hendersonville, NC
  350. This a very good shaver and works well on tuff beards. This is the best shaver I have had by far. Cleans easy and I really like being able to see how much time I have used it and battery life. Takes very little time to charge it and seems to hold a charge for a week.
  351. Very smooth and effective, although a bit slower than I would prefer
  352. Good razor, no complaints, like the wet dry, east to clean.
  353. I have had this razor for a couple of weeks now and I am very pleased with it. I have used an electric razor for several years as I would get cuts regularly with a regular razor. However, this razor is much better than either of the previous two electric razors I have had. I did spend a little more on this one than the last one but I think the three advantages to this one are the moving head, the four blades and the fact that you can shave with shaving gel vs dry. This razor in my opinion shaves almost as close as a regular razor but without the razor burns and cuts you get from a regular razor. With my old electric razor if I didn't shave for a day I would have to use a regular razor as my electric razor would not shave me well with that much growth. This Panasonic razor has no problem giving me a great shave even after skipping a day of shaving. It did take my face a couple of weeks to adjust to the closer shave.
  354. Overall, this is a very good product. I say this after having previously owned two Remington electric shavers (about 4 years), the last one being the Remington Titanium MS280 shaver. I have also been a long-time wet shaver and have a ton of experience with Mach 3, Schick Quattro, and Merkur Double Edge razors (have tried Feather, Gillette, Bic, Dorco, Crystal, Derby, Merkur, etc. blades) via wet shaving. The Remington shavers usually got a pretty close shave, however this close shave was accompanied by a lot of skin irritation (razor burn), mostly around the neck area due to repeated passes; although, I did find that applying baby powder before the shave would help with the burning a bit. As for the wet shaves, they mostly produced very close shaves, but often the amount of time it would take me to achieve such a close shave (on average about 15-20 mins.), and the resulting nicks and cuts on my face, plus ingrown hairs, eventually had me abandon this method of shaving. It wasn't efficient and ultimately became incredibly frustrating - I tried before-shower, after-shower, shave brush, no shave brush, and used tons of different types of shave creams and gels and ridiculous combinations of this and that before I said, this sucks. So, my brother purchased this same shaver, but with the cleaning dock. He let me do a trial shave on his, so I have to give him credit for introducing me to this product, even though I ended up buying the shaver without this cleaning dock. A little bit about me, my beard, and my shaving habits - I'm a 25 year-old engineer, I have incredibly sensitive skin (I sunburn easily, get razor burn easily, and get dry skin often in the winter), my beard is pretty dense (about 7/10 on the density scale), not extremely dense, but the whiskers are extremely coarse (about 9/10 on the coarseness scale) and curve slightly toward my face after a few days of growth; consequently, my beard is very prone to ingrown hairs. I shave around 4-5 days per week, usually letting the weekend scruff go for about 2-3 days. When I shave, it's usually in the mornings (pre-shower). I always shave dry, but do apply Williams Lectric shave (w/ Green Tea extract) to my beard pre-shave to straighten those whiskers and slightly lubricate the shaving surface of my skin. One complete and close shave, usually after one full day's growth, will take me about 7-8 mins. on average. Now to the review: Sound when operating - In my opinion the Remington shavers that I have used emitted a much deeper-toned and coarser piercing sound when in operation. This sound was often pretty loud also (9/10 on loudness scale), and sometimes would hurt my ears when I was shaving close to them. The Remington shavers would often pull slightly on my hairs when going over them, and the motor would noticeably strain when navigating through thick patches on my face, most notably on my chin and stache regions. This Panasonic shaver, by comparison, has a much higher-pitched sound - I believe due to its much higher RPM motor. The motor really seems to have plenty of power, even for my very coarse beard. I've heard some people say this Panasonic shaver is pretty loud. I would say that in comparison to the Remingtons I've used, it's definitely quieter and less harsh on the eardrums. That being said, it is not a very quiet shaver. It reminds me a bit of my Sonicare toothbrush with that high-pitched almost sonic wine, and this sound coupled with the sound of your hairs being mowed down can be considered somewhat noisy by some people's standards. In my opinion though, this thing is a 7/10 on the loudness scale, about average, but definitely tolerable (a 10/10 would be ear-piercing and painful most of the time). Closeness of shave - This thing definitely gets a pretty close shave. It does have four blades, as advertised. It has two independent blades within the shaving compartment of the shaving head, and two additional blades located on the exterior of the shaving head, located between the two screens protecting the two internal blades. The two blades on the surface of the razor head interlock with each other during operation to create the effect of a trimmer almost (imagine two razor sharp screens slightly overlapping each other; the hairs enter the holes in the screen, and as the screens move toward each other, they cut the hairs; the screens move out again away from each other such that the holes realign and the hair slips in again. Etc., etc. This repeats but at hyper speed!). Hopefully I was able to explain the operation of the external blades ok. Altogether, the four blades working together in sonic-speed harmony really seem to create an irritation-free shave, and never do I notice a hair-pulling sensation as I did with the Remington shavers. The biggest plus with this razor is that is produces little but mostly 0% shaving irritation! Usually, I get no irritation at all whatsoever; although I have to say that on occasion, when I spend too much time on my neck going over the same area several times, I will get a very slight burning sensation, but this never results in really any redness - just a slight burning sensation (nothing a little bit of Nivea post-shave lotion can't fix!!) This phenomenon really threw me at first but after using this razor for almost 2 months now, I am REALLY impressed with that aspect of the shave. Overall, the closeness of the shave above my jaw-line would rank a 9/10 (10/10 being a Mach III shave) and about an 8.5/10 on my neck. Pretty good considering the short time invested. Design - This thing fits pretty ergonomically in my hand. It is very lightweight and sits comfortably in my hand during operation. The high motor speed transfers very little vibration to the handle or head surface, resulting in a very comfortable and manageable grip and shave. The shiny blue body is very sharp, especially in contrast with the orange font digital readout on the LCD screen,telling you the elapsed time of the shave in minutes and seconds (i.e., 7'08\\" would be 7 mins. 8 secs.). This screen also flashes the battery life remaining (i.e., 80%) for about 3 seconds after you turn the razor off but before the screen dims completely for power-down. There is a single push button power switch to turn the razor on and off. It is conveniently located and the razor reacts instantly once it is pushed. If you hold this button down for greater than say 5 seconds, it will enact \\"cleaning mode\\" which basically is like a turbo mode that increases the motor RPMs and lasts for about 20 seconds before turning off automatically (I have not found a real use for this feature yet). The razor head is somewhat bulky in size, and the cover enclosing the screen is made of a durable and lightweight plastic, as is most of the razor. Note - the large razor head does make it somewhat difficult to shave around facial hair, i.e., sideburns, stache, goatee, etc. due to its wide size. The razor head is spring loaded with a gentle suspension that allows the head to tilt left and right, up and down, to better glide along the contours of your face. The head may also be switched to the locked position, which will give the head rigidity and restrict its movement. The trimmer that pops out is somewhat useful but it is not the best design I've seen. In this respect, the Remington razors do outperform this Panasonic here in terms of trimmer effectiveness, use, and design. The somewhat narrow Panasonic trimmer pops out at about a 110 degree angle from the body and seems to have a difficult time staying in the locked position whenever I use it to trim any stubborn hairs that I missed during shaving. Also, the funky angle that this trimmer sits when extended makes it tough to trim missed hairs on your face, but especially more difficult to do so on the neck. For making a straight edge on sideburns, it works quite well, however. Cleaning - The reason I purchased this standalone razor over the package with the cleaning and charging dock is pretty simple. You don't need the charging/cleaning dock! Cleaning this razor is effortless. As many have said here, a drip of dish soap on the screen spread with your finger all over the razor head while running under hot water for about 20 seconds is all you really need (do this while the razor is on of course). I of course pop off the razor head to make sure to rinse off the internal compartment with the internal blades (do this when the razor is off so water doesn't splash all over the place), but in total, cleaning takes about 30 seconds!! This is great because I have felt that my Remington dry razors would sometimes accumulate bacteria on the screen over time and this would be evident on my face via breakouts of achne, etc. Charging and battery life - Charging is a breeze and takes about an hour from 0% - 100%, as others have said here. The cord plugs directly into the wall and plugs right into the bottom of the razor. I would say that the battery life, for me, lasts about the equivalent of 4-5 good shaves. Also, this is rated for up to 220 volts AC. Just brought this with me on my on trip to Australia and it handled the 220V AC power there no problem. (US uses 110V AC power). Overall impression and final notes - If you buy this razor, you must know this FACT: this will not get quite as close as a Mach 3! However, it gets pretty dang close! If you are willing to compromise a bit of shave closeness in exchange for ZERO irritation, then this is the razor you've been waiting for. For me, using this razor saves me time, as compared with wet shaving with a Mach III, so in my case, this is an added benefit. This shaver claims that it will get a close shave on the first pass, but I have yet to see this. Often I will go over the same area a few times (gently of course, and that is key!) to make sure that I get every hair ground down as close as possible. This is especially true on my neck, as the hairs seem to change direction all over the place. Also, I find that stretching the skin on your neck during shaving with this razor will help to expose some hard-to-cut hairs, especially on the outer regions and on the adam's apple. Definitely use some sort of pre-shave lotion. As I said previously, Williams Lectric shave is definitely liquid gold, super cheap, and will last you a while. People with facial hair may find this razor has a tough time shaving around such places. This razor works best for full-face and neck shaves, with minimal facial hair to navigate around. The replacement blade/screen razor head cartridges are expensive ($50), but this annual cost is still cheaper than buying Mach III refills and shaving cream over the span of a year. Very importantly, this shave is most efficient after a day or two of full growth. Any more growth than this, and this razor really becomes less efficient. I tried shaving a week's worth of growth and it takes a lot longer (2x)! It also requires use of the trimmer to get the longer growth hairs that this razor seems to miss beyond 3 day's growth. And lastly, don't buy the cleaning dock! It is truly a gimmick and a waste of money! Otherwise, props to Panasonic for this tactfully engineered consumer grade electric shaver! I am a new convert! Cheers, Rob
  355. Purchased ES8243A on 7-25-11 - I use once a day - clean per instructions - on 1-5-12 noticed shaver leaving scratches on my face - upon closer inspection found that blades had ate a small hole in foil - this after less than six months usage - called panasonic customer service who told me that the foil was a consumable item and not under warranty and is recommended to be replaced once a year - I asked how much they charge for replacement foil - $60 - I asked her if she thought that was reasonable to expect to spend $60 every 6 months and her response was that she could not help - not an inexpensive shaver to have such short life on foil - shame as I liked the shave I got with it

My face did not have a problem getting use to the shaver since it was most likely use to the previous one. I love the digital display to let me know how much of a charge is left. The charge is lasting me 10-14 days. Cleaning the shaver is easy without needing any special chemicals or container. My issue is with the foil. You are supposed to remove after shaving so as to clean the unit. The foil feels fragile and I have had some difficulty getting it to snap back into place. I do believe that this is a weak spot for the unit and that I may have to replace the foil often (price is about $35 on Amazon). Overall a very good shaver but only time will tell if the foil is durable and if the battery will last.

  363. I am coming from an older high end Panasonic shaver. This one is lighter, cuts faster, charges very fast, and gives an excellent shave. My previous shaver had a charging stand and could be charged while wet. This one is a direct connect, so is not quite as \\"safe\\" but works well and makes the whole package less bulky. I highly recommend this shaver to anyone who wants a fast, close shave. I have been using it dry with no irritation and for the money is a great deal.

  373. This razor gives a decent shave, but I can't say its better than my comparably-priced Norelco. I suppose this doesn't matter if you're using the razor in the shower, but if not this is a major pain in the a$$.<br /><br />UPDATE: Have been living with this razor for close to a year now and felt compelled to update this review. I went from three stars to two because the way it dumps hair everywhere remains abominable and now I have discovered that when the battery is drained it will NOT shave as a corded razor; you have to re-charge it before it will work again. With my cheapo Norelco, if it ran out of juice I could at least plug it in and finish shaving. This one? Better be sure there's enough charge in it to finish your shave, or you'll have half a beard. I wish I could still send it back.
  374. A follow-up to my earlier review: My ES8243A by now is five years old and it is still working as well as it did in July 2011. The problems I find with it: 1. The &#34;replace blades / head&#34; symbol often comes up after about 6 months of use and it is almost impossible to get rid of it. 2. In the neck area, it doesn't work as well as I'd like it to do. I follow up with an age-old, 3-blade Remington that is noisy, but finishes the job. 3. The price of the shaver, including travel pouch and charger cord, in round numbers, is $90. The replacement blades and head combo, after taxes (in New York City 8.875%!) is over $50 - so I am tempted to buy a new shaver the next time the &#34;replace blades/head&#34; symbol comes up. In my experience, the replacement blades do not last as long as the ones in the new unit, so the price difference may be worth it.
