  644. The Panasonic ES8243A Men's 4-Blade (Arc 4) is an excellent electric shaver. I am 50 y/o and have used my share of electric razors and this is by far the finest one yet I have ever seen and i have used many by most all makers. Does it shave as close as a hand held bladed razor like a Mach 3, dont be silly, of course it doesnt. No electric shaver will ever compare to a blade..period! Does it get very close, indeed it does this coming from a man who is bald by choice. I shave my head and most of my face everyday and this shaver does a great job. With an average 7 minute shave time (To do my entire head and face) I get 6 to 7 days out of a charge. It is very easy to clean and charges in an hour. I found it on Amazon for well and I mean well under $100 on sale. For the money and the shave nothing compares to the Panasonic ES8243A Men's 4-Blade (Arc 4) at twice the money. There is nothing here you dont need, a charger and carrying case and the shaver, no bulky unneeded elaborate cleaning system to clutter up your bathroom. I find it to shave equally well both dry and in the shower but I am use to an electric shaver. If I want and extra close shave for that super shiny look afterwards I will quickly go over my head with a Mach 3 but that is in no way an everyday or necassary thing. If I never picked up another blade the ARC 4 ES 8243A does a great job!
  645. Love it. I could not ask for more.<br />At first, it did not worked very well. Because, the hair has to get inside the holes in order for the shaver to cut it, and the best way to get it there is when it is short.<br />I always cut my hair short with the shaver first, then use this panasonic shaver to finish off, I use it dry, I get the best results that way.   647. I used Braun shavers for 15 years before getting this Panasonic wet/dry shaver as a Christmas gift this year. It does shave much closer and cleans up easier than any Braun I've owned. The noise is higher pitched, but managable, especially since it shaves faster. To clean, all you do is squirt a tiny drop of dish soap on the foil, turn it on for a few seconds and rinse. I'm a convert now. Doubt I'll ever buy a Braun again. I also love the digital power meter. The only time I could tell when my Braun got low is when the motor started operating slower. This tells you exactly how much shaving power has been used and is available. Only drawback with the Panasonic is it didn't come with a travel case like my Brauns.
  648. I'm a big believer in \\"crowd-think\\" when it comes to purchasing commodity items like this. So after reviewing Consumer Reports and all the reviews here on Amazon, I decided to go with this one. The first thing I noticed upon opening the box was a piece of paper that said, \\"Please! Give it a chance! Use this razor for 30 days before giving up on it, as it takes your face that long to get accustomed to a new shaving method.\\" Wow. I have been a rotary shaver user for about 15 years, but decided to try foil this time around. So I started using it and was immediately not impressed. Seemed like I had to go over the same areas over and over. And then my wife would notice areas that were still stubbly. But I wanted to give the benefit of the doubt to the 30-day trial, so I waited. Even after the 30 day period (shaving almost daily and exclusively with this), I still don't feel like I got a good shave. So I have returned it and will be ordering a new rotary shaver.<br /><br />Still, many people seem happy with this, so your mileage will vary. It felt great in the hand, the LED information about charging was terrific, and it cleans super easy. But at the end of the day, it's all about how smooth your face feels, and that's where it let me down. I could eventually get a smooth face, but it seemed to take a lot longer and a lot more work.
  649. this razor works really well. close shave. simple to operate and clean. And it doesn't need eight more words either.
  650. I purchased this for my son who is 21 and has a disability. He has a very quick-growing heavy beard and would complain that his previous electric shaver would pinch and pull, making it very uncomfortable to use. He seems to be satisfied with this product and finds it easy to use.
  651. This is the best razor that I have shaved with. I have used Norelco since I was 15, but this razor is closer than the Norelco.

  653. Love this razor. I shave my face, neck and head with it. I let the hair on my head grow out a couple days to see how the razor performs on hair longer than whisker length. It really wouldn't get the job done. However, if you use it every day or every other day it is very impressive
  654. My father loves this razor. It takes him only 2-3 minutes to shave all the broad planes of his face and neck, plus a minute or two more to take care of the details like the nostril creases and close under the lower lip. He loves the simplicity of its function and appreciates the fact that he only needs to pop the foil off and run the blades under the tap to clear them. I can't speak to its longevity yet, seeing as he's only had it three weeks, but once it's proved itself in that area as well I will be happy to recommend it to any man who uses an electric shaver.

Its, definitely a faster motor, never any tugging, as the Braun did a little since day one. This also is cake to clean with a squirt of antibacterial soap and a rinse under the faucet. No more buying those expensive solution cartridges with the Braun. Also, it can be used wet/dry. Once in a while I'll treat my self to a wet shave....extra close and smooth results. Even used primarily dry I get very nice results and much better under chin than the Braun. I have a medium grade stubble.

  675. During the years, I have been using any kind of razor available on the market. Starting from BIC's , shick's to mach'3, no one can get me the closest shave I desire, especially on the neck. Then I decided to go to the classics: double edge razors. I bought a DOVO - Solingen (open comb) - the closest you can get on double edge razor, a pure badger brush and some natural glycerin soap. This was a step up, but still not satisfied. Then I went to the next level: Straight Razor !!! Takes time to learn, but this is the closest you can get!!! But if you don't have 40 minutes to shave, just buy the Panasonic ES8243A - it will get you the same close shave as a straight razor, but in 5-10 minutes. This electric razor shaves wet or dry, the wet can get you closer shave, just buy a good shaving gel like: Cremo Cream or King of Shaves Alphagel Shave Gel. And is very easy to clean. I am still shaving with the straight razor, but only on the weekends, when I have more free time. Straight razor shaving involve buying many additional thinks like 3\\" Black Latigo Razor Strop for sharpening your razor daily and some sharpening stones for deep sharpening - every year.   681. Shavers really are a very personal item, but for me this relatively inexpensive Panasonic has been astonishing. I have that worst of combinations: a heavy black beard with sensitive skin. Plus, the hairs around my mouth and chin seem to grow at every possible angle. Add to that the fact that I insist on a perfectly smooth shave. Result: for years I have used a Mach 3 blade for most of my face, generally with one pass with the grain, followed by a pass against the grain. Then a Track 2 blade to trim my sideburns. But I needed a Norelco to shave around my mouth and chin, which took many passes and, worst of all, ultimately irritated the sides of my mouth down to my jawline. I had stuck with Norelcos for years, after beginning shaving with Remington and Braun foil shavers and finding Norelco to be a great improvement. So I was reluctant to switch, but Norelco quality seems to be going downhill fast. My last few sets of replacement heads felt like cheese graters. So after reading many, many reviews I decided on this Panasonic, which I bought at a reduced price, less than half of a top of the line Norelco. I've used it for 2 months now, and can reliably report on its performance, though not on its longterm durability. I haven't needed to use its wet shave option, though being waterproof does make cleaning extremely simple, quick and effective: a little liquid soap, some running water, shift it into Turbo Mode (which it shifts out of automatically; Turbo Mode is for cleaning, not shaving), and without even taking the cover off, it's squeaky clean and shiny again inside. The shave is as close as the best blade--totally smooth--yet with no cutting or irritation--even shaving dry, and even on the crazy quilt of hairs that surround my mouth. It's just a delight to get a smooth face after only one or at most 2 passes against the grain. And I now have 15 extra minutes every morning: priceless. Plus, the trimmer is excellent, so I no longer need anything extra to use on my sideburns. The LED display is also quite good, especially for the price, though it is not quite as good as the LCD on my old top of the line Norelco, which showed \\"minutes remaining\\" before recharge. This display gives you a percentage of battery charge remaining, and a prompt when it's time to clean, plus a rather useless bar that is supposed to graph remaining charge but is not helpful whatsoever. One other minor complaint, that applies to ALL new shavers, even the most expensive: they all seem to only pack 60 minutes worth of battery charge. The last few Norelcos, going back a decade, gave me 99 solid minutes, which usually meant 105 minutes because they ran for 5-6 minutes after reaching 0 percent. What's going on here? I thought battery technology was making leaps lately! Still, this shaver has literally changed my life. No cuts, no irritation, no need to bring along the Mach 3, the Track 2 and shaving cream when I travel, great, virtually self-cleaning blades, a great trimmer, and best of all, 15 extra minutes every morning when I need them the most. At around $100, any man who shaves and has periodic access to electricity should try it. Do NOT mess around with the models that have the cleaning unit. That is a totally unnecessary waste of money, time, counter space and plastic, especially with a shaver that cleans so well in Turbo Mode with just a little soap and water.
  682. This is the first electric shaver I've had that allows me actually to go into a business day with only an electric shave. Historically, with a series of Braun shavers over 25+ years (up to and including the latest Series 7), I've always had to electric first, then blade-shave to get an acceptable result. While I still do that occasionally, this Panasonic (my first) gives a satisfactory shave by itself. I use it dry for now (have not yet experimented with wet-shaving with it). Only 1 criticism: it's loud. When it's near an ear, it's really piercing! On balance, however, I highly recommend it.

I decided on this after reading the Amazon reviews. Had my first wet shave today and its fantastic. Just as good as blade shave except I dont have a sore tender neck & no need to clean up my towels and sink from my bleeding neck after as I did with wet shave... I have sensetive skin and thick stubble and this worked great just a close as wet shave and charging took only about 1 hr. My best buy on Amazon...
  684. I had been looking for a shavor to replace my old Norelco shaver (which I was not happy with since day one). After reading the positive reviews in the Amazon reviews section I selected the Panasonic ES8242A shavor. I have to say that after using the Panasonic razor I am completely satisified with the results. It gave me closer shave with no irritation. To date no other razor has worked as well for me as the Panasonic. The battery life between charging is only about 5 days but it is certainly worth plugging it in a little more often. If you are looking for a close shave with no irritation I would recommend this razor.
  685. I've had several Panasonic shavers. One, my old ES 882, is still on the job in my travel bag. There have been several different variations on the linear drive motor, some better than others but all decent. The 8243 is about as sharp as it can be with out being abrasive. Shaving times are fast and thorough. The pivoting head along with the curved shape makes it very easy to shave the hard to get to places. It can be locked in place but I find it works much better if left unlocked. I'd like to see a little less plastic and the vinyl case is a bit cheap but adequate. The clear plastic head cover is a good feature. My only complaint, a minor one, is how often you have to charge the battery. It lasts for about 4-5 10 minute shaves before requiring recharging. The battery is a 3 volt single cell Li-on. I've had better results with the old ni cad batteries. There is a replacement but very hard to find. I'd look for a 3 volt ni cad if I could find one. Meantime, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this shaver. Head replacement is easy, clean up after each shave is simple and quick. I also keep a can of Remington Shaver Saver handy to keep the heads sharp and lubed. The other item is noise. The motor is fairly loud. Pros: Close shave, easy to clean. Cons: Loud motor, battery drains quickly. Bottom line: Good shaver overall. One of Panasonic's best efforts.
  686. I am not one to take up writing reviews. However, I make the exception because I feel compelled to write to thank both Amazon, and Panasonic for making this item available to us users. I have used an electric shaver before, but it occasionally resulted in razor burns and in-grown hairs on my face. I stopped using it. I switched to something that I have been using up until now. I normally used Costly, \\"Disposal Razors.\\" These razors usually cost me $15.98 for a package of 8 razors. I try to squeeze approximately 3 shaves out of them, Shaving my head and face Everyday. I found them to be the best, leaving me with no razor burns, bumps, or in-grown hair. Now I ask you to do the math. I have been using these for about 8 years now. Your conclusion, like mine this is quite Costly. I can safely say that my newly found Close Friend, \\"Panasonic ES8243 Arc IV Nana Men's Wet/Dry Rechargeable Shaver\\" will save me lots of Money, it is Superior to any Shaves I have ever had up to my current age of 60. I cannot say enough about this unit. It feels Solid when you handle it, Easy to hold, Great texture in your hand, Very quiet, Very easy to clean and also Easy on the eyes. The most important thing is that it glides on my face, Even during Dry Shaves. I have not tried it wet yet. I simply found no need to go wet yet. Most important Question to ask is: Would I do it again. My answer is Absolutely, Without Hesitation. Best feeling I have had in months when parted with my money. Well Worth every penny. Thanks Amazon, Thanks Panasonic Denzel in Canada
  687. Pros:<br /><br />* Faster than my previous Rotary-head<br />* Handles older growth without pre-trimming<br />* Easy to clean<br />* Joy to use.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />* Not quite as close as a lift-and-cut rotary, rough stubble may reappear mid-day for me. Evenings out may require a second touch-up shave.<br />* Under the nose and the neck-line seem to require adjusting technique to ensure you don't \\"miss\\".<br />* Not so much a con, just an adjustment in behavior - the shaver won't operate if plugged in. Must be operated cordless.<br /><br />Extended Thoughts:<br /><br />I figured I'd take a chance at a different style razor when this device showed up in a Gold Box deal for a steal of a price. I'm glad I did.<br /><br />Consider me a bit lazy, but I don't enjoy shaving daily. That said, I could with this razor because it's fast and easy to use. On those occasions when I feel like skipping a day or three, this razor handles my thick, semi-coarse, quickly-growing beard with ease. On days that I don't skip, the shave is quick and reasonably thorough.<br /><br />My previous rotary bladed Norelco would skip most of the hairs after an extended \\"razor vacation\\", requiring me to pre-shave with the trimmer before shaving with the rotary head, taking 10-15 minutes. This Panasonic doesn't require a pre-shave in most cases and rather attacks longer hairs with ease. I may still find the occasional stray missed hair, but those could be counted on one hand. Shaving longer hairs doesn't come with any pulling, though occasionally if I move too quickly, the head may briefly \\"stall\\" (changes tone). At this point, that is never associated with any pulling though.<br /><br />Cleaning is simple - when the indicator lights up, simply apply liquid soap and activate the 20 seconds of turbo-cleaning speed. Rinse under water, remove the blade cover, and repeat the soap and turbo-mode treatment, followed by another rinse. Blot dry with a towel and reassemble. That's it!<br /><br />Like some other reviewers remarked, because this isn't lift-and-cut, the shave isn't quite as close or as long-lasting as that which I used to get with the Norelco. Because I can achieve a clean shave after a few days in ~5 minutes vs. 10+ w/ the previous device, I'll take the trade-off any day.<br /><br />Another point that required me to re-adjust my behavior - the placement of the foils makes getting the spot under my nose just a bit harder. I find I miss some of those spots and have to revisit them 10-15 min later (say, after my shower). The neck area continues to be a challenge with this razor as with any other electric because of the parallel-to-the-skin angle the hairs tend to grow toward.<br /><br />All in all, very happy with the purchase.e or as long-lasting as that which I used to get with the Norelco. Because I can achieve a clean shave after a few days in ~5 minutes vs. 10+ w/ the previous device, I'll take the trade-off any day. Another point that required me to re-adjust my behavior - the placement of the foils makes getting the spot under my nose just a bit harder. I find I miss some of those spots and have to revisit them 10-15 min later (say, after my shower). The neck area continues to be a challenge with this razor as with any other electric because of the parallel-to-the-skin angle the hairs tend to grow toward. All in all, very happy with the purchase.

It's never been dropped or submerged, only used at my sink. I would have expected no problems with charging for at least a few years but I guess nothing is built to last anymore. I'm lowering my rating from 5 to 3 stars; 3 only because it was great when it worked.<br /><br />Original Review:<br />I purchased this shaver as a replacement for a low end Panasonic ES3041K that was cheaply constructed and hurt me when I shaved. The ES8243A is light years better and well worth the price I paid for it. The construction looks and feels high quality. It cuts through my tough beard effortlessly and leaves smooth skin. It charges quickly and I really like the digital display that shows how much battery is left. I clean it by running a little soft soap for about 5 seconds then rinsing and that works great. The only negative I found is that I tried to use it when it showed only 10% power, my mistake because as it ran down the battery it felt like it jammed on my chin, ripping off a piece of skin leaving me bleeding so I just won't run it at that low a charge anymore.   693. For the last 6 years I've been using a Philips (Norleco) rotary head and changing the blades each time the display advised. It was fine for a few months after but didn't really feel like a close shave after that. I thought I'd try the foil type and I'm glad I did - this is a really good product.   694. Been shaving over 50 years, have thick stubby beard. Wore out my last shaver and wanted to try a wet dry shaver. Looked at many reviews and decided that this looked most promising and Amazon had the best deal. I think the only way to get a better shave is to use a razor, but this is faster and more convenient. Panasonic did a great job on this one, and I saved some money on this model since I like to clean my razor after each use manually. The following routine works for me. BTW, My beard didn't need any adjustment period - hope you find the following helpful. Fully charge the shaver before first using it - a full charge lasts for several shaves. Spread a little shaving lather on the shaver head and shave about 1/3 of your face before the lather dries - then repeat two more times over the rest of your face. The lather lets the shaver glide smoothly over the face without excess effort and you're done in less two minutes. To extend life of shaver, after shaving, let COLD water run over shaver head while it is on for about 5 seconds then turn it off and take the cover off. Turn shaver back on and rince cover and shaver head then turn it off. Blow water out of the blade area and let the shaver & cover lay on a papertowel for a few minutes, then put the cover back on and put the shaver away. Unfortunately Panasonic doesn't include a stand for vertical shaver storage. I converted another brands shaver stand by removing its charging connectors and put a folded papertowel in the bottom. When the shaver is put away, it is mostly dry and sits pointed downward so any remaining moisture will be absorbed. Aside from occasionally charging the shaver, it works like new every time. I've used electric shavers with triangular, rectangular, large & small heads ... this is by far the most quiet, ergonomic efficient and comfortable shaver I've ever used. Highly recommended. :-)
  695. I am retired and do some traveling with my family. I also work part time as an over the road truck driver. The razor fits my needs.

  702. The razor works great and has all the features described. Great battery life, I haven't had to recharge yet and I have had almost a month. I am very happy with the purchase
  703. It is clearly better than the other ones my husbund had been used, but he is still hoping if it could be even closer to a classic manual shaver.
  704. I've never writen a review before but felt compelled to do so. I've had this Panasonic razor for two weeks and<br />Am amazed by how close a shave it provides. Billy jealous hydroplane shave gel plus this razor gives me the closest shave I've ever gotten in about 3 minutes time.
  705. This shaver provides an \\"okay\\" shave. Believe it or not, the shave is not nearly as close as the one I get from the little battery-powered travel shaver made by another manufacturer that fits in my Dopp kit. The shaver needs re-charging about every 3-4 days, which is more frequently than the last shaver I owned made by another manufacturer. That's not really a significant problem for me, but I usually need only about 3 minutes to shave each morning, so if you have a really heavy beard and expect to spend more time on each shave, then you might want to consider that factor.<br /><br />On the plus side, the shaver does seem to re-charge fully quite quickly-- I think in about 30 minutes. The travel case is small and soft and does not accommodate the cord. Twice when I got the shaver out of my luggage at the end of a trip the shaver had no charge. I suspect that was because the \\"on\\" button accidentally got pushed through the soft side case when the shaver was inside the luggage. I wonder how a running shaver inside a suitcase gets treated by TSA. Anyway, it recharges quite quickly, as noted.<br /><br />So in summary, it's an okay shaver, but I think it would be worth taking a serious look at another model or brand if any of these issues are of concern to you. And if you take your shaver when you travel, I recommend that you consider a shaver what comes with a hard case that also accommodates the cord. It is nice to have the two packed together. Sometimes I have forgotten to pack the cord, which makes the shaver useless during the trip after the battery runs down. And sometimes I find myself spending quite a bit of time fishing through my packed luggage trying to find the cord. So I think a shaver with a hard case that accommodates the cord is a good idea. That said, I suspect that for $15 to $20 you can probably buy a small hard-side camera case that would work to hold both the shaver and the cord, but of course you should factor that in the price you'll be paying. Alternatively, if you are considering a shaver with a soft-side case and you plan to use it for travel, then you might also want to consider whether the shaver is designed so that the \\"on\\" button cannot be pushed accidentally through the soft side case.g. Alternatively, if you are considering a shaver with a soft-side case and you plan to use it for travel, then you might also want to consider whether the shaver is designed so that the \\"on\\" button cannot be pushed accidentally through the soft side case.
  706. The noise level & the weight are much less than my former shaver, a Remington.<br /><br />They expect me to clean the shaver under running water but I clean my shaver daily & I find it easier to clean it with a cleaning brush. It's a shame that I have to use an old cleaning brush since they didn't include one. That's why I gave the shaver a 4-star rating.<br /><br />Bottom line: I'm satisfied & recommend it.

  709. I bought this for my husband as a gift. He had never used one with these type of blades, so I was unsure but the reviews were very convincing. The first couple shaves it didn't get as close as he was hoping, but by the time he shaved 3-4 times, he says it's just as close as using a straight razor. It isn't painful and it's incredibly close. The only complaint is that the hair can't be past a certain length or it does not pick it up. If he waits too long to shave, he has to go over it with the trimmer that is included on the razor first. Clean up is very easy, you just hold under running water. We did not purchase the self cleaning station, as other reviewers said it wasn't worth it. They were correct as running water works perfectly.
  710. The shaver produces an very nice shave and does not irritate my skin. There are three shortcomings that are worth noting. The first is that the shaver will not run while charging. You need to estimate before starting a shave if you have enough charge to make it to the end. The second is that the configuration on the head of the shaver makes it difficult to shave close to nostrils since the razor head is curved for a better overall experience. I may have noticed this more because I moved from a basic Norelco where this was not a problem. The third is that she shaver is surprisingly loud, so much so that its annoying to have it near my ear. My son had the<br />Panasonic ES8103S which is noticeably quieter and produced a very similar result<br /><br />If you see a version of this shaver that allows shaving while charging, I suggest going for that model instead.

The shave took half the time and was so close that you could not feel any stubble/whiskers. I am 44 and have had only norelco and remington shavers before this.I did alot of research before purchasing this shaver, I chose this one over the 5 blade model just above this one only because this one looked a little less bulky and i was worried about shaving next to my gotee. it does a very good job and i love the wet feature mostly since it is so easy to clean. i seem to get a better shave dry with some baby powder. it mows thru 2-3 days growth much better than any shaver ive ever had. as far as a \\"one pass\\" closeness for me there is no such thing since i have wiskers that grow straight down and so close and tight against my skin, even with this shaver i have to streach the skin and make many passes but i do not get razzer burn with this shaver and it does do a better quicker job than any others i've tried.

  718. I just received my ES8243A and after the first shave, have to say I'm totally impressed. I have a heavy beard and have been shaving with a Braun for about 5 years. I was getting tired of spending 10 minutes every morning going over and over my face to get a close shave (only to be asked \\"Did you shave today?\\") so I decided it was time to take the plunge and get a new shaver. After researching different options, I settled on the ES8243A. I decided against the much more expensive Black Vortex model after discovering that you can just as easily, with a few drops of liquid soap, clean the ES8243A and avoid having to buy the $5 monthly soap cartridges that the Vortex requires. That appears to be the only difference between the two models - the Black one has the Vortex cleaner/charger and the Blue one just has an AC adapter and you clean it with soap and water. After charging the shaver (only takes 1 hour) I gave it a try and am totally impressed with how fast and close this shaver works. Compared to my older Braun, it's a totally different shaving experience. This Panasonic shaver is quieter, lighter and all around a great shaver. I'm looking forward to trying it out in the shower (something you can't do with a Braun).
  719. I am a bit surprised by the high rating that this product has so far. Maybe I am just not used to this shaver yet. It would be interesting to find out what type of beard every reviewer has. Bottom line is that, while it performs well, it cannot cut the hair from neck-chin junction point. If you don't grow any hair there it will do. I have to go over that are a few times, and still need a blade to cut the hair that it leaves behind. This obviously causes discomfort and irritation. Another thing is that it is quite noisy. Apart from the points above the quality of the shave is good.

  722. I'm just amazed at how quick and easy shaving is with this model. I've been avioding foil shavers for years because one that I bought long ago didn't cut the longer hairs. The rotary norelcos always did a nice job of cutting the longer hairs, but never shaved as smooth as a foil. I was never good with a razor. Always getting little nics and cuts, and, quite frankly, too much of a hassle for me. This model gets the long hairs, and shaves every bit as close as a razor blade, all in under 2 minutes. It works equally well wet or dry. I honestly don't know how it can shave so close without a hint of razor burn, but it does. Truly a wonder of modern technology! Before this one arrived, I had thought about getting my broken Norelco fixed, but after shaving one time with the Panasonic, I'll never go back to a rotary again. I don't know, maybe it's me, but after a year, I started having the same problems with this one as I did with the Norelco. This unit no longer works. It turns on and off randomly. I originally purchased a cheaper model, because I couldn't justify spending so much on a shaver if it's only going to last a year, however, the amount of time this model saves me shaving, I think it's justified, so I've ordered a similar model and just hope it last longer this time.

  724. I have used blades all of my shaving life (45 years) with a few intervals using an electric shaver.   725. I've used quite a few different safety razors (1, 2, 3 & 4 blades), 2 or 3 Remingtons and I've also had one Braun. All of the safety razors caused a lot of irritation on my neck. The Remingtons & Braun shaved very well when new, but after a month or so they all seemed to dull and give only a fair shave. This Panasonic, from day one gave a great shave, and after well over a month, the shave has not changed! I've tried using the shaver dry, but didn't care for it that much. I wash my face & neck in hot water, rinse the soap off, and put on a thin coat of shaving cream (I heat up the shaving cream for a better feel, not a better shave). On the neck I have to move the shaver in all directions, since my beard seems to grow that way. It takes me around 5 minutes or so to finish, rinsing the shaving heads now & then to keep the shaving cream from piling up on the them. When finished, my face is smooth; the shave is close, and there is absolutely no irritation. Is the shave as close as a blade? I'm not sure, but my face & neck sure feel a lot better then they do after using a blade. Would I buy this razor again? Without question! Do I recommend it? Let's just say that it's far better than anything else I've ever shaved with.
  726. I have used Panasonic electric razors for several years. From time to time I have tried other brands, including top of the line Braun models, but I always came back to Panasonic as the best overall for me at least. I was pretty satisfied with my current Panasonic, a triple blade Arc nano unit (8109). However, I saw some unusually good reviews for this new Arc IV model that led me to try it. I have to agree with the reviews I saw. This model is clearly the best Panasonic has ever made, and better than any other brand that I have tried. I don't know if it is the wider head, something about the extra blade in the center, or some other design change--but this model gives a closer shave with fewer strokes. I noticed the difference the first time I used it. It is easy to clean under the faucet (no need for those cleaning bath units), and it has a nice display on the razor that shows not only battery time remaining but also elapsed time and other indicators. Just FYI, this razor has two conventional blades that are mounted separately under the cover and replaced separately. The other two blades are built into the cover. One of those appears similar to the one on triple blade models intended to cut longer hairs. The other appears more conventional from the outside, but is still integrated in the cover. I am not sure why this was done, but it seems to work.

  730. For a bald guy that shaves every day this is by far the best razor I have used yet. I used a TCT 3 for 8 years and only replaced it because it was dropped and not worth repairing. I THOUGHT I had the best razor because it never let me down. I searched for the best replacement and this was by far the best reviewed for the money. I now know why. This razor takes a minute or 2 longer than usual when you first use it. But after a few weeks it averages out. There is definetly a break in time for the razor and your skin. It's almost like the shave trains the hair the correct way to be shaved and you don't realize this until you have used it for a couple of weeks. The result is a shave as close to a blade but much more comfortable and alot less irritating. I never realize there was something out there this good. The timer on it lets me know it takes me 13 minutes a day to shave face and head. That means I spend 4745 minutes a year shaving. That's 3.3 days of continous shaving a year!! Why wouldn't you invest in a razor like this if you where spending that much time? The only thing I can say about this razor is it advertises as one pass shaving. While it does a good job on the first pass you definetly need to cover an area more than once. Frankly what razor out there cuts on one pass only? Maybe a straight razor but who uses those anymore? By far this is well worth the money. If you are reading these reviews you obviosly take shaving seriously. You owe it to yourself then not to think twice about purchasing it. You will not be disappointed. I will be sure this razor is never dropped. Make sure you keep it plugged in. A 13 minute shaves brings a full charge to 80%. That means I get 3 good shaves before the productivity decreases. So bring the charger when you travel.

  741. I've had this shaver for a week and love it. The trimmer is the only thing that holds me back from \\"five-starring\\" it. What I like: If you have four high-quality blades, they're going to shave faster and better than the one. And they do! This shaver gives me an incredibly close shave, no overdryness or irritation to my skin, and it's fast. I can't get my shaving time down to 2 1/2 minutes like what I see from a lot of reviews (more like 3 1/2 - and I don't have a thick beard or anything really challenging), but there's so much surface area to the head that the shave does go faster than what I'm used to. What I don't like: The biggest issue is the trimmer. My last shaver, a low-end Braun, had a great trimmer that went through anything like a lawn mower, but with more finesse. This doesn't. I've kind of adapted so it does kind of okay on my sideburns, but other things I took for granted with the old Braun, like eyebrows, the back of my neck, even my own hair on my head sometimes, are way more than this wimpy trimmer can handle. Distant second concern is battery life. Squeezing a week of shaves out of this is a challenge, although it recharges fully in an hour, and there's a display to show remaining battery life. Final concern is that the large shaving area - a plus for speed - makes it difficult to get to small or tight places, which everyone's face has here or there. I had often thought that the extra money spent for a razor costing more than $40 was for useless bells and whistles. I was wrong, and this product is great proof of that!

  749. I've tried the top of the line Braun, Remington, and Norelco shavers. I've used both foil and rotaries. Nothing I've ever used holds a candle to this Panasonic. It was one of the best electric shavers I've ever had, and my son eventually boosted it from me when he moved out on his own. Why I didn't just stick with the Panasonic back then I'll never know. Probably because, who associates Panasonic with electric shavers? You never see them at Christmas time making cute commercials with baby polar bears and penguins sliding down snow-covered hills like Norelco, right? Anyway, I read a lot of positive reviews on this shaver, so I took a gamble and ordered it. I'm ecstatic I did.<br /><br />It still requires me to cover an area a couple of times, but then any electric shaver is going to. It does require far fewer passes than any other shaver I've ever used, so I guess it's the least of all evils. I haven't actually timed it, but my perception is that it does not hold a full charge quite as long as some other shavers I've used. I think most guys will get at least a full week out of a charge, and if you have a relatively light beard as I do, you'll probably get 2 weeks, possibly a day or two more.<br /><br />All in all, if I was in the market today for a new shaver, I'd go right out and get another of these Panasonics.

  752. IN SHORT: DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT even bother using this electric razor WITHOUT [[ASIN:B004GKAKK0 Mennen Afta Pre-electric Shave Lotion with Skin Conditioners, Original, 3-ounces (Pack of 6)]]. If not this one, then some other pre-electric lotion, but that is the only one I've tried so far. I actually purchased it from Wal-mart because it came out cheaper, even with the cost of shipping. It will probably vary upon your location. Wherever you buy it, match the picture with the product you want, as the title of the product wasn't as accurate as I would've liked it to have been. REVIEW I bought this product almost a year ago. I don't shave everyday, just when I have to go to work. I get lazy on weekends. Now, I'm not a skinny guy, but I'm not huge. My face is fat, so I have to stretch my skin with my other hand to get a closer shave. I've had to use my old razor to finish up on my neck and the corners of my mouth, as this electric razor didn't get the job finished. Well, that changed this morning... Earlier last week, I was reading reviews on this product. One customer mentioned Afta Pre-Electric shave. I figured I didn't have much to lose, considering I'd spent $90 (at the time) on this razor, already, and I wasn't quite due for new blades, yet. So, I ordered this stuff. My complaint is that it comes in such a small quantity. I would've liked a bigger bottle. Anyway... Just wow, my neck actually was shaved correctly. Well, OK, my old razor STILL did a slightly better job, but still, the conventional method of shaving takes a bit longer. I'm all about conserving time. Here's what I did: 1. Showered 2. Got Partially Dressed 3. Applied AFTA (Note my face had a few minutes to dry after shower) 4. Shaved I don't think there's any need to wipe the AFTA off your face, afterward. While I was reading the reviews on this product again, last week, I discovered that there is a cleaning mode. That's what I get for not reading manuals. To activate thecleaning mode, hold the button in for 2 seconds. This activates \\"Turbo Mode\\". The manual says to NOT shave in Turbo mode. I think it only stays in turbo mode for 20, maybe 30 seconds from what I read. That's more than enough time to run the razor under water. Because of the addition of AFTA Pre-electric shave, I have updated my rating of this product from 4 stars to 5 stars.
  753. Look no more, as your face will become hair-free WITHOUT the irritation. This electric shaver by Panasonic has truly changed my life.<br /><br />My first shaves, for years, were with a blade. However, my skin would always end up irritated -- especially at the neck area. Plus the ingrown hairs would always be present and had to be plucked away. Later on, I read that an electric shaver would minimize both the irritation and ingrown hairs.<br /><br />My very first purchase for an electric shaver was a Norelco; one of their mid-priced models. It did deliver its purpose, by minimizing both irritation and ingrown hairs, but in order to achieve a close shave (which was not that close, actually) it took 15 to 20 minutes! Other than the fact that it could not be used in the shower.<br /><br />But alas, I researched reviews from both professionals and customers, and found that this Panasonic electric shaver does its purpose, and beyond. It will deliver a blade-like shave in 5 minutes or less -- NO JOKE nor exaggerations. I could not believe how my neck area ended up smooth and irritation free. That itself is amazing. Plus you get the versatility of using it both inside or outside of the shower!<br /><br />This review comes literally one year after purchase. And I can assure you, I am one truly happy customer. Great shave and great skin at an awesome price. Who can beat that formula?
  754. This shaver is totally worth it. My husband has thick rough facial hair that grows quickly. Shaving everyday with razors leaves his face irritated. This electric one shaves it so close I am still not always able to tell the difference. It is quiet and holds it's charge longer then the last one we had. I definitely reccomend it.
  755. I combined this with the art of shavings shaving cream and found the following steps to work best: 1) Take your badger brush or hand and grab a small amount of shaving cream. Work it over your face covering the areas that need shaving. 2) Make sure when you apply the shaving cream it's not too thick of a lather 3) Take your shaver and run it under hot water while it's on. 4) After running the shaver under hot water apply it to your lathered up face. 5) Go down in straight lines and then rinse the shaver under water to get the shaving cream and hair out. Go over the area of your face you just shaved one more time and work from opposite direction up. Will get a a thin lather to form as the shaver foams up the shaving cream and a really close shave 6) Repeat for remainder of face
  756. Don't ususally write reviews, but I must admit, this is the best razor I have tried. I use it alot and seem to overshave, but it does not tear my face, which is sensitive, and I do get a really good shave. I would recommend it to anyone. I do like the fact I can clean it under the faucet, and the recharge is amazingly fast. Hope you enjoy yours too!
  757. Works well, especially inn the shower - although it is difficult to dry afterwards. Not sure how robust the blade foil will be with all the cleaning and drying.

  771. Now have 2 years shaving experience with the ES8243. Having used the highest end Braun product just prior, and Remington, this is the best electric shaver I've tried. It provides a closer shave, is robust and easy to use, easy to clean (dry or wet), and provides a charge message (high end products do this now). The charge lasts 9-12 days. For Braun users ... High end Braun products are good but in my experience the mechanical parts tend to fail from use over time (on/off switch on 2 of them because of the extension for trimming ... presume they've fixed this). The last one was a 7000 series with the proprietary cleaner system (you don't need this; I stopped using it because experiments showed it wasn't doing anything). The Braun 7XXX provided a good shave; the Panasonic provides superb shaves. Full disclosure: None of these products shave as close as a good multi-blade razor but without being careful I tend to cut myself seeking a closer shave against the hairs. I jettisoned the Remington with Ti blade. It abraded my face and I don't recommend it. If you are a Braun fan, you can't go wrong with the top model but you are missing out on a better product with the Panasonic, at a lower relative price. Hate to say this because I tend to own a lot of PG stock from time to time. Improvement: The sideburn / long hair trimmer is adequate but could be improved. This is true on Braun models as well. February 2013 Update. Worth noting that I am still using the original foil and cutter which provide a satisfactory shave. I purchased replacement parts but being frugal have not come to the decision to use. The current shave is noticeably not as good as the first shaves, but it is adequate. Offering this message for those of you concerned with the cost of replacement parts. I don't use the shaver wet, tap to remove cuttings every day, brush cutter every 1-2 weeks, recharge about every 8-10 days. This is a very low maintenance appliance. April 15, 2013 Update.Decided to treat myself to new blades and foil but keeping the old ones in case of need. They still work fine. September 2016. New blades. Shaver still working very well. Only disadvantage is blades and new shaving head/screen expensive.
  772. I have had several electric razors (Braun, Norelco and Panasonic) and this is by far the best ever. I've stuck to Panasonic for their Wet/Dry feature because of my dense beard. This shaver is so good I rarely have to use it wet. The result is a quick smooth shave. It has a locking feature which firms the head or unlocked which helps the head/beard interface conture better. Nice display and charge time. Cons are no stands like the past razors and the travel case is cheap looking. Would definitely recommend.
  773. I've had this shaver for about a week and am mostly impressed with it. I have used it dry exclusively. I have previously used Norelco rotary shavers and find the Panasonic to shave closer but only marginally faster. I've experienced very little irritation. Like many shavers, Panasonic claimes this one offers \\"remarkable shaving on the first pass\\". That is, of course, a fantasy on their part but this is still a good shaver. I'm not exactly sure what \\"remarkable\\" means, but I find it still takes several passes on areas such as my neck which are difficult to shave. All in all, this is a good shaver for the price but not the holy grail of shaving.

Used to be a big fan of Braun's shavers, but get irritated by their push of models coming with pricey washing solution cartridges. I was impressed with features of this Panasonic shaver and decided to give it a try. I ended up a very happy user. This is probably the best shaver I've ever had. Here is my take for this shaver: Pros: 1. A terrific wet/dry shaver which allows you to shave in the shower or with shaving cream. 2. It comes with a \\"sonic washing mode\\" which allows you to wash it right under the tap water. The shaver even let you know when it needs cleaning. 3. Fast recharge speed. Ready in minutes. 4.   778. After my old Norelco Cool Skin died, I was in the market for a new shaver. I really don't like a dry shave, so I definitely wanted to go waterproof again. I wasn't ever totally happy with my Norelco. It did a great job on my face, but I couldn't ever use it on my neck without severe razor burn. Consequently, I was left having to shave my neck with a blade. I've read rave reviews about how great this Panasonic is, but the high price of it scared me. Still, I figured, if it works on my neck and I don't have to buy Fusion blades anymore, it might very well be worth it, so I took the plunge and bought it. And I am I glad I did. This is the best shave I've ever had with an electric. It works as advertised. It is fast ( takes me about three minutes to shave with this ), comfortable and very close. I haven't had any abrasion or razor burn. And best of all, it works great on the neck, not only on the face like some other shavers. I have only two minor complaints about this shaver. First, I wish it had a wrist strap for use in the shower to help keep you from accidentally dropping it like the Cool Skin does. Second, is the charger. It is simply a cheap-ish charging cord. A high-end razor like this should really give you a nice inductive charging stand for the amount of money you are spending. Other than those two minor quibbles, this is probably the finest electric shaver on the market right now. Worth every penny. PROS- - Fast shaves. You're done in 2-3 minutes. - Comfortable - no abrasions, nicks, or razor burn - Easy to clean - no expensive cleaning solution cartridges - Great shave. Almost as close as a blade, especially wet. CONS- - Somewhat pricey - No wrist strap for the shower - Cheap charger

  801. I have been using this shaver for about 2 months now. I have used Panasonic, Braun, and Remington shavers in the past. I also bought the model without the cleaning machine. I prefer to rinse it off with water after each use and then do a high speed cleaning with soap and water about once a week. The ongoing cost of the cleaning cartridges, etc. I find prohibitive. This is a great shaver - it is light, fits well in my hand, the charge lasts more than a week for me, and it gives a really comfortable and close shave.
  802. I saw the shaver ad on TV and decided to get it after reading some of the reviews online. After using it,I am honestly very surprised by the high rating that this product has so far. The shaver cannot cut the hair from neck-chin junction point. If you don't grow any hair there it will do.   803. To put this review in perspective, my previous shaver that I owned for over 5 years was a Norelco 6885XL Quadra Shaver. My Norelco gave excellent shaves but the battery was dying and the head shell and blades needed replacement. So after reading all the stellar reviews on the Panasonic ES8243K, I decided to give it a whirl. [My shaver is identical to the ES8243A but in black. It was originally offered without the HydraClean system, which I think is unnecessary.] When it arrived in the mail, I was happy to see Panasonic is using eco-friendly all cardboard packaging. Both my old Norelco and the Panasonic are very ergonomic. I decided to use the ES8243K dry for the first couple week to be able to compare apples to apples. The Norelco gave me a close shave but the Panasonic was even closer and more consistent over all parts of the face and neck. And each day during the first three days of use, it seemed to shave a little closer. I didn't find it to be any quieter than the Norelco, just a different sound. The Norelco left my face just mildly irritated but the Panasonic was considerably more irritating for the first three days. After my skin adjusted to the change, I found it to be less irritating than the Norelco. I have a thick beard but sensitive combination (normal/oily) skin. The second week I tried using shaving cream. This is the first time I've used shaving cream with an electric razor. It seems to shave slightly closer than when I shaved dry. But the main benefit is no irritation at all after shaving. No need to use an after-shave anymore--just a good organic moisturizer. What works best for my skin and beard is to first shower, then wash my face with a good quality organic facial wash or exfoliant. Then I pour hot water into my shaving scuttle I bought from Dirty Bird Pottery. Next, I create a lather with Classic Shaving Cream (unscented) and a Rooney best quality badger brush. These products are relatively expensive when compared to drug store brands, but they last quite a while because I have to use only a small amount each time. Plus they're hypoallergenic, the shave is very close, and my face doesn't feel irritated afterwards. The shaving head has a locked and unlocked position. I really don't notice a difference in the shave. I just leave it unlocked and the head flexes slightly. I like to shave once, not going over the same area a lot. Then I re-lather and go over my face and neck a second time. Now the trick to a really close shave is to shave the neck and chin in a direction 90º from how you shaved before re-lathering. After shaving, I rinse with warm, then cold water to close the pores. And I apply an organic moisturizer. The last step is very important to protect the skin and I have no idea why a lot of men don't use a moisturizer. Cleaning is easy and just takes a little over a minute. Apologies, I can't compare the shave to a safety razor since I don't use one. I doubt that it's quite as close as a Feather single edge double-blade but there's always trade-offs. I paid $200 because I bought it when it first came out--no complaints. It's a bargain at it's current price. Cons: There is no stand for the razor so that it can rest vertically and take up less shelf space. It would also look nicer on the shelf. Panasonic should design and offer a stand with a clip or something to hold the outer foil shell while it's drying after cleaning. The other problem is that the lighted read-out for minutes shaved and percentage of charge left should be brighter to be able to read it in a brightly lit room. It's a little hard to read because my bathroom has a skylight.
  804. This razor replaces a Braun that I had for years, and really liked . After searching on line, I liked the sound of this Panasonic. Received it in short order and the first shave was terrific, easy, smooth and felt good. I'm a little hesitant to rinse it under water, but I will attempt that soon...I have no problem cleaning it dry. Another thing, no more prolonged blood thinner bleeding from nicks.<br />Great product!!

  809. I give it 4 stars for performance and 2 stars for reliability.<br /><br />I bought this Panasonic ES8243 shaver in April of 2011. At first, it worked great! Provided a close shave, closer than my Braun, and functioned wet or dry. (You call really use it in the shower!) However, about 3 months into use the LED panel on the front started to malfunction. First some of the numbers were slightly unreadable when the battery power was low. Fully charge it was fine. Then it was unreadable all the time (all numbers read as \\"888\\") and all warning signals (time to clean, change foil, low battery) were on all the time. It still functioned well, i just couldn't tell when to charge it or clean it.<br /><br />I called Panasonic and they told me there was no \\"reset\\" code for \\"fix\\" it. So they instructed me to send it back to the Panasonic factory in TX(2 year warranty). Had to use my old shaver for 2 weeks. Got the Panasonic back two weeks later (factory refurbished and without the nice accessories) and it worked well for 1-2 months and then THE SAME PROBLEMS RECURRED. The LED display went haywire and was unreadable.<br /><br />I guess I'll just keep sending it back whenever the LED goes bad and that way i won't have to buy new shaver blades and foils!

  814. I really love this shaver; it has served me well and I continue to enjoy it after almost 2 years. It is powerful and delivers a close comfortable shave. It is wet capable for those so inclined however I only shave dry and it performs well even with no shave gel or moisturizer. With a shave gel it gives results similar to a blade. The only two negatives are relatively low battery capacity ( I get only 3-4 shaves out of a charge) and the shaver does throw out stubble when used dry. Even so, I highly recommend and give 5 stars.
  815. I've never been able to use an electric razor before. My skin is too sensitive. However I decided to buy this one to see how it would work out since the reviews were good. I was not disappointed.
  816. best purchase i ever made i hate shaving this makes a fast job of it<br />it would have been nice to have a charging stand but i still wouldnt trade<br />it for another
  817. I loved it immediately upon first use, and it provides the closest and easiest shave of any electric that I've used.
  818. so far no problems at all, purchesed about year ago, it really works well and have no complains.<br />love it
  819. this razor works well. on the whole i am happy with it. but it will not work while plugged in. that said, you can charge it enough for a single use in just a few minutes so that is probably not a big deal. also, it stays charged for a long time so you don't need to plug it in every day. it works much better for me on a dry face. however, i have never used any other wet/dry shaver, so i maybe wet shaving is just more difficult in general. there are a few spots on my face that i have to go over a bunch of times to get them smooth, but that was true with my last shaver too. i did find this shaver did a good job with 5-day scruff where other foil razors fall down. i think because of the trimmer blade down the center i don't need to use a trimmer first. even with the trimmer blade, it has never nicked me, and i am really cavalier with it.
  820. Excellent initial performance
  821. After flopping back and forth between my old electric shaver and a conventional blade, I bought this shaver based on others reviews. And they were right.<br /><br />If you want an electric shaver that rivals a blade's performance, this is a good one to choose. Each morning I'm still impressed with the closeness of the shave, as it leaves very smooth skin without stubbles and no hair left behind. This is my experience with dry shaving, never tried using it with shaving foam (although it can be used as a wet shaver).<br /><br />Amazon featured this shaver one day as their gold box deal of the day and I bought it using that deal. Not sure if the 'normal' pricing is considered expensive for a 4 blade shaver but it's worth the price if you want effortless, close-as-a-blade shave without the chance of knicking your skin on occasion.

  823. I haven't used an electric razor in years because I never knew one that could shave as close as a blade. I finally found what I was looking for with this Panasonic. Shaving is easy, fast and there is no irritation to my skin. I like a close shave, and to obtain that with a blade, I would often suffer small cuts, especially if the blade was a few days old. Not so with this Panasonic, which effortlessly glides over my skin and produces a close shave, whether I shave wet or dry. I have only used this for a week, so I can't speak to this product's reliability. My beard is average in thickness and growth, so I also can't gauge how this razor would work on someone with a different thickness of beard. I also have not used the trimmer. But I am extremely pleased with the shave I get and the way it leaves me feeling smooth and pain free following my daily shave.

Shortly after that, it would sometimes fail to come on when fully charged. I paid over $100 and should be able to expect more than a year and a half out of this product. I emailed Panasonic about this and received no reply. I can only assume that they don't stand behind their product.

Pros: Much lighter than the older inductively charged shavers. 4 blade foil cuts more and easier. Holds its charge for many days. Charges before I leave for work. Under $100.   893. I have used mid-priced Braun razors for 25 years. I never had a great shave, but could not see myself spending two hundred plus dollars for the top of the line Braun.   894. The razor is nice, holds good charge, and has a nice LCD display to show discharge and run time on each shave. I have been using high quality blades for a long time. Those blades lasted me at least a month each. yep, they are sharp, and very durable. I wanted to try an electric, and iI don't think any electric can do what a good blade can do for a clean shave that feels clean as well as looks clean. The two biggest complaints I have read about this shaver as both true. The first is technology based, and I trusted it was true even before I got it. LCD's do not do well in heat, so being a wet and dry shaver presents a problem for guys who like hot showers. The heat from the hot shower destroys the LCD display. It does not hurt the razor in any other way. the newest model of this is said to have gone back to LED displays. LEDs do well in hot environments, but they are limited in what information that can give you. This razor is very nice as far as the display goes, and charge time versus usable time. The other complaint was that they do not supply a stand to allow the razor to be taken from the shower, or after rinsing in the sink and let it stand up to dry. Some wanted a ultraviolet disinfectant lit holder, but that would drive the cost up, and I could do without it. Just keep the razor clean. I sometimes use the razor when I want a closer shave, but I use the electric first. It does come with a travel zippered pouch.
  895. I've bought five assorted models of Panasonic wet/dry shavers over the years, and they all have given me good shower shaves. Why five? The first lasted 4 years; the second three; and you get the picture. The latest, this model, lasted only a year before the digital display went wacky, wacky to the point of being useless. After two years, I had a similar problem with its predecessor. In a headline: the quality of Panasonic wet/dry shavers has reduced to the point that they are now great throwaway razors.

This razor gives me the closest non-blade shave I've ever gotten and I've been shaving my whole head for more than ten years now and my face for about 25 years. I started out with a Remington foil razor (close as a blade or your money back); when I first shaved my head I moved to Norelco three blade razors and I've used three-blade Remingtons, Panasonics, and various Norelcos all of which I've been happy with, with the exception of the most recent Norelco/Philips which did not work and which was a huge, expensive pain to return (I'm still waiting for my money). I've never used a better electric razor, hands down.<br /><br />I cannot speak to how well it would do with lather/wet but here is a summary of the pros and cons of using it dry.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />Really close, smooth shave.<br />Easy to clean.<br />Easy to charge and to see how much charge is left.<br />Absolutely no skin irritation.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />Takes me a little longer than the three-circular-blade type.<br />Doesn't trap the hair quite as well and the cuts are finer so the hair gets scattered about a bit.<br />Took some getting used to after a decade of using three-blade types--had to find the right method/pattern.<br />Doesn't feel like it is doing well on my bumpy head (but it does!).<br />Has to be cleaned every day (IMO--the instructions say you can wait until it tells you to clean it but I've found it drops less hair on me if I clean it every day).<br /><br />Looks like more CONS than PROS but, really, seriously, the Cons are quibbles. The fact that it shaves so closely really does outweigh everything else.
  902. somehow it doesnt shave at all, my good old machine is way better than this one, its a waste of money....
  903. I recently purchased this shaver for my boyfriend. He absolutely loves it! He always complains that he cuts himself with disposable razors, so I did my research and when I saw that this shaver had a lot of positive reviews, I purchased it. He loves that he can't cut himself and that it's waterproof, so he can still shave in the shower. Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and would definitely recommend this shaver to anyone who is considering it.

It comes close to the smooth shave of a razor and takes less than 3 min to accomplish the task. My only skin prep is William&#34;s Lectric shave. Shaving the neck and under the jaw takes the most effort and time. I can get about 10-12 shaves per charge and cleaning is a snap.......just run the foil and blades under running water.<br /><br />While this doesn't shave as close as a blade, it comes pretty darn close.   922. I'm a longtime wetshaver. I have sensitive acne prone skin that's treated with topical medications. I also have a thick beard. As a result, it used to take me a long time to wetshave. I used to use an old fashioned italian barber's shave cream that I lathered up in my hands, and used a Gillette Sensor XL. I lathered up twice, shaving once with the grain, and a second time across. I never shaved against the grain so despite my routine, a lot of hair on my cheek wouldn't get cut short enough but I lived with it. For whatever reason, I decided to try electric. I was skeptical. I started with the Braun Series 5 I got from Costco. Although the box said series five, I found out a few days later that it was actually the old 360 Complete in a Series 5 box. Anyway, after a couple of days the shave wasn't bad. It was close enough to where I decided never to go back to wetshaving. I could shave in 2 minutes instead of 10! Plus it had the cool auto-clean system. Well I read a few more reviews, and found that 99% of people preferred the Panasonic 'Arc IV' over anything else. With nothing to lose, I bought the Panasonic and decided between the two, I'd return the weaker link. I really did NOT want to like the panasonic. It didn't come with a cleaning stand, and above all, I couldn't use it while plugged into the wall. Nevertheless, I tried the Panasonic this morning with a DRY shave, and decided I'm returning the Braun. The Panasonic cut CLOSER than I could get with my blade, with no burn (I had some slight skin sensitivity/discomfort after using the Braun 5). It was also much quicker. It curves around my jawline where the Braun would not (The Braun left enough hairs straggling to where my wife noticed them). I had to go at them with my blade. Not so with the Panasonic. I would say once every few days I'll use the blade around the neck because no electric will do that well in that area. I considered the Braun Series 7 but the Panasonic cost me $115 or so from Bed Bathand Beyond with their ubiquitous 20% off coupons ++plus a return policy that can't be beat---no limit to when you can return. So if this thing craps out, guess where it's going back to for an exchange? Bottom Line: despite a major boneheaded design flaw (can't use while plugged in) this thing makes up for it with the quality of the shave. When comparing to a traditional wetshave with a blade going with and across the grain, the Panasonic will be the same if not marginally closer. Nothing will cut closer than a blade going against the grain, though, but do you really need to go that close and get bumps? As far as the cleaning stand, I'll order one from Panasonic.
  923. I have been using this electric razor for two months. It is without doubt the best I have ever used. One gets a close shave without nicks and cuts; it's fast and easy to use. At first I was a little uncomfortable using water to clean the razor, but my trepidation was quickly dispelled by the efficiency of the cleaning cycle. The only suggestion I would make to Panasonic regarding this excellent razor is to consider making the trimmer a little smaller. In this way, it would be easier to trim my mustache. The current trimmer makes that process more complicated. Thank you Panasonic for an excellent razor.
  924. I have used Braun (Synchro) and Norelco (Arcitec) shavers for the last few years and haven't tried a Panasonic for at least 10 years. I always liked the Panasonic Linear shavers except for their battery life. This one is a bit better with respect to battery life getting about 12-14 shaves per charge where past experience would have me charging at least once a week. The most noticeable difference between this shaver and the others is the speed. It takes less time to get a good shave with this razor than with any other razor I have tried. It shaves as close as any other but most times I can shave in under 3 minutes even after a full weekend's growth. The Norelco Arcitec in contrast takes me over 6 minutes of going over and over my beard to get a full shave. The Norelco's battery life is at least 3 to 4 times the Panasonic, going over a month between charges. This is little consolation when spending more than twice as much time shaving. All in all this Arc IV is the best shave I have tried to date. My time (especially in the morning before work) is very valuable to me and this razor shave close, fast and without the irritation of going over and over the same areas.
  925. Update October 1st, 20010- second time I am shipping razor to repair center. First go round; shaver (3 months old)) display and functions erratic, turned on and off on its own. Repair center never acknowledges receipt of razor, no viable e-mail or phone contact for status. Razor returned 5 weeks later, working with no communication enclosed at all. Four months later (razor now 10 months old) entire unit dies completely, I ship razor back to repair center limbo and wait for its return. Terrible customer service and product quality, works well when it is functioning which is infrequent. I bought this shaver as a result of the recommendations posted on Amazon. I was tired of paying Gillette a small fortune for blades. I must admit that the first week my shaves were less than close and I was skeptical about the manufacturers advise to wait for my face and beard to adapt. I have owned the shaver for 30+ days; the shaves improved as time went on (maybe I just learned how to use the device better)but IT IS NOT as close as a blade shave. The big advantage is speed and lower use cost, I will recoup my investment in a little less than a year. I tried using the shaver \\"dry\\" with very bad results and find it works best with a thin layer of good soap on my face and frequent rinsing of the razor. I shave in the shower and clean-up is easy, it holds a charge for a week with each shave lasting ~3 minutes. It charges quickly and is compact for travel even if you bring along the charger. It would be nice if the charger was mini USB but it is unique to the device. Do not be confused by the various models of Panasonic with comparable features; shop by price and use the comparison chart published by Panasonic.

  966. My previous razor was the Norelco 7735X Cool Skin. I had 2 of them, and liked them ok; they were relatively inexpensive, but the battery dies after about 16 months, no matter how careful I was to charge it for only the manufacturer-recommended 8 hours or less. I though the shave was fine, but not that close, and there were often stray hairs left on my neck despite trying pretty hard to get rid of them.<br /><br />The Arc IV is a _much_ better shave. The charge indicator is very nice, as is the timer, so you know how long your shave took! My cheeks are a lot smoother than they ever were with the Norelco. And my neck is virtually hair-free. Don't expect any miracles -- you still have to work at the shave to get all the hair, and pull your skin this way and that. But in 4-5 minutes, I get a great shave that I'm quite happy with. I really like shaving in the shower with a good low-foam shaving cream.<br /><br />The beard trimmer is very easy to use. I didn't think I would bother with it, but it was pretty handy to trim my sideburns.<br /><br />I hesitated over the price before I ordered this, but I'm glad I took the plunge.<br /><br />**UPDATE**:<br />The display breaks easily if you drop the razor. I keep the razor in a shower caddy, and I've gone through two of these: After just one fall, the display was rendered completely unreadable. I think the product should be sturdier than that. I've dropped an iPhone from similar heights (accidentally!) and had no damage at all. I'm docking 1 star from my original review because it's so fragile.
  967. A few years ago, I switched from a Braun 7540(3 of them over a 4 year period...too many repairs, virbrations, etc.) to a panasonic 8077. It shaved as close as the Braun, no vibrations or repairs or anything for the past 3 years except a very close shave with no irritations. The linear motion cannot be compared to any of the standard battery configurations. It really does hold a full powered charge to the end....it does not weaken as it is being used. After reading about the Panasonic 8243A with the 4 blades and Arc(convex)shaped foils, I decided to see if the claims were true. They were. It shaves even closer (didn't think it was possible)than the 8077. By the way, I am in early 60's, my beard grows quite wiry, dense, and in several directions. The shaver handles it all very easily, even after not shaving for a day or two. I would recommend any linear Panasonic to everyone.
  968. This is a replacement for my Norelco 6885XL rotary razor. This is also my first foil razor. I enjoyed the ease of the shave. Yes, the neck area took longer as usual, but if you don't like the fact that you have to go over it a few times, use a blade! Overall a pretty good shave. Quicker than my Norelco. I shave only about twice a week so I'll see how fast the hairs grow back using this foil compared to my rotary. As a side note, I've noticed throughout my life using an electric razor my hair grew back at a MUCH slower pace than if I used my blade. Not sure if all people are like this, but that's why I'm able to shave only twice a week. But what really stood out was the fact that when I was done, my face & neck didn't burn like it did after my Norelco shave. I'd have to splash cold water and then use a cooling aftershave balm and even then it still burned a little. With this Panasonic, my face felt 90% less razor burn after my 4 minute shave (3 minutes on the neck--LOL!) and just a little cool water did the trick. I heard people say your face takes time to get use to any new razor. Not me. Switched from rotary to a foil and didn't feel any major difference. Shaves a lot nicer than my rotary; didn't pull at all. Plus, the deal I found on Amazon a couple weeks ago was outstanding. I was Googling this razor to find a good deal and a couple sites showed it for $79.99. They were actually links to Amazon. I thought OK, you have to sign up for Amazon prime to get the 30% discount but no---the price at the final step was actually $79.99!! What a great deal!
