The Panasonic is quieter, faster, and shaves closer. I can't believe how smooth my face is! Clean up is awesome.....just a little soap and water and you are done. I use it dry, but it can be used wet.
  971. My husband just got this because his old electric razor (a Norelco) gave out on him. Well, he's had it for two days and he absolutely loves it. Here's a synopsis of what he told me:<br /><br />1) Much closer shave than his old Norelco<br />2) Get's a clean shave in less than half the time<br />3) Doesn't leave pesky individual hairs on his neck<br />4) The wet/dry function allows him to use shaving cream which helps with the closer, cleaner shave<br /><br />His only gripes:<br /><br />1) The shaver is very loud<br />2) Takes a while to get the shaving cream out of the razor when rinsing it
  972. This is a great shaver so far!I use it wet and it works as well as my Fusion blades plus it won't be as expensive as those damn blades.<br /><br />overall a great buy!
  973. UPDATE: I had written an excellent review of this electric shaver, but I now take it back. It sucks! Without warning about two months ago, the shaver just stopped working -- just completely stopped. I thought it was the battery, so I unplugged it overnight. When I plugged it in the next morning, the unit showed the battery had a 100-percent charge. I dug out the warranty card -- two years. I e-mailed Panasonic, and I got a b.s. automated reply telling me that my shaver only has a one-year warranty. I have the documentation that it's two years! Shortly after I bought the shaver, by the way, I also got a brand-new Panasonic TV that had bad parts right from the factory. What this shows me is that Panasonic has quality issues. I'll have Panasonic fix their crummy shaver before the two-year warranty expires, but I now avoid the brand. After the shaver died, I bought a Norelco -- they are much more reliable.
  974. I used Braun shavers for years, but the quality of their lower-end shavers has declined considerably in recent years so I decided to switch brands. This Panasonic provides a much closer shave than any Braun I've ever owned. It's very easy to clean and even tells you when it's time for that. My only complaints are that it doesn't hold its charge for very long, you can't use it while it's plugged in (so you have to make sure, each time, that there's enough charge left to do the job), and the carrying case for the shaver has no room for the bulky power cord so you have to store that somewhere else. All in all, a great product.
  975. I bought this in September, primary to trim my chin beard and mustache. It was never very good at beard trimming but was pretty good for shaving. After about 3 months it just stopped working. I wasted over $100. I would not purchase this again but would buy something else.
  976. I have been very pleased with this razor. It charges very quickly,gives a close shave in about 4 minutes and is very easy to clean. It is also light in weight and less noisy than my old shaver. All in all I would say I am quite pleased with this razor.
  977. I've been using this Panasonic razor for a few weeks now and I like the razor. I was using a Norelco Spectra for a few years but finding replacement blades wasn't easy anymore. Anyways, this razor seems to cut closer although my previous razors blades were dull. One thing that I do like about it is that you can shave in the shower. I have tried shaving out of the shower and it does a good job also, but the blades/foil do get hot since they do move very quickly. Panasonic advertises this razor as a 1 pass shaver. I'd say it takes at least 3 passes to get a close shave. They also say it takes 3 minutes to shave. I have finished in 3 minutes when I was in a hurry and it does do a decent job in that time. But for those who want a really close shave it takes around 5 minutes to do a proper job. The trimmer is of good quality also. At about 5 minutes a shave you get about 10 shaves per charge. There is a charge indicator that tells keeps you advised to how much power is left. The batteries are li-ion and you can charge them whenever without fear of shortening the life prematurely. After looking at and using this razor for a while I think that the 2 main blades do most of the cutting so the 3 blade foil/razor probably is more than adequate to do the same job. The 2 inner blades don't look like they do much but I haven't tried using the lower priced models to tell for sure. Over all I'm happy with my purchase and I think I'll be buying a Panasonic razor again as long as I get a good few years use out of this razor.
  978. I've used electric shavers exclusively for the last 20 years. Mostly the triple rotary head Norelco shavers. When my last Norelco shaver's battery died, I was going to buy the latest triple rotary head model. I went to amazon like I usually do for most of my stuff and saw the Panasonic ES8243A and read the customer reviews. The reviews were so good that I hesitantly ordered a ES8243A hoping that I wasn't making a mistake by switching from a triple head rotary form factor to the ES8243A form factor. After using the ES8243A for two weeks in dry mode (I always shaved in dry mode) I'm so very pleased with this shaver. In fact I love this shaver. It shaves closer and faster than all of my previous Norelcos and is comparable to a blade. The cutting heads vibrate so fast that is more like a fast hum than a vibration so is a pleasure to use. This model has 4 rows of cutting heads. The two outer rows are the foil cutters and the two inner rows have openings that differ from each other. The entire head assembly is spring loaded to allow the optimum pressure on the face, not too soft, not too hard. But the head assembly can be locked if you prefer a stationary head. The rounded edges on all four sides make the shaving very comfortable no matter what angle or direction the shaver is moved. I plan to buy some gel or other liquid to see how wet shaving feels like, but I'll probably just continue with dry shaving since it's fast and what I'm used to. I highly recommend this shaver. I don't think you'll be sorry if you buy one. I'm really happy that I decided to take a chance and switch from triple head rotary to this shaver. I love this shaver so much that I felt compelled to post a review in spite of the large number of positive reviews already posted.
  979. I have never found an electric razor that can give my heavy beard the close shave that I would like to have. I had been using a Remington MS3 1000 for a long time and thought the Panasonic might be better but so far it has been about the same. I have tried blades but they don't treat my skin very well and are more expensive. I will keep the Panasonic in hopes that it will be satisfactory over time.
  980. This is a great shaver. I owned a Panasonic linear motor shaver 5 years ago, then switched to Norelco and now switched back to Panasonic. I love the ease of shave, floating heads, and almost everything about this shaver - except the trimmer, which is kinda small. Overall great product and 100% worth the money.
  981. Before I decided to purchase this shaver, I read all the reviews on Amazon and I was pleased to see all the very positive reviews. So, I jumped on it. I like the fact that this shaver gives me a very close shave. However, in order to get this close shave, it takes me at least 20 minutes and not the \\"advertised\\" 3-5 minutes. But the real problem I have with this shaver is that the foil and blades (I have submitted a separate review on this) only last 2-3 months. Beyond this time frame, I start to get cuts on my face. That's pretty disgusting in my opinion. This also becomes quite an expense since these things are by no means cheap. I have yet to try wet shaving and perhaps I will get close shaves in much less time and hopefully the cutters and foil will last a lot longer.
  982. I have been shaving electric since I was 16 and this is my fourth electric shaver. I believe I can provide a unique perspective since my first three were one each of the three major brands, as follows: 1. Braun - Paid: $80. Duration: eight years. Demise: battery. Shave: decent, not great but it was also 1989 when I bought it (it was a single foil). Build quality: amazing, a brick, solid. 2. Panasonic (can't recall model, but it was a mid-upper model, I think it was a three blade). Paid: $70. Duration: five years. Demise: foil (didn't replace since cost was about 1/2 a new shaver). Shave: dry-excellent wet-unbelievably close. Build quality: good overall, but excellent in that it was truly water proof. This was a true winner. I loved this shaver. One might question the duration but I also took it to three continents on multiple trips, it had a hard life. and for some reason I ventured away from Panasonic to buy a Norelco... 3. Norelco 6891XL. Paid: $95. Duration: seven and a half years. Demise: foil (again, almost 8-yrs old, didn't want to drop $35 on new blades, etc). Shave: mediocre - I always struggled getting a decent shave from this razor, I pretty much hated it from day one wishing I bought another panasonic. Build: Very good. Not bad, but not impressive. So given my experience, I decided to repurchase a Panasonic, the ES8243a. Paid: $75 (ebay NIB). I am in disbelief as to how good this shaver is. Yes, there's no such thing as a perfect shaver (no such thing as a one pass shaver on the neck), but it's amazingly good. And it's as good as a dry shaver as my first Panasonic used as a wet shaver. I haven't tried this one as a wet shaver at this time. The raise clippers are about average but do the job (i.e., trimming gotee or what have you). With minor technique, you can edge hair lines (side burns, gotee, etc) quite well. It could use a stand, would be handy on the counter, but not a big deal. This really is an impressive razor.I highly recommend it.
  983. I stopped using electric razors about four years ago because of the irritation it was causing on my face and the inability to achieve a nice close shave. I recently decided to research to try an electric razor again and my criteria was simply an affordable razor that gave a close shave without irritation. I also refused to buy an electric razor that was going to require me to spend more money for cartridges to maintain it. After about one week of shaving with this razor I found it hard to find very much difference between a shave with this and my straight razor and cleaning is as simple as a little soap and water. I couldn't be happier with this purchase and I would suggest this razor to anyone who is looking for a nice close shave.
  984. Several months ago I began a quest to find the best electric razor under about $150. I had a Norelco and it was pretty good, but for some reason I started to get very particular about the closeness of the shave, which, frankly, is odd for me, because I've never been very good at maintaining a clean shave. However, using an electric razor is kind of fun compared to a blade. First I tried the highest end Norelco. I was suprised that actually it was no better than the mid range Norelco. One thing to say about the Norelcos is that they are exceedingly quiet. I shaved with this in a hotel room while my toddler was sleeping and she didn't even stir. But it didn't get that close, especially on the neck. And over time, it started to make my skin feel raw after using it, much like after using a dry blade. I decided to try a foil type electric. I got a Braun 370. I immediately noticed that it gave a closer shave. It was slightly louder than the Norelcos. But the shave still wasn't perfect. I had to go over and over the same areas and ultimately couldn't get a perfectly clean shave. Everyone I talked to said a really clean shave is impossible with an electric, but I wanted to keep trying. One thing about the Braun is that of the three brands I tried, the clipper on the back (long hair trimmer) was by far the best. The thing was like a laser. It cut very well. Finally, I got this razor, after reading Consumer Reports and lots and lots of reviews. Actually, Consumer Reports gave the highest award to the top of the line Braun, which is also much more expensive than this Panasonic, so I can't say how that razor might compare to this one. But the Panasonic was a close second. When I first tried the Panasonic I knew immediately that it was the best razor I'd tried so far, in terms of the closeness of the cut. It is actually possible with this razor for me to get a completely clean shave -- to rub my hand up and down my cheek and neck, in all directions, and not feel any stubble! Previously only a blade could do that. Mind you, to achieve that with this razor does take quite a few passes, and you have to learn how to pull your skin to get those tricky hairs, but it can be accomplished in about 3 minutes or less. As for the wet shaving thing, eh... as far as I can tell it's mostly a gimmick. I can understand if you're taking a shower, you could save time shaving while you're in there, but why would you bother to use shaving cream? It just obscures the job. To me, the point of having an electric is that you can do it without having to lather up your face. I did try it once with shaving cream, but it certainly didn't work any better, and possibly worked slightly less well. The long hair clipper is ok. Not wonderful like on the Braun, and a bit short - would be handy if it were a little easier to see. Like the digital screen too. It's the most useful of the three razors. Not easy with this razor to get close to my mustache/goatee. Some reviewer said something like it's more like a lawnmower than a weed trimmer, and that's true. The margin of my facial hair has become slightly less clean because of this. However, it's still my favorite electric razor ever.
  985. This razor definitely gave me the best shave of any other brand I have tried. It is expensive - but it performs!
  986. A well constructed and designed shaver. It provides a smooth an comfortable shave
  987. So far, I am enjoying the Panasonic razor very much. I especially like it when I've been working outside, and therefore perspiring. I use lather; get a good shave that feels good. I'm still in the transition stage from my long-term using of Norelco shavers.
  988. Just used it on four days of neck beard. First thoughts: wow this thing is loud. It emits a high pitched whine. Otherwise, the shave is good. It cuts close and leaves very little irritation, but (on a dry shave at least) didnt pick up every hair exactly. Some hairs I ran the shaver over like ten times and it didn't catch it. Efficient and cheaper than a Braun, but the king of shavers this is not. Temper your excitement people, a step up this may be but don't believe all the hype. Now I personally hate reviews that leave me unsure, so let me say: buy if you need a step up from a Norelco. If you have a Braun you love, save your money.

Is that a plus or a minus? Mindless self-grooming? The shave, as many have noted, is less precise than a razor but acceptable (at least for me).   1026. I almost NEVER write a review of ANY product on Amazon or anywhere else, but having used this razor just a couple of days, I had to write. I have been using electric shavers all my adult life (I'm 53) and always had left over stubble (not visible, just a \\"high grit sandpaper\\" feel) that I thought was just the price of convenience. As my old Braun started failing to hold a charge for more than about three shaves, plus the rubber on the side was separating, I shopped Amazon for new electrics. I saw a Norelco video on one of their products which we bought for our son (he's a rotary guy), and the guy was using shaving cream and talked about getting a closer shave, etc. I had heard about \\"wet\\" electric shavers and thought \\"what's the use\\" since again, I was concerned more over convenience, and dry electric seemed the best option, especially since I didn't think there would be much difference. Reading the reviews, I narrowed my choices down to the Panasonic ES8103 and the newer Panasonic ES 8243A (Arc IV Nano). After checking out a couple of other review sites, I opted to spring for the extra $20 to get the Arc IV Nano. I used it dry the first two days and was very pleased. I still found just a little \\"sandpaper\\" feel in spots (mainly neck), but still WAY better results than any electric I'd ever used, and frankly better than most blade shaves as well. This morning, I decided to try out the \\"wet\\" approach with Nivea shaving cream. WHOA! No sandpaper feel AT ALL - ANYWHERE! I have NEVER had a shave like this! I didn't know a shave this close was possible. When I shave with a regular blade, I virtually always come away bleeding, and even then, had \\"sandpaper\\" spots. Seven or eight hours later, it still feels better than it ever felt RIGHT AFTER I had shaved. This is incredible. The \\"wet\\" shave technique may actually help shorten the time - certainly not take longer - since I can see clearly where I've shaved without constantly running my left hand all over my face to feel where I haven't shaved. Cleaning is easy as well. If it takes me an extra minute or two, it will be well worth it.
  1027. I've used several other brands and styles of electric shaver and recently I've switched to the Gillette Fusion razor, but nothing has compared to the Arc IV Nano. This is the closest and smoothest shave that I ever had bar none. It is also easy to clean.
  1028. My beard grows in all directions, and all too often laying pretty flat against my skin. My previous Braun shaver just didn't get those, so I'd use the Braun to get the first 80% and a Mach-III blade to get close and catch the bunch that the electric missed. Yes, two shaves each morning. I asked Santa for this Panasonic after reading other reviews, and in hopes of getting a close shave in one try. I can't be happier, and can hardly believe that an electric razor can actually shave so close. The special blades that pick-up the hairs laying flat works great. I've tried it dry (pre-shower) and wet after stepping out of the shower, and while it performs well dry, my best shave is wet using Billy Jealousy Hydroplane Shave Cream. The combo is nothing short of amazing. I get NO shaver irritation, a nice clean shave, and my face feels great. While it's not *quite* as close as that of a straight blade razor, no electric can do that with the mesh between cutting blades and your face, this Panasonic gets as close, well closer, than I thought possible. Highly recommended.
  1029. This is a very nice razor that shaves nice and close. I got it for my husband for Christmas. He hasn't used it \\"wet\\" yet. It holds a charge for several days. Super fast shipping from Amazon.
  1030. I was one of those that got suckered into using the latest and greatest leading-brand razor with the EXPENSIVE refills that would last me no more than a week before have to change the blade. I've tried other electric razors in the past, but nothing really worked on my beard that has to be shaved every day. That is until I tried this Panasonic ES8243A Arc IV. I had always shaved in the shower and desperately wanted to try an electric wet/dry razor. So after working out how much money I would be saving yearly on disposable blades I decided to part with my hard earned money to give this one a try. I am glad to say that it's been a year and a half now and just getting to where I need to replace the foil and blade. I use it almost EVERY day so I would say that I've definitely got my money's worth already! All I do at the end of my shower is take a bar of Dove soap, glide it across my face and then shave. The soap helps glide the razor across the face and I can't believe how close of a shave it give's me. I have never had this close a shave with an electric razor before. The charge lasts at least a week, maybe a bit longer, even when I use it every day. When it's time to recharge it, it finishes very quickly... maybe an hour. The razor also doesn't start to \\"wind\\" down near the end of the charge either, which sometimes can be a pain if I let it go to long before charging since it will just quit on ya. Usually you can still get another 30 seconds or so out of it by turning it back on after it stops. But that is the only negative thing I can say about this thing. It is very durable. I've dropped it several times in the shower and still works. However, the last time I did drop it, it must have hit to tub just right and now the lcd screen is jumbled and it is difficult sometimes to make out what % of charge is left. Oh well, that's about par for my clumsiness though.
  1031. If you are like me and are tired of being ripped off buying disposable blades, then I recommend you give this shaver a try. I like it because I can use it with lather, in the shower, or if I am in a hurry, use it dry. I like this model because it can be cleaned with a little liquid soap, after a dry shave, and you do not have to buy any cleaning cartridges. My previous electric shaver was a Braun. I would not go back to the Braun. This shaver is a great product and a good value.
  1032. Been using this for almost a month now. I got it to replace my old Braun 3612 razor. I've used two different Brauns for probably 20 years and generally liked them, but had to work at getting a good shave. For example, I could only use the Braun for a few days before needing to shave with a blade because there were places it would miss no matter what I did. Plus, if I missed a day (which happened frequently) the Braun would take a lot of work to handle the 2 days' growth. I liked the Panasonic immediately--it was quiet and it gave me a good shave from day one (no \\"break-in\\" period for my face). It was easy to clean. Unlike the Braun, whose screen could be irritating to my skin, it felt very smooth on my face--and left my face very smooth--and felt good in my hand. After using it for several days straight I looked for the telltale \\"always miss\\" spots that my Braun would leave. Instead of several spots, I found only one, and it was quickly and easily addressed. I've so enjoyed using this shaver that I've rarely missed a day, but on a few occasions it handled 2 days' growth nicely. And after one long weekend it even handled 4 days' growth very nicely. On the downside, it sometimes vibrates strangely (and loudly) after having replaced the cover, even sometimes when I've carefully and firmly snapped everything back in place. But then it goes back to normal. This is why I'm giving it only 4 stars. Also, I was puzzled by how, in the pictorial instructions for cleaning the razor, they get so much foam from a little bit of hand soap. I'm guessing it's because they're assuming you've used it wet and already have water inside the head to begin with. I shall have to try wet shaving with it sometime just for the experience. Bottom line, this is a great razor so far (1 month). It surpasses my old Braun in every criteria.
  1033. Simply put, the best electric razor i have ever owned. I searched around on the internet and the reviews for this razor were all good. And those reviews did not let me down. Best part, it's not the most expensive but it's definitely the best. Highly recommend it.
  1034. So I've been around since before there were cell phones and been shaving since 16. Blades, then Braun razors then back to blades, then latest version of Braun, then razor stubble, then blades, then the hell with it just grow a beard then keep beard for 13 years, then shave and back the most expensive Braun I could find. Drop out of rat race for a while, move to Costa Rica, start jeep safari business, not shaving is part of the gig, love it. Get back into Corp America so have to start shaving again. So buy electric razor. For those of you that have been away from electric razor advances like I had, you will be AMAZED! Sounds like an ad but the damn thing shaves as close as my Gillette Mach 3 Turbo - and I used to blade shave against the grain! This Panasonic razor shaves close and it shaves fast. No razor stubble and I've had the thing for about a month now. Cleaning? Just pop off top and shake it out and blow a bit - takes 45 seconds and anyone can do it. Not sure of the latest Braun's which I almost bought - but this thing does the job BETTER than advertised. And I thought Japanese engineers wouldn't know how to design such a decent product since they don't have tough beards. Go figure.
  1035. Replaces my 6 year old Panasonic. Impressed with the closeness of the shave with just light pressure. I like how quiet it is. Once in a while if I don't shave for 3 days it will have trouble with some of the long hairs but I think any razor does.
  1036. I have been using this shaver for almost a month now and it works like it should. There is a \\"break-in\\" period for you face to get used to the device. I switched from a Norelco rotary shaver and am very glad I did. I recommend this product for the function and the value.

I don't have to go over the same spot again and again to get all the stray hairs or ones going in odd directions. In 50 years, this is the BEST shave I ever got, and it only takes me about 3 minutes for a terrific shave.

  1040. Ive been an electric shaver user for 20 years now and I was very impressed with this product. I shave my head too, so put this Panasonic to the test. First thing I did was shave my head (I felt I could get a more accurate sensation of the closeness)as close as I could, with my Norelco triple head, then went over it with my new Panasonic. The difference was very obvious and I could hear it shaving the hair the Norelco could not get to and left me with a much closer shave. This is about as good as it gets in comparison to an actual blade and am extremely happy.

  1042. This is kind of funny writing a review about a shaver. This beast gives a REALLY REALLY close shave! Dont be fooled by stupid amazon picture. In real life the razor is really well put together and on the back it has a little beard trimmer that works very well. For people that are not use to shaving with electric razors your skin might get a little irritated but that will soon go away. Highly recommend buying from amazon because everywhere else does sell this for $200.

  1044. This razor is light, cuts very close and cleans very easily. I have only ever used electric and this is the best I have ever owned in 32 years of shaving. It does not shave completely in one pass but then again, I never believed it or any other electric razor could but it does do a great job in fewer passes than I am used to. Only complaint is that the one/off switch is right where my thumb rests so I accidentaly turn off the razor once or twice per shave. Digital read out is nice and makes sure I charge it in time. It also tells me when it's time to clean it.

  1047. Been using a Remington MS2-390 and the screen went bad. Rather than buy a screen and blades I usually get new. The Remingtons have always given me a close and fast shave but have often been difficult to clean, the blades fall off, sometimes getting dinged. I've had Brauns in the past but eventually figured out that they don't shave near as close or fast. Accordingly I researched razors and this one has excellent reviews. I can see why, it shaves as close and fast as a Remington without the noise and easy to clean. The first day I shaved 1/2 of my face with the Remington and the other 1/2 with the Panasonic and couldn't tell the difference in speed or closeness. The Panasonice ArcIV is as quiet as a Braun, which isn't critical to me but nice and gives a fast, close shave. It's also comfortable to hold securely and holds a charge good for 7-10 shaves. Probably the best shaver I've ever used. To clean it you wet the head, rub a drop of soap on the screens with your finger, hold ON for a couple seconds and it goes to Turbo mode, let it run for 10 seconds and then rinse for about 10 seconds. Clean as a whistle! This thing operates at a very high speed, turbo is even higher and they say that's why it cleans so well and easy. Very cool. The only thing that I dislike a bit is that it won't run while charging so if you accidentally run it all the way down and aren't finished you need to wait a few minutes for it to get a quick charge so that you can finish.
  1048. This is an excellent razor. I was please with the quality of the shave. I have never used this brand before and was very happy with how smooth it shaved.
  1049. I have owned this shaver for about six months now. I transitioned from those expensive disposable multi-blade razors... At first it was rough, I have a very thick beard that grows quickly. The manual states that you can shave in 3 minutes using this shaver. At first that was not possible, but as I have gotten used to shaver and learned how to use it I can shave in 3 to 4 minutes (there is a time display in the unit, very nice!). I do have to shave daily to accomplish this though. If I skip a day or two it is more like 5 minutes. The battery life has been great. I would readily take this shaver fully charged on a short business trip with no worries about bringing the charger. I find that the quickest shave is dry. I have used it with water or even shaving cream. I would not recommend the shaving cream, but with water seems to make things smoother and was necessary when I was first getting used to it. Cleaning is simple and the display informs you when it is needed. I would agree that it does take about a month to get used to, don't give up though! I love it now and have absolutely no plans of going back. I would happily buy another and I have probably already made up my cost when compared to the major brand disposables.
  1050. To start off with, I am in my 60s, so this is not my first electric shaver. It is however the first electric shaver that I have ever liked, no, loved. I bought it primarily because it is easy to clean. My last shaver required a cleaning station and special liquids and was a real pain. It also never actually cleaned very well either. With this shaver you just put a little liquid soapon the head, turn it on and put it under a running facet. Easy. Takes about 20 seconds and competely clean. What I did not expect was the quality of the shave. With my old shavers I always finished with a wet safety razor to get a close shave. This it the first shaver I have ever used that gave me a closer shave than a safety razor. I have read that there is sometimes a problem with the display going dead. If it does, I will buy another. I love it.

  1052. Shaving wet or dry (I prefer wet-in the shower) with this razor is really a pleasure. I use some Kiss my Face shaving cream and that helps, but haven't tried anything else yet - since that works so well (a little is all that's needed). I remove the shaving outer screen and rinse the blades and screen after each use. I've been using it for several months now. I got used to it right away, switching from a safety razor. In past, I tried Norelco razor (about 8-10 years ago) again after a long gap between trying electric razors prior. Other razors (Norelco, and a Braun) irritated my face and I gave up on each after about three months. This razor holds a charge pretty well (five to six days for me). Prior to this Panasonic electric razor, I shaved with the Gillette latest high-end razor, but that scraped me up too and it just wasn't pleasant no matter what shaving cream I used (I tried many). I'm hoping this will last a long time and I'm willing to replace blades and outer screen in a year if I need to.
  1053. UPDATE: almost two years later (2.5 total ownership years) I still use this regularly and I'm quite happy with it. My one major complaint is that shortly after my last review water got inside the display circuitry, causing all of its lights to be on or off pretty much at random (or sometimes even halfway in between being on and off). This is after normal use, and is a pretty big issue for a device that's supposed to be used in your shower - so I'm changing my review from 5 to 4 stars. I can't tell if I need new blades, or if the unit needs washing, or even how much power is left; I just have to sort of guess. Nonetheless the unit has otherwise functioned quite well, and continues to shave and self-clean without issue. I have only needed to replace the foil once.<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW:<br /><br />I always used disposable straight edge razor blades before I bought this. I hated it it so much I was always scruffy, shaving once every few days or less. There would always be a mess in the sink, it would take 20 minutes, and even going very slowly I would get all sorts of cuts. I tried different blades, different shaving creme, everything; no luck.<br /><br />I bought my ES8243 last August. I take it into the shower every day; there's no cleanup! No shaving creme needed! I think it has cut me once the entire year. It did take a lot longer than claimed to shave at first, but I've got it down to five minutes - the trick for people used to straight edge is that you have to go back and forth pretty quickly (but not pressing hard) in a way that would bloody your face with a normal shaver. The shave is far closer than I have ever been able to manage with a normal razor.<br /><br />Most importantly, I think it's cheaper. I was worried I'd need new blades after 3 months. The \\"replace blades\\" signal has only just come on after 11 months of use. As such, it was better to pay the $100 or so up front for this, than to keep buying new straight edge blades every few weeks.
  1054. Have used electric shavers for over 60 years, and this is, without a doubt, the best I've ever used. It shaves closer and doesn't leave behind any neck hairs. I shave dry. Highly recommended.
  1055. If you want a really close shave, stick with blades. Pimply face that gets shredded by blades? Electric is a face-saver. This razor works fine, but still can't match a blade. And not having to belt a bath towel to your face after some errant 'blading' is definitely a plus. All in all a nice razor for convenience, safety, and close-enough shaving, but if you've got to come with your \\"A\\" game I'd advise going with the blade.

  1084. I just switched from a DE razor (Merkur Classic, Israeli Personna blades) to electric, and bought both the Philips Norelco SensoTouch 3D 1250X and the Panasonic ES8243A. I've spent a few weeks with both, and here is what I found:<br /><br />First, the &#34;try it for 3 weeks&#34; thing is REAL. The first two weeks were terrible. Shaves were not close, I had irritation, redness and ingrown hairs. I tried shaving wet and dry, with similar results. Then, miraculously, halfway through Week 3, everything cleared up. Once that happened, the electric shaves were closer than my DE (or closer than I was willing to go with my DE).<br /><br />For background: my beard is fairly thick, and has a few regions that grow in different directions. The hair on my neck is all over the place. My hair is straight and black, my skin is brown and rather delicate, and I used to shave 2-3 times a week because it would take 15 minutes.<br /><br />Now, to compare:<br /><br />Closeness: both shavers are closer than doing a single with-the-grain pass of a DE razor. The Panasonic was noticeably (to the touch) closer on my face and chin, and the Norelco was possibly slightly closer on my jawline and neck. Both shavers also miss the same areas, creating consistently longer zones into two spots on my neck. My wife says she doesn't notice, but I do.<br /><br />Speed: average shave time with Panasonic was 4'15&#34;. Average shave time with Norelco was 5'30&#34;.<br /><br />Number of passes: on straight surfaces, the Panasonic needed just a few passes to cover the area. On curved areas, the Panasonic needed a lot of angling and back and forth, but it was a precise operation. The Norelco always needed a long random walk with lots and lots of passes, I think because the ratio of cutting surface to contact surface is much lower. The one exception is that flat-lying hairs would get picked up more quickly by the Norelco (though they wouldn't get cut as short).<br /><br />Comfort: both were very comfortable to shave with. After the 3-week adjustment, both caused no irritation or redness.<br /><br />Cleanup: easy on both. Though average cleanup time was about 0'40&#34; with the Panasonic, and 0'30&#34; with the Norelco.<br /><br />Coolness: The Norelco is SO COOL. It looks amazing, and feels like robot kisses when you shave with it. The Panasonic is not beautiful, and the Black/Orange display screams &#34;budget&#34;. The Norelco is a gadget, while the Panasonic is just a tool.<br /><br />Price: current pricing and coupons at the time I bought these put them pretty close together. $100 for the 1250X, and $85 for the 8243A.<br /><br />Overall: I love the Norelco so much. It is so, so cool. But it takes an extra minute, and is not quite as close. So I'm returning the Norelco and keeping the Panasonic. I have agonized over this decision way more than I intended, and I'm glad it's over. I also have to shout out to Philips customer service. Getting an RMA number was really easy and took less than 5 minutes.o shave with. After the 3-week adjustment, both caused no irritation or redness.<br /><br />Cleanup: easy on both. Though average cleanup time was about 0'40&#34; with the Panasonic, and 0'30&#34; with the Norelco.<br /><br />Coolness: The Norelco is SO COOL. It looks amazing, and feels like robot kisses when you shave with it. The Panasonic is not beautiful, and the Black/Orange display screams &#34;budget&#34;. The Norelco is a gadget, while the Panasonic is just a tool.<br /><br />Price: current pricing and coupons at the time I bought these put them pretty close together. $100 for the 1250X, and $85 for the 8243A.<br /><br />Overall: I love the Norelco so much. It is so, so cool. But it takes an extra minute, and is not quite as close. So I'm returning the Norelco and keeping the Panasonic. I have agonized over this decision way more than I intended, and I'm glad it's over. I also have to shout out to Philips customer service. Getting an RMA number was really easy and took less than 5 minutes.
  1085. I had the last version of this razor that had fewer blades and it was very good but not always close. I got this one thinking more blades equal closer shave. It was a little better initially but not spectacular. But then after using Panasonic shavers for over a year I decided to finally follow the directions and press LIGHTY. What I learned was the lighter you push the closer the shave. End of story. It's counter intuitive but this now offers me a very close and quick shave. Great product if used according to manufacturer.
  1086. This is my 2nd Panasonic Electric Razor, and I love this one even better then the last one.<br />It provides a great, close shave and seems to hold a charge for awhile.

But the downfall to that is I have very sensitive skin so I alway nick myself and it's expensive to constantly change out the cartridge. I was destined to use an electric razor. Not only that it is a lot faster and less mess. Thank you Panasonic!
  1102. i did alot of research due to my sensitive skin and the panasonic modes with the Arc system were highly rated. i have been using for over 2 weeks now and if you have sensitive skin this is the shaver for you! however, depending on how fast your hair grows you may want to consider sticking with a straight razor. i have found that shaving daily with this razor is not enough due to how fast my hair grows - i am still cleaning up with a straight razor after using the Panasonic. this is the first electric shaver that I have used so I don't know what to expect from competitors. i bought the new gillette straight razor last night and loved it. just my 2 cents.
  1103. I was a staunch believer in disposable razors ever since I started shaving several decades ago. That is, until I tried this Panasonic razor. The shave I get with the Panasonic is just as close as with a disposable but in about half the time. I recharges quickly, too, and it couldn't be easier to clean.
  1104. Prior to this shaver, I have always gotten bad razor burn from any electric razor I have ever tried, regardless of style or brand. My face is also sensitive to any scented aftershave, so I have to use an unscented moisturizer. I have been using a 11 year old Remington that worked just fine (except for the razor burn). But I started wondering if 10 years had produced any better shavers. I read some reviews and decided to give the Panasonic ES8243A a try. I loved it from the first shave. Shave time dropped from almost 10 minutes to 4-6 minutes, depending on whether I shave every day or every other day. My face is far less iritated than with any other shave I have tried over the years. The shave is just as close, and it deals with longer hairs much more reliably than other shavers. The only complaint I have is with the documentation. The instructions on cleaning are unclear and contradictory. But I was able to figure it out on my own without too much trouble so that isn't too big a deal. It is certainly easier to clean than any of my other shavers. I would recommend this shaver to anyone with or without a sensitive face.
  1105. Ok so I never write reviews of products, but I just want to say that this razor is amazing. Now i'm not one of the guys who bought this razor because I have sensitive skin or because I cut my skin all the time. Honestly, I can shave with just a little bit of water on my face and that's it. For my first shave, I had a about 2 days growth...not much but enough to be a good challenge for my first electric shave. Now I have to admit, it will probably take getting used to the feel of getting shaved by an electric, but it wasn't as bad as thought it was going to be. There are some tough place on my face that i had to go over more than once, but then again, i have to go over those places more than once with my other razor. This thing really does give an extremely close shave. I thought people were stretching the truth a little when they said it's as close as blade...and i'm here to confirm that it truly does give a razor close shave... I am so impressed. I love this thing.
  1106. I really wanted it to work, so I could ditch the razor, but it just would not cut the hair on my face. Even if I used my Panasonic trimmer to get my beard nice and short (which I love, and have used for years). It would cut some, but leave even more. No matter how many passes, how hard I pressed, wet or dry, it just wouldn't do it. I suspect I am one of those people for whom an electric shaver will never work. No, I'm not some hairy beast with a brillo pad face. Perhaps some of my facial hair is thicker than can pass through the foil. On the construction and ergonomics of the shaver, I would say that Panasonic hit another home run. It's well made, easy to hold, and I like the floating head design. I wish it came with a base instead of just a cord, however, so you could just drop it in. Panasonic makes a great variety of fantastic gear. But this one is going back.
  1107. Overall, I really like the Panasonic ES8243A Arc IV Nano Men's Wet/Dry Rechargeable Shaver I bought myself as a Christmas present during one of the special pricing opportunities here on Amazon. I was leery of trying another electric shaver, but so far so good after several weeks.<br /><br />This shaver is easy to grip, it follows facial contours closely, it holds its charge quite well, and the wet/dry capability is great. And though the color has nothing to do with function, I like this shade of blue. This razor seems more durable and well-crafted than other electric razors I have tried.<br /><br />My main con could be labeled as operator error, but sometimes I cut too closely and abrade the skin. Learning how to apply the correct pressure seems to be the key, and using this razor with a bit of soap or oil works best for me.
  1108. Wanted an alternative to safety-razor for those days when either time constraints or just laziness would make electric razor desirable. Been only a week but the ES8243A performs higher than I anticipated; very high quality close shave. Near safety-razor close shave over entire face and neck without irritation. Still require a blade/foam to properly trim sideburns but I expected that as pop-up trimmers generally are adequate for only a so-so job. Have only used as a dry shave and results are excellent. If I'm going to take the time for a wet shave I'll likely just use the safety razor, as for me the purpose of the ES8243A for me in the first place is a quick no fuss close shave.<br />This model fulfills my preference for a cord charger versus a docking station battery charging setup; really didn't want the permanent clutter on the counter considering infrequent need to charge. Cleaning as simple as tapping unit over the sink or a quick exposure to running warm water. Carrying case is sturdy enough although I wish it had been designed to also hold the cord but I'll use a zip-lock bag to carry both shaver and cord when traveling.<br />Overall I could not be happier with this choice. Performance is outstanding, made in Japan and quality appears first rate, plus price was attractive.
  1109. I get a closer shave with this Panasonic when I use it dry, especially when I rub a few drops of Pjur Original over my stubble. Then the cut is as close as a blade. Amazing. I bought it to shave in the shower, which I do a couple of times a week -- when I also use the opportunity to rinse out the razor, so it's very easy to keep clean. My beard is soft and slow growing -- I'm not a heavy weight shaver. I had been a Braun user up to now. Each time the old shaver wore out I reverted to blades for a couple of years, hankering after a closer shave. This time I'll be inclined to replace my Panasonic.

  1119. I put it up against my Gillette Fusion Proglide and ... First some setup, I'm mid 50's, white, Scandinavian type, takes me 3 weeks to grow a complete, full beard. I started my shaving life with a Norelco rotary, I shaved dry before I showered (I didn't know better) and then 15 years later moved to an Eltron Universal and then after a couple more years switched to a dual blade manual. From there it was 24 more years of manuals moving up the line to the 5 blade Fusion. I wanted to try an electric again purely for the days I needed to shave dry. Some mornings I go out kayaking or surfing and the stubble on my neck gets irritated by my wetsuit or paddle jacket if I haven't shaved or if I didn't shower before shaving. The neck hairs are mostly why I stopped shaving with an electric because it left too many. I've now got 10 days of use on the Panasonic. My very first impression was that it did the job but wasn't as close as I was use to. That thought persisted over the next few days as I shaved in the shower using my usual Neutrogena shave cream to ease my way thru the break-in period. BTW, no skin irritation so far. I also thought that by 5 pm I had more stubble. BUT, then after a week I shaved half my face and neck with the Fusion, and half with the Pani. I was surprised, the Pani shaved closer and by the next day I had less stubble. The difference was minor but even my wife felt it. A few days later I repeated the test but switched halves to be fair and while still in the shower I could feel the Pani side was smoother. The morning after my wife once again picked the Pani side. Also, I've done a dry shave using a Remington FaceSaver stick and still no skin irritation from the shaver or paddling jacket. I'm loving this whole rinse with water cleaning process. No more cleaning mess with those darn little brushes. I opted not to get the cleaning station because I really didn't believe this was going to be a daily shaver, but now that it is I still don't have any regrets because of the simplicity of this cleaning process. I also think this model will be more travel worthy. The sideburn trimmer seems okay but I already own a Wahl beard trimmer so its not a concern for me. Recharge time is quick! At first I also thought the unit was a bit bulky but I've easily adjusted and the rubbery grip is secure in the shower (BTW, those shaves are without the water running). Lastly a few words on neck hairs, mine grow in many different directions and I've never gotten a perfectly smooth shave with anything. That said, this is as good as a manual for me.
  1120. not even close to being as close as a blade and some spots just get outright missed. it takes longer than regular shaving and does a worse job, especially if you have a small bump on your face or it's not smooth. neck & chin are almost worthless. i'm amazed that people feel like this works b/c it's no where near as good as a razor blade.

  1122. I am updating my review because I bought this just over 14 months ago, and for the last several months the shaver's display has lost its function. So I now have a display that doesn't show the power bars or time expended. It now ALWAYS says I need to clean the shaver, replace the cutting head, and there are other displays I have never seen before. So,now I am writing an update so people who do buy this knows that you are going to spend $10/mth for the shaver and an additional $10/mth for replacement heads.. or about $1 per day.. so, here is my original review.. and I suggest if you write a review early after purchase, you calendar yourself for 9 mths after your purchase and see if you would keep this review...<br /><br />At Age 57, I have tried many an electric shaver since Nixon was president. If you are like me, who has tried blade, remington, braun, and norelco; your journey should end at this shaver. I now shave wet, not dry, and that is so huge for comfort and closeness. I am writing because my shaver died, after being on a plane over three years jostled by carry on baggage. It's battery is remarkable, lasting over a week when the battery is trained to last that long. With sensitive skin, and a number of bumps on my face, this shaver has reduced the pain and suffering I have had using the other shavers. In addition, the other electric shavers, for the price, are not as close cutting. If you do buy this shaver, make sure you buy additional blades/foil to replace every 3 months. You can last 6 months if you don't travel, but if you do.. go 3 months.. the jostling does impact the cut, and I use oil of olay body lotion as my shaving foam/soap.

  1130. My husband is so happy with this razor that he wants to get one for every man in both families. He tells everyone about it. Good clean, super smooth shave, no irritation.
  1131. I thought I swore-off Foil Shavers after a really bad experience with a previous Remington. But I realize now, that the Remington just was horribly made. This electric razor even shaves better than my last Rotary electric razor. I have a pretty narrow, angular face that does not make it easy to get a close shave with an electric razor. However, the Panasonic Arc 4 gets a closer shave than anything I've used short of a bladed razor. If you are in the market for a very good electric razor, you can't go wrong with this razor.<br /><br />If you have doubts about there not being and &#34;auto-clean&#34; base, don't feel like you are losing out. My old Remington had one, and rusted out after a year (again could have been poor design). This panasonic can be easily cleaned in under a minute. Put a drop of liquid hand soap on the foil, turn the razor on to lather it up a bit, then hold down the power button to activate the Ultrasonic mode. Just wait until the razor stops automatically after 30 seconds, then repeat the Ultrasonic mode under running water. Remove the foil and clean off the inner blades under running water once more. Dry off the razor and it's just like new. It's simple and quick. All in all, it's been the best electric razor I've ever owned.
  1132. This is my first electric shaver and I got impressed how fast it was to me get used to that.

It took about a week to get used to the new shaver but every shave has been close and smooth. I would definitely recommend this shaver to others.

  1146. I cant quite give this razor 5 stars yet, but I will say, so far, it's over delivered on my expectations. I bought this when Amazon had it on sale for Black Friday for under $80.00. I'm a long timeblade man, I Haven't used an electrick since high school when I got a Eltron (now Braun)for graduation in 1980. Since then, I've sadly developed a pretty heavy beard, and gave up long ago on the convenience of an electric for a good close shave with a blade. However, with all the constant technological improvements we enjoyed in the last 30 years, I figured they must have made some progress in this department. After spending a good amount of time checking the reviews for a bunch of electrics on Amazon , I settled on the this model and I bought this on a lark for a Christmas present to myself. Although I have not quit the blade 100%, I think since Christmas, I've only used one a few times. I've been using the Panasonic quite a bit, and here's what I've found. 1. Love the wet / dry option. For best results, I've found shaving in the shower with some good gel provides the best shave. 2. It's not perfect...there are times I have to do some spot clean up in the tough spots with a blade, but that's usually only having skipped shaving a day or two. 3. Does NOT work on a weekends growth, or anything more than day or two max. You have to keep up on the shaving every day for best results. 4. Not necessarily a time saver. I find I have to pretty much use the electric shaver exactly as I would a blade, going over the tough spots ( jaw line, neck, etc...) multiple times to get acceptable closeness. 5. Works for last minute touch ups before an evening out. I get a good shadow by 5pm, and if we have a night time function, I can get a decent, passable touch up with the Panasonic, even using dry to save time. 6. I agree that you have to use the electrice for a week or so to adjust for best results. I dont think your beard necessarily 'adjusts' as some have speculated, but you learn how to use it for best results. 7. Best of all, for the first time in my adult life, I do not have those ugly nasty red shaving irritation bumps on my neck from using a blade. It's still only been a few weeks, but so far, I'm impressed. Now the big question is how long will the blades and screen last. 1 review said 1 year. if so, that's a great value. I wonder if that's really accurate.
  1147. Works very nicely as a cordless Wet/Dry razor and I wanted to try the newer technology from my old 3 circular blade rotary Norelco. I shave my head as well as my face and wanted this for the in between shaves to save time rather than lathering up and using the straight razors every day. It works great on one or two day growth but past that it takes 2 or 3 passes and pressing harder to get the equivalent job of a 5 balde Gillette Fusion straight razor. And when pressing harder on the neck area it tends to leave a little razor burn but still overall, a great razor for the money as compared to $200 + for the Norelco high end model I was considering. Good one to have but don't throw out your old standby straight razors. It runs fairly quiet, holds the charge well and is easy to clean by just running it under warm water.

  1162. This is my second ES8243 in 4 years. I do shave with different Panasonic shavers for 15-18 years already. Found it much better than Braun, Remington or Norelco.   1173. I cannot attest to longevity, but as for effectiveness, this razor is very good. I had the So much better than the Panasonic ES-RT51-S 3 Blade Electric Razor -- which was barely effective even when it was working. It died before the one year mark. This 4 blade razor must have a totally different shaving design. It's smooth and effective. If it lasts, I'll be very happy.<br /><br />UPDATE: Something to note if you travel. The on/off switch is a button on the front that toggles on and off simply by pressing it. The button is easy to press and to activate accidentally -- unlike a slider switch. I recently traveled with this razor stored in checked baggage. When I retrieved the baggage, the razor was on, and nearly depleted. At some point during the flight or afterwards, the button had been pressed. This is a design flaw that needs to be addressed in the next version of this razor.

  1189. I followed all instructions and shaved areas of my neck and face I normally shave with a triple-edge blade. I used a good gel. The shave was really nice and close, so I was initially very happy; however, there were two problems. Problem number one was that in an area of looser skin, the shaver \\"bit\\" me, I don't know how (I know, it seems impossible for a shaver that has no exposed blades... but it really happened). It left parallel bleeding cuts, about 9 or 10 of them, on the underside of my neck. Problem #2 came in 3 days when the shaved areas became red and covered with swellings from ingrown hairs. 3 of these turned into abscesses and required minor surgery and antibiotics, leaving what will certainly be permanent scars. So... no, not happy.<br /><br />What makes this worse for me is that this shaver has a 30 day money back guarantee, but there was a sheet of paper included that practically begs you to use it for 30 days, despite any \\"discomfort\\" it might cause, and not return it without giving it a chance. Well, this makes me think they knew there is a likelihood of ingrown hairs. Maybe the shaver just works too well and shaves too close? I don't know. Still, I think it would have been more appropriate to warn of the possible side effects.

  1200. I bought my ES8243A shaver on Amazon.com 3 years ago. It is STILL the best shaver I've ever owned. I am just now getting around to replacing the original blades and foil. (My beard is very tough. Other shavers I've owned needed replacements a lot sooner.)<br /><br />As mentioned in many reviews here, the Panasonic shavers that are made in Japan are amazing and the Panasonic shavers made in China just aren't as good. I've owned both; it's true.<br /><br />Cleaning the ES8243A is trivial. Just apply a bit of hand soap and rinse. I owned a Braun shaver with a cleaning system once. I'll never do that again. It dulls the blades faster, the cleaning cartridges are not cheap, the shaver isn't any more clean that it would be otherwise, and it's noisy - for hours.<br /><br />One note for cleaning the ES8243A - make sure you rinse the trimmer too and leave it open to dry.<br /><br />I've owned shavers by Norelco, Remington, Braun, and Panasonic. The ES8243A is significantly better than any other shaver I've owned - except an earlier Panasonic, which was also made in Japan.

  1213. Really don't like a dry shave, so I went looking for a wet/dry electric option. A little over a year ago I bought the Panasonic ES8168. It gave a good shave on the face but I needed to go over the neck several times for the closeness I wanted. All in all a good shave...but not great. Also, I wasn't crazy about the cleaning/drying/charging station - I didn't like having to buy the refillable cleaning units and it took almost four hours to complete all cycles. Recently I picked up the ES8243A and couldn't be happier. Firstly, the shaver's appearance is much nicer than the online photos... the blue on the front is dark and the sides and back are slightly rubberized black (I think it is black). So if you are holding out for the black model ES8243K (with the cleaning unit) don't bother. The 8243A is the new \\"four blade\\" technology - purported to be a faster, closer shave. I have found it is what has been advertized - a faster and closer shave! The \\"four blades\\" actually refers to the outer foil, a \\"squarer\\" design than the 8168. There are still two inner blades, but spaced farther apart than the 8168. For me, the new head design touches more of my face than the 8168 and therefore cuts faster. I have read on other sites that the foil is a thinner steel, allowing the inner blades more access to the skin. The shave has been fast, gliding easily and for the most part needs only one pass for the reults I want. Big improvement! Ergonomically the shaver is easier to hold than the 8168 and the head design hits all of the hard to reach areas of the neck. Have been using it with Billy Jealousy Hydroplane shave cream, a great product. Because you only need to apply a very thin layer it is perfect for an electric shaver. The ES8243 glides effortlessly over it and the build-up on the razor is minimal. I usually rinse it 3 -4 times during each shave. Until this shaver I have been of the opinion the electrics couldn't compare to the closeness of the Gillette Fusion (my previous fav), but all that has changed with the ES8243A. For the first time I can say the shave is as close as the non-electric options, and with no razor burn. IMO Panasonic has hit the bullseye with this product.
  1214. For years I've searched for the perfect electric shaver. I have a tough beard and very sensitive skin, so a straight razor is out of the question. To get a smooth shave from any top brand electric shaver takes 20 minutes, and the abrasions are a killer, not to mention the red face for most of the day. So I once again entered the new razor arena, recently trying the top brand shavers including the newest Braun Pulsonic 9585 and the latest Norelco Arcitec, and was left unsatisfied with 20 minute painful and irritating shaves, until using the Panasonic Arc 4 ES8243A. I've never been inspired to comment on any product of any kind like this, but I would like to spare others the hours of surfing online for the perfect shaver. The Panasonic Arc 4 actually delivers as claimed. I can shave comfortably and even more smoothly in literally half the time compared to my previous 20 minute ordeals. I'm also experiencing an unexpected bonus: even after only a few days, each shave has taken less time than the day before. My last shave this morning was only 8 minutes. My skin is consistently left smooth and comfortable. So far, I've only used this shaver dry. When I'm not rushed in the morning I may try it wet to see if I can lessen my shaving time even more.
  1215. I've been trying quite a few brands and models of shavers for the past couple of months, then I bought this model. This has to be the best I have tried. Doesn't irritate my skin, it gives one of the closest shaves, specially if wet-shaving. Very easy maintenance, no special detergents or fluids required. Somebody had pointed out that it was noisy. I don't find it noisy but it is louder than a Norelco I was using. I recently bought the ES8249K, same model, in black and with a cleaning/drying/charging station, mainly because I wanted some kind of station where it could rest & charge automatically (I wasn't interested in the cleaning portion).
  1216. Excellent! My fiance is more than pleased! He's showed his father and best friend...who both now want the same one.
  1217. First off, I don't use cheap razors. Learned that lesson a long time ago, when it comes to placing a sharp cutting edge on your face, saving a few bucks isn't worthwhile. So I have experience with a lot of high-end razors over the years, and originally didn't consider this one because it was so inexpensive. I bought this shaver about a month and a half ago, and have used it steadily since then. I like it, but it's not the perfect shaver. A very good shaver, but not perfect. Pros - This is the closest to a true single-pass shaver that I've ever had the pleasure to use. The documentation cautions you not to apply a lot of pressure which means you might have a habit to break there; applying too much pressure will give you razor burn, and with shaver, you simply don't need to press hard. Even if you need a few 'scrubs' across an area, minimal pressure works great. I use this to not only shave my face, but the top of my head as well, every morning. It works even better on the dome than it does on the face, giving me the closest shave that an electric has ever offered. The wet-shave option just makes the experience nicer, and you can actually use a light layer of shaving cream with this razor. Cons - Battery life isn't as good as I had hoped. This isn't a show stopper, just something to be aware of it; it won't last as long as many other electric razors out there. Probably due to the higher cutting speed. This razor has a big head which makes it fine for large areas, like the top of your head, and it covers your cheeks pretty fast, but I sport a goatee and moustache too. That's where this razor really shows it's limitations, the shaving head is too big to do anything approaching detail work. I shave the upper part of my moustache and this razor is just too big to even see what I'm doing in that area, let alone do fine work like shaping a moustache and goatee. On the flip side side of the razor is the obligatory push-up trimmer, and yes, it works, but you're taking achance very time you use it. That big shaving head once again gets in the way of being able to see what you're doing with that little trimmer and you're just as likely to trim off half your moustache if you insist on trying to use it. Bottom line - The Arc 4 is what it is; a superb shaver of broad, open areas. But if you have a moustache or goatee, don't be so fast to get rid of your other shaving options because the Arc 4 can't do it alone.
  1218. Great shaver. Get good shave without pressing hard against skin
  1219. mom & i bought this for dad for his 88th birthday. he says he has never had a better shave in his life using this razor! mom & i are so happy we bought it for him now. at first we were skeptical because of the new technology and i will say that if there was anything bad about this purchase it would be the instructions are a bit overwhelming for older folks. however, once he had it charged and ready, he says its the greatest! he loves the optional wet/dry features and he says its really easy on his face...easier than anything he has ever used. it has been a perfect gift for him!!

[[ASIN:B001DKMY9Q Panasonic ES8243A Arc IV Nano Men's Wet/Dry Rechargeable Shaver, Blue]] I have been shaving with electric shavers for over 40 years because I never found a blade system that was comfortable for my skin. During those years I have owned almost every conceivable shaver made by either Braun or Norelco. I was impressed by the almost uniform raves and at about half the price I took a chance and bought one together with Billy Jealousy shave cream.   1222. I have an extremely heavy and stubborn beard. Think \\"5 O'Clock Forest\\" instead of \\"5 O'Clock Shadow\\". If I don't shave for 2 days, little old ladies hurry across the street and cops follow me around. While I used a Panasonic ES 8092 regularly, I was never satisfied since it took repeated passes to get the heaviest areas and the neck clean. Even then, when I got into work I'd see bits that hadn't been properly cleared and the overall look was still a bit \\"shadowy\\". If I didn't use the electric for 2 days in a row - forget it. Only a Fusion FIVE BLADE would really clean things up. In fact, when I really needed a clean look - meetings, dates, DMV pictures - I would use the blade. So I decided to retire the old 8092 and give electrics one last chance. When I saw the specs and the price on the 8243A, I figured this was it. I waited a day and a half before using it for the first time. Wow! In literally 1 minute (yes, I timed it), my beard was gone, my neck was clear and my skin clear. It still stung a bit (skin not used to 4 blades and a 13k rpm motor), but it didn't feel anywhere near as bad as a blade. This thing is amazing. It blows regular blades, including the Mach3, out of the water and I suspect it could match the Fusion. Need to do a few more test shaves before I can be sure. Effortless shaving, incredibly clear results, fast shaves and quick recharges. What's not to like ???? Update: I can now report that I have used this shaver regularly for weeks on a SINGLE charge. That's how effective it is. Shaving barely takes 2 minutes. I even look forward to it since it provides a \\"clean look\\". Truly exceptional. Update 2: Six months and still going strong!
  1223. I purchased this shaver about a month ago. Before that I was using Mac3. When I switched, I expected some irritation in the first few days.   1226. The last shaver I purchased was one of the Norelco rotary head ones, and I had begun to regret it shortly afterwards, but since I'm not one to want to waste money, I vowed to use it until either the unit itself was dead, or the blades I bought with it got too dull for effective use. My cats finally decided that enough was enough, and they sent my old Norelco crashing to the floor perhaps one too many times, and it finally died.<br /><br />So I began the search for a good foil shaver, and at first was dismayed that I couldn't find a decent plug in unit. It seemed most of them were battery powered and came with some kind of giant cleaning apparatus which I would inevitably use until the initial cleaning solution was gone...and then I would abandon. I then found this an ad for this Panasonic, and reading some of the reviews, I figured it was worth a shot, no matter what, it had to be better than the last one I used for almost 2 years.<br /><br />I am glad I made that decision, this thing shaves much closer, and due to the very high speed motor, cuts through my extra coarse beard without practically plucking each of my hairs, like my old Rotary did from the start.<br /><br />My only annoyance with the unit is that you can't run it plugged in, it has to be charged, and then used off the battery, meaning that if the battery dies, the shaver is toast, as it doesn't appear to be easily replaceable, if at all.<br /><br />While I ponder why no one makes a good plug in foil shaver any more, I will settle on this Panasonic as an excellent second choice.
  1227. This is a nice shaver. Spend the extra $30 and get the Panasonic ES-LA63-S. It's much better and is the closest electric shaver I have used. They LOOK the same but the ES-LA63-S is a better unit.
  1228. was getting tire of using my clippers to try to shave my head.. it was hard to do and missed many spots and even cut my head sometimes...   1230. I can't remember if I've never reviewed anything on Amazon before and probably have not even though I make most of my purchases for everything on Amazon now of days. I came on here today just to recommend this razor. Ever since I can remember shaving, I always got razor burn on my neck. These of course were the times of the dispensable Bic razors. I eventually upgraded to Mach 3 blades and eventually electric razors all with the same razor burn result. I tried different creams, aftershaves, balms, ice on neck... everything. So, for the last 10 years, I've pretty much shaved with a beard trimmer that would get close to the skin, but not as close as a shave. During the 10 years, I bought and tried other expensive electric razors such as panasonic and norelco thinking that eventually they might develop one that was good for me. Still the same razor burn result and so I stuck with my trusty beard trimmer. Until now. Just recently purchased this razor. Was a little optimistic after reading reviews. I also purchased the Billy Jealously Hydroplane shaving cream and bought an after shave cream. I'm not sure if it was the shaving cream or the razor... but 10 shaves in now... closest shave I've had in forever and no razor burn. Now I'm sure others have done extensive tests on other comparable razors like the Braun 7 or other panasonic razors and I'm sure they're just as good... maybe better. I just wanted to come on here to say that this razor is the best I've used and I'm extremely happy I made the purchase.

  1243. I bought this for my husband 2 years ago, and before that, he was struggling with really bad red bumps/ingrown hairs from shaving. He tried all sorts of different razors, skin products, and methods of shaving, but he could never get rid of the bumps, and a lot of the time, he'd end up with a shave that wasn't very nice and clean. This shaver has been great for him. He doesn't have any red bumps at all, and he gets a very nice, close shave. It's good quality, and he hasn't had any issues with it. He hasn't ever replaced the blade or anything like that (and now that I'm thinking about it, he probably should...) but it's still going strong! Great product! This had good reviews when I first bought it, but now it has almost 1,000 good reviews... definitely a testament to its quality!

  1245. I have had it for 2 weeks now. The first 2 shaves were rough, as can be expected, because it's been months since I had a working electric razor. I charged it up when I got it, it's currently at around 60% after 2 weeks, shaving every other day or so.<br /><br />The only complaint I would have is that the charging cord doesn't fit in the carrying case.
  1246. June 22, 2012 update: my original reviews stand - this razor is AWESOME! I've been using it almost daily for the last 2 years and I'm *incredibly* satisfied and pleased with the purchase. I haven't replaced the blades yet, and it's still chomping through my stubble like a champ. A great buy, and if this razor ever dies I'll definitely buy another.<br /><br />November 25, 2010 update: as stated in the instructions, stick with it for at least a month. This is probably the best electic razor I've owned, as long as I don't press too hard and keep the head perpendicular to the skin. Also, I dropped it on concrete from about 3 feet and everything came apart. I thought \\"great, now I have to buy another one\\". But instead, everything popped back together and worked like a charm.<br /><br />Original Review: I've owned quite a few $60 electric razors, but I read about 20 reviews on this unit and decided to give it a shot. Arrived quickly, charged it for about an hour, read the instructions, and decided to give it a go dry on about 3mm of growth. Took about 20 mins, but holy cow, the result is as good as a regular razor. I'll write another update in a few days, but coming from a person who's pretty particular about their electronics and their shave, this razor is amazing.
  1247. I just charged up my new Panasonic razor and shaved off a 3 day beard in 2.5 min. Ultra smooth shave. No pulling. Felt like velvet sliding across my face. Reasonably quiet razor.   1248. As a shaver it's neither great nor awful -- it's somewhere in the middle. It's been about 8 months since I bought it and it doesn't seem to shave as close as quickly as it used to, but eventually it does the job. I'm also not crazy about the high-pitched whine -- I guess I'm used to Braun shavers that have a lower, deeper buzz, which is more pleasing to my ear -- not a small matter considering I use this thing every morning at a time when I'm not always in the best of moods. But the main reason I'm giving this product two stars is that it doesn't work when you plug it in! So you have to unplug it to use it. Then, when you're done, you forget to plug it back in again...and then right in the middle of your next shave it quits on you! You then have to plug it back in, wait at least a couple minutes for it to get up to at least 10% so you can finish the job -- then you better remember to plug it back in or you're doomed to repeat history. The Braun shavers I've used in the past never had this problem -- I could use them while plugged in -- which is why I'm planning on getting a Braun -- not in a few months or a few years when this Panasonic dies on me, but NOW.

I still have 5-o'clock shadow by mid-afternoon, but my skin feels much smoother. But, don't let them fool you. It still takes me close to 10 minutes to shave which is no faster than the Norelco.   1252. I have been using a Braun high end shaver with the cleaning device for 4 years. First the cleaning device leaked all over the place and needed to be thrown away. Then within days the shaver started having major problems also. (it's like it had a 4 year fall apart timer)<br /><br />So I went to Amazon which is the first and best place to research items and found this Panasonic very quickly. The reviews were overwhelmingly good and people recommended buying it without the cleaning device (even though it was a small price difference).<br /><br />Since I had spent quite a bit of money on the cleaning of the old razor and I liked the look of this shaver (nice blue) I ordered it.<br /><br />By the way it was around $100 bucks on sale - which was fantastic.<br /><br />I have a Goatee and trim it with another device bought here. For the rest of my face my hair is very thick and goes in every direction so it always takes a long time. My neck hairs are particularly hard to shave and regardless of the shaver need several passes.<br /><br />The first shave with the Panasonic was fantastic. It took 9 minutes which is close to what I'm used to, however when I felt my face I had never had a closer shave ever. I've been using electric shavers for 30 years and this is by far the closest I've ever felt.<br /><br />Further, the shave lasted a few more days without shaving and looked good proving that it really shaved much closer.<br /><br />Today was the second time and it took about 7 minutes and I got just as close a shave. I didn't clean it the first time since I figured it could go a few without cleaning.<br /><br />I got just as close a shave - I love this.<br /><br />As far as the pop out trimmer which I need since I use it to trim the sides of the goatee it works very well. I've read some reviews that it's not that good but I have to say it's much better than any other pop out trimmer I've used. The only downside to it is that you do have to hold the shaver at an unnatural angle to use it properly.<br /><br />Also today I decided to clean it. I imagined a horror of steps and time to clean this since I'd been spoiled by the automatic cleaner for 4 years.<br /><br />All you have to do is put some hand liquid soap on the shaver and press down for a 2 second turbo clean. I found it worked like a charm and literally took less than a minute including rinsing it for a while longer. The next step which is to take off the top and run the blades under water could not be easier. The top pops off VERY easily and running the blades through the water was 10 seconds. Then you are supposed to lay both out to dry. Couldn't be easier. I'll put them back on later tonight.<br /><br />I am very happy not to be paying for the cleaner cartridges and yet still have a great shaver.<br /><br />I would recommend this to anyone. It's by far the best you will find and you will not be disappointed.ral angle to use it properly.<br /><br />Also today I decided to clean it.
