  1722. I've had Norelco shavers for years but as my latest one started to die, I thought I'd try a change so I went with this Panasonic. I'm generally happy with it but here are some additional thoughts if you're deciding:<br />Pros: It seems well made and is comfortable in-hand. It's MUCH easier to clean than any Norelco. It has a nice screen that tells you how much charge is left--also how long you just shaved (not sure the reason on that last one). It shaves very close and doesn't &#34;pull&#34; at hair like the Norelco does if you've skipped a few days.<br />Cons: It's a little louder and shriller than my last Norelco. The trimmer is not well designed in that it's short and narrow so it's hard to see what you're doing while using it. The Norelco one is better designed. Battery life seems relatively short, so expect to charge it at least once a week if you're using it daily. The power button is located right below where your thumb sits while you're shaving so once you've powered it up it's easy to accidentally turn it off. There are some little dimples above the button and that seems to be where they want your thumb to end up.<br />I've tried this dry, with a liquid pre-shave and with a gel, and it seems to do fine with all of these. The gel is kind of messy and requires clean up right after you shave, so I'm still not sure how much I'll do that--maybe there's a better gel product to try.<br />All in all, the shaver is a good product but I'm not blown away.
  1723. As a general razor its fine but if you want to have anything more then a weekly &#34;once over&#34; shave its not the best. I found that I had to go over again with a regular razor in order to get to clean shaven. Also, this thing cut up my adam's apple area on my neck.
  1724. This was a gift and I have been told that it does a good job.
  1725. Gives my husband a smooth shave. Nice versatility.
  1726. ***History***<br />I've been a die-hard Panasonic razor user for many years. My last non-Panasonic razor was purchased in the late 70's and was an AC powered Norelco. Yes at least some of you will remember the old Norelco ads during the holidays, where Santa was sledding on the Rotary Track razor!<br /><br />Each of my last Panasonic razors has lasted a long time and I've been quite satisfied with them. So, once my trusty Panasonic ES8067 started acting up (the trimmer stopped working and needed new blades), it was time to purchase yet another Panasonic razor (why wouldn't I?).<br /><br />I chose the ES8243A after carefully reviewing options and liking the price point and features. It was purchased through Amazon and arrived ahead of the promised time (can't hate that).<br /><br />*********Review Conditions*********<br />I tested this razor in three ways:<br />1) shaving 4 day's growth<br />2) shaving 1 day's growth<br />3) edging and trimming my goatee<br /><br />All shaving was cool and dry (not steamed whiskers or with any electric shaving liquids).<br /><br />Here we go…<br /><br />*********PROS*********<br />+ Comfortable shave<br />+ Wet/dry so cleaning it is very nice<br />+ Made in Japan (not China)<br />+ An LCD shows battery and charging status<br />+ It has a cord that can be plugged in and run even if the battery is dead<br />+ The price was good (plus there was a $20 off coupon)<br />+ It looks nice (well maybe it's important to someone)<br /><br />*********CONS*********<br />- Pulls whiskers when shaving longer growth (seriously ouch)<br />- Has a cord to charge (yes it's also a con) and not induction charging<br />- Doesn't edge a goatee very well<br />- Trimmer is difficult to use<br />- Light weight (details later)<br /><br />We'll start with the PROS…<br /><br />***Comfortable Shave***<br />This razor does a great job, when shaving normal one-day growth (not long whiskers). It was comfortable to use, didn't irritate my face and provided a very close shave. In comparison to my Panasonic ES8067, the result was somewhat closer/smoother overall. It also seemed faster at completing the shave but this may not be fair since my older razor actually needs new blades (which I'm not buying just to do the review, lol). It is fair to say that it obtained a good quality result quickly. Please see the related &#34;Pulls Whiskers!!!&#34; con, later in this review for the full story on its shave.<br /><br />***Wet/Dry***<br />Anyone that has a wet/dry razor will probably agree that it's very handy to be able to clean them with water. Pop it open and run it under hot water and set to dry (huge plus for me). I don't use the razor wet or with shaving gel but you can (a plus for someone out there).<br /><br />***Made in Japan***<br />My old Panasonic ES8067 lasted more than 16 years. For something used every day and sometimes 2x a day, it's hard to argue that their build quality is not great. I did replace my foils and blades from time to time (twice that I can recall) but that is to be expected. Foil+Blade cost is roughly the same for both of these models at around $50 on Amazon.<br /><br />I hope that my experience with this new (still made in Japan) model is similar. We'll see…<br /><br />***LCD Display***<br />The display shows status of the battery (bar display and % remaining), an indicator if it is plugged in and charging and the minutes/seconds it was used. My old razor only had a couple LEDs that told when it was charging and when it needed charging. The new detail is nice since I can gauge how much time I actually still have to use it.<br /><br />***Price***<br />The price was good and with the current coupon deal it was less than a hundred bucks. If I get another 16+ years on this one, that's pretty darn cheap, even with a couple foil and blade replacements figured in.<br /><br />***Looks Nice***<br />For those that care a lot about aesthetics in their razor, I'm noting this.<br /><br />So here is the entry that is a Pro and a Con.<br /><br />***Cord to Charge*** (pro & con)<br />Here is the double edged sword. It uses a cord to charge it, unlike the ES8067 that was induction charged. I had always liked the induction charging but the only reason I'm listing this as a PRO is that you can run the razor plugged in. The ES8067 required recharging when it was out of battery.<br /><br />Both models quote a 1hr charge time.<br /><br />Now to the meat of what I didn't like so much, the Cons.<br /><br />***Pulls Whiskers!!! ***<br />First I just want to say, &#34;OUCH!&#34; I tested this on about 4 day's growth. When I made my first pass, I went at the normal speed I would have used with the ES8067 and &#34;ouch&#34;... wow, not fun. I experimented with it and through quite a few ouches later... I found that I needed to slow down about 50%. At that speed I was getting pretty consistent results without pain.<br /><br />Why? No idea really but my older ES8067 with &#34;less powerful motor&#34; with &#34;less advanced blades&#34; definitely handled the heavier growth at a faster pace without ouches.<br /><br />On shorter growth (normal 1 day growth) I had no experience with ouches. This leads me to believe that the real issue is just with the foil/cutter that is handling the longer whiskers. So if you are a disciplined every-day shaver, this may never be a CON for you.<br /><br />***Edging***<br />There is a distinct difference in the ES8243 vs the older ES8067. I have been unable to just use the razor to shave the edges of my goatee. I just can't get it to shave up to that line and have a clean break between goatee and shaved face. The older model did this well. This is not long hair trimming but the actual short whiskers that are to be &#34;shaved&#34;. I'll keep working on how I'm doing this but it is fair to say that it is harder to obtain the same results that I had with the ES8067.<br /><br />***Trimmer***<br />The trimmer is a huge step back from myES8067. The pop up trimmer is both narrower (22mm vs 30mm) and has finer teeth than the old model. It also pops out away from the back of the razor (perpendicular) vs the old model which slid up to just above the foils. This means that the razor body blocks you being able to see what you are doing. The overall effect is that it is more work and much harder to use. I'm unlikely to use the pop up trimmer at all and will stick with my Wahl clippers for this task. That is unfortunate since it is far more work to go get another device for a task that my old razor handled well.<br /><br />***Weight***<br />Well, this is more of a nebulous topic in that I can't say for sure that it is a con. It is a difference that I infer something from. The ES8243A (179g) is significantly lighter than the ES8067 (260g). When you pick them up, the difference is striking, like picking up something with a metal frame vs one with plastic. I don't actually know what parts in the razor are lighter but 81g is a significant difference.<br /><br />In some types of products lighter would be a great change, in others not. My perception of a mechanical device (based on past experience) is that light means less robust build quality. I have no facts or experience with this particular item to back up any claim of less quality. This is just perception. Time will tell the real story. Remember my ES8067 lasted over 16yrs.<br /><br />***Summary***<br />I'm not sure yet what I really think of the razor, from the standpoint of overall satisfaction. My experience and thoughts on it are definitely a mixed bag.<br /><br />How you will feel about it is likely to depend on which of the above points are important to you and which are not.<br /><br />One thing is for sure, when shaving normal one-day growth and not dealing with edging, trimming or shaving heavy multi-day growth, the razor does provide a very nice close and comfortable shave.<br /><br />Well, that's it. I hope you find this useful and good luck with your razor purchase!
  1727. This replaced an older model Braun and is head and shoulders a better unit. Very smooth shave and the built in ultrasonic cleaning system works great. It is a little big pricy but worth it.
  1728. My husband only dry shaves his face once a week and has issues with getting ingrown hairs and he loves this shaver. It doesn't grab his skin or nick him and leaves him with baby smooth skin. It gives a close shave as good as any razor.
  1729. best electric shave I have ever had
  1730. I had been a Norelco rotary blades loyalist for the past 15 years, upgrading 3 times to their latest and greatest electric shaver. I always had to make multiple passes (even with their improved 3 rows of cutters per rotary blade) over my beard. I decided to give the Panasonic 4 rows of cutters a chance on the basis of reviews from users and it did not disappoint. This shaver is an incredible value, as well as an incredible shaver. I shave in half the time my Norelco used to take. Finish shaving and put 1 drop of liquid soap on the cover, place under running tap water for 2 or 3 seconds and turn it on -- wait 15 or 20 seconds and rinse with tap water -- the cleaning process is complete. No chemical washes to buy, no other rinsing necessary. Smells fresh and is ready to go. Charging is quick, though this shaver has to be recharged every 5 uses. I find that does not pose a problem.
  1731. I stopped using electric razors a very long time ago, due to burns and inefficiencies of the ones I had tried. Recently, I decided to sport the \\"bald look\\" and definitely did not want to trust my scalp to a traditional razor blade! Several folks recommended I try the Panasonic ES8243A, especially for head shaving. I took their advice and couldn't be happier with this razor! It is absolutely amazing what a comfortable and close shave this razor is capable of producing! While I originally purchased this razor strictly for my head, I am now using the ES8243A for my head and my beard. If you are considering purchasing this product, stop wondering and researching, you can not beat the performance of this razor and especially at this price!
  1732. I only use this razor for cleaning up my neck after trimming my beard. I like the way the head flexes, the way the razor feels in my hand, and the closeness of the shave (lower neck isn't the easiest area to shave). It even does well with longer hairs without leaving me with the feeling they were yanked out (my older razor would really tug on longer hairs before they were cut).<br /><br />It charges quickly and has great charge status indicators. One thing that put this at 4 and not 5 stars is that you cannot use it with the charger plugged in; I guess only the older razors had that feature.<br /><br />I really like the cleaning steps and that the razor tracks when cleaning is needed. I have not tired using this razor \\"wet\\" (i.e. in the shower), in part because of reviews I've read on several wet razors about them failing after several months or a few years of shower use due to leaks.
  1733. It has been a few years since I tried an electric shaver. My experiences with electric shavers in the past has been mixed, so I wasn't sure which shaver I should go with.<br /><br />I am happy to say this Panasonic shaver exceeded my expectations. It provides a smooth, close shave in a short amount of time. I grow a thick beard seemingly overnight, so daily shaving is a must. On a single charge, I will get 4+ days of shaving from this Panasonic. So, for a short trip out of town, I don't even bring the charging cord. I've had it for a few months now, and no sign of shortened battery life.<br /><br />The shaver works in the shower, but I dry shaving with this razor and get a good shave without any kind of razor burn.
  1734. My old Braun shaver finally burnt out and I purchased this Panasonic model after reading the reviews. i have to say that I have been very impressed, does the job: gives a close shave and is very quick, the two things that are important on any busy morning!
  1735. Excellent razor. Closer shave in less time than my previous electric razor. Definitely recommend this.
  1736. Have used it for almost two years now and it is still ticking. Very pleased with this product. Easy to clean.
  1737. The Panasonic gives the best shave of any shaver I have owned and my price paid was excellent; now I will wait and see if it<br />stands the test of time.
  1738. I wish I could use the main blades when my facial hair gets a bit on the long side, but the trimmer does a great job of cutting them down to the stubble the main blades handle very well. Still, I really like it and don't regret getting it, my first electric razor in over 20 years.
  1739. I purchased this for my 89 year old father. I had read the reviews about how this one did not pull the hairs when in use. The first time he tried it he was very pleased! This lived up to the reviews. It was extremely fast recharging and sooo easy to clean! Very Happy with this purchase.
  1740. Excellent shaver. Best i have owned. Nice fast close shave. Love the features and overall look and feel. Awesome. 5 stars all the way
  1741. I use it with the face cream and it leaves a smooth feeling. I have never hand an electric cut this well. Hope it lasts.
  1742. This is the best I have ever used. i i i love love love it it it it it it
  1743. THE CHIN AND UNDER THE CHIN ARE THE HARD PARTS TO REMOVE
  1744. I have been an electric razor user for more than 25 years and used Remington foil products 90% of the time with a brief excursion to a Norelco floating head type of electric razor. I always like the Remington foils and would just buy the newer model when my current one wore out.<br /><br />This time, I read reviews both online and in Consumer Reports and decided to spend a little more money and try this Panasonic ES8243A. I was a little hesitant because Panasonic made OK TVs and mediocre electronic components, but what did they know about shaving? Turns out, quite a bit.<br /><br />This is the best shaving experience I have had in 25 years. It is very quiet compared to the Remington. It shaves close and does not miss neck hairs like my Remington did. It does not pull the occasional whisker out by the root. That in itself is a huge plus to me. I like the digital display informing me how much charge remains. The recharge is much quicker than the Remington. And it weighs less than my old Remington.<br /><br />Damn, I love this razor. Why did I wait so long to discover the Panasonic? Spend a few dollars more and invest in this razor.
  1745. I use the razor to shave my head. It does a great job - not quite as close as a razor - but never with any cuts or nicks. It holds a charge for a long time. Very happy with it.
  1746. I have been using Panasonic wet-dry shavers on a daily basis since the 1990's, and employed this particular model for three-and-a-half years (June 2009 to Jan 2013). I have a thick beard coupled with adult acne and sensitive skin, so shaving has always been a challenge.... Happiest day of my life was when I was able to combine an electric shave with hot, wet lather, a concept that Panasonic introduced. (Note: there's really no need to spend a lot of money on a shaver if you can't / aren't going to wet-shave with it; a dry-electric shave will inevitably be inferior.) I agree with other reviewers that the design of, and results from, Panasonic's earliest wet-dry's were superior to the ES8243A (and similar high-end models of the past decade); nonetheless, I would still strongly recommend this shaver to anyone. It delivers a smooth face (even in the pesky spots under the chin and down the neck) with a minimum of irritation in under 4 minutes.<br /><br />As the 4th or 5th Panasonic wet-dry I've owned, however, this model continues with what I have found to be a disappointing build quality. This shaver lasted 3.5 years before giving up the ghost; my previous Panasonic (earlier version of this model) lasted only about 3, as I recall. None have lasted more than 4 years. Granted, I provide regular, fairly hearty use, but I always scrupulously clean and air-dry the shavers - no dropping on the floor or tossing out of windows. This shaver failed in a manner identical to the previous one: one day it started activating randomly, without my touching the switch, and within a week it stopped responding to the switch entirely (i.e. wouldn't turn on). During the previous 12 months, the battery life had decreased - down to about 16-20 minutes on a full charge - and the LED screen had ceased functioning, though the motor still provided full RPM and shave quality was great.<br /><br />My buying habits tell the story: to replace my deceased ES8243A, I'm sticking with Panasonic, as I always do, and have purchased an ES-LF51, essentially the same shaver with a slightly stronger motor. I'm looking forward to using it. But I own a cheap backup, which I expect to have to use for a few days in about 3.5 years (give or take a few months) when my new Panasonic fails. 4 Stars, because any product that costs more than 100 dollars (as this model did in 2009) ought to last at least 5 years.ys do, and have purchased an ES-LF51, essentially the same shaver with a slightly stronger motor. I'm looking forward to using it. But I own a cheap backup, which I expect to have to use for a few days in about 3.5 years (give or take a few months) when my new Panasonic fails. 4 Stars, because any product that costs more than 100 dollars (as this model did in 2009) ought to last at least 5 years.
  1747. I have only had this razor for about 2 weeks. I am more than happy with the results. I have always had a problem with razor burn on my neck with an electric razor. About a year ago I began shaving my head and have the same problem with the neck area. I switched to the Gillette Power Fusion which I love but was looking to save some money on blades so I thought I'd give this a try.<br />I love it, a close shave and not a trace of razor burn. not even the first time. I thought for sure that would happen. It says to wait 30 days for it to really start giving you a close shave. While the Fusion is a tad bit closer right now. I am very happy with it and am guessing that it will catch it real soon.<br />Buy it if you are looking for an electric!!
  1748. it is very good productor, but it just makes a little bit more noiser than Piliph, in a word , I like it
  1749. Husband loves it. Says it is a good shaver
  1750. After years of buzzing my head once a week or so with clippers, I decided to go totally bald and experimented with methods. Blade in the shower worked well but was slow and laborious, so I decided to try electric shavers. Before buying this one I tried a triple head Norelco and a Braun foil. Neither worked satisfactorily. I did a little online research that pointed me to Panasonic. I am super pleased with this shaver. In less than 3 minutes I get a shave that is the functional equivalent of a blade shave. I have not yet tried it wet in the shower, as it works perfectly for me dry before showering. I don't give many 5 star reviews, but this product deserves one.
  1751. had this for a few yrs, still going strong, use it every day without any issues. easy to clean too.
  1752. I have tried all brands of electric shavers. Its always a question of what works best for the individual. I have owned two Norelcos and for me they both were inferior to this model. I was lucky as I paid $79.99 after a 20 dollar coupon here that was applied to purchase at checkout. I always seem to return to Panasonic. To me - it comes down to the Arc 3 or 4. The Arc 5 is far too expensive in my opinion. Bear in mind that the replacement cutters / foil are least expensive for the Arc 3. So the cost of ownership for that model cannot be beat. That would be the best choice if one was happy with results. However - again, it comes down to what works best for the individual. This Arc 4 model is dated and there is a newer model around now. But for what I paid its to me blade close and noticeably better than the Arc 3 model. Especially if you pre-treat your face with a electric shave lotion that seems to get hair to stand up in order to achieve an unbelievably close shave. I am finished with rotary shavers. As far as Braun's go - their cleaning system is gimmicky as well as an added cost. You cannot beat simply placing a few drops of a liquid soap on this shavers head and then pressing power and holding to go into its high speed cleaning mode. You then simply remove the foil and rinse and let dry. For what I paid. I feel this is the very best electric shaver value around. Absolutely superior in quality and performance with a trimmer that is not only sharp but very precise. I highly recommend. Panasonic says to replace outer foil once a year and inner blades every other year. Cost wise that is not too bad.
  1753. I've been using a Remington for about 39 nine years and always preferred a blade. On a whim I bought this Panasonic shaver and was amazed at how well it cut a 2 day growth totally dry with no pinches or pulls.<br /><br />I rate this 100%.
  1754. Perfect smooth shave and fast! No rubbing face with razor until your skin turns red! I recommend it to everyone!
  1755. This is a superior shaver. Close shaves and a solid product. Also great for travelling..I now have two of them one for backup and I love them.
  1756. This thing is awesome. My boyfriend uses it to shave his head, so that should give you an idea of its ruggedness.
  1757. I bought this over 5 years ago, going strong, I'm actually thinking of buying another one as a backup in case. Best electric shaver I've owned so far, and don't need the extra features to go up to the higher priced ones. Good enough for me. Only problem (but this is with all electric shavers) is buying replacement blades and screens, and the cost involved, but it's worth the trade-off.
  1758. After more than a thousand reviews what can I add? Well, as a traditional wet shaver I feel that electric razors have been given a bad rap. That has been deserved to only a degree. I started out using them back in the mid 70's and continued until about 10 years ago. I have used a couple of Norleco razors and one Braun. I still have the Braun (Model 5414) that I was using for evening touch-ups. For reference I have a moderately tough beard combined with sensitive fair skin.<br />I have been wet shaving for about a decade. I travelled the familiar route of canned shaving cream and decent disposable razors and then to a Schick Quattro. For the last 3-4 years I graduated to using a shaving brush, better shaving creams and soaps and finally to double edged razors. I still use on very rare occaisons the Edwin Jagger razor equipped with Derby, Feather or Dorco blades. That served me well for years and is a very nice way to shave for very little money long term. As mentioned previously though, I have sensitive skin and it was taking it's toll. I tended to use 5 passes on average to get a nice close shave. Six was not out of the question. By Sunday my face was very sensitive and I was tempted to skip a day which is not something I like to do at all. Trying to shave in the evening for a night out was not a fun prospect and I would cheat and use the Braun. Not nearly as close but passable.<br />To give context I will rate my shaves in order of comfort and closeness. First off, cheap disposable razors. Worst of everything. Feels like I am ripping out the hair and the skin with it. My experiences with these go all the way back to their earliest days.<br />Second, the older electric razors. Not very close and I would have to go over and over my face to get the job (it really felt like a job) done. ElecricShave did not help much. Any raising of the hair was accompanied by drying of the skin as well as a burning sensation.<br />Third, the newer Gillette and Schick 4 blade razors. Ridiculously expensive blades and the shaves are not as close as a double edge. I experimented with this several times. After about 3 passes with them it seemed they just started gliding over my face without getting any closer. They are a good compromise between comfort, no nicks, and closeness. I could easily get closer after them with my double edge. In fact, when my face was a little tender I would use my Schick for the first 3 passes and then two more with the DE.<br />Fourth, my trusty DE razor. If it were not for the skin irritation I would have just stuck with it. The closest shave of all and quite a pleasurable experience every morning. Very economical as well once you purchase a razor. About 10 cents a blade when bought in decent quantities.<br />OK, so now you have a baseline for my review. I would like to take the opportunity here to thank previous reviewers for helping me make the decision to purchase this razor. I have been using it for 5 weeks now. My face is in better condition than before without a doubt. I don't have to worry about touching up before going out at night anymore. As a side note, I do not use any alcohol based after shave balms or cologne. As per my previous experiences I was hesitant to purchase another electric razor. This razor is in a completely different league. I did not expect to ever be able to give up my DE razor especially with my affinity for really close shaves.<br />You can use this razor to dry shave but if you want a nice, COMFORTABLE shave, use a wet shaving technique. I still use my shaving brush to apply a very small amount of shaving cream directly to my face. No need for a shaving bowl. It's too bad since a have a couple of nice ones. If you over-apply it will be like putting Bubble-Bath in a jacuzzi. Just a big counterproductive mess. I use Truefitt & Hill shaving creams. It can be applied using just your hand if you wish to avoid the cost of a brush. I tried using plain water and facial soap but the results were not nearly as good.<br />I make a few passes and then rinse off the razor and some of the lather off of my face. There is plenty of cream left inside the razor to give you a nice glide for a couple more passes. Don't let it get dried out from the friction. Just keep your face slightly wet. You will get a nice feel for it in no time. The results have surprised and pleased me. Really a great shave with almost no irritation. I can touch up at night using a dry shave method without too much irritation at all. A little (non-alcohol) aftershave balm and I feel great. Is it as close as a 5-6 pass DE shave? Not quite but it is as close as a 4 pass shave at least, and certainly IMO as close as a Shick or Gillette shave with much more comfort. Everyone's face is different so YMMV.<br />A few folks have mentioned the noise of the razor. I only have my old Braun for comparison. At 4&#34; away it measures 71 db. The Panasonic measures 66 db. The Panasonic is much quiter but it's noise is a little higher in pitch. Certainly not too much to complain about IMO.<br />My final verdict; a very fine product for a reasonable price. Works better than expected. This is coming from a very dedicated DE shaver.<br />I will add a couple of side notes here for guys who have not tried products outside of the norm or are just struggling with having to shave and getting no pleasure out of it at all. First off, if you are using alcohol based after shave balms or colognes and you do not like the burn or the drying sensation quit using them. Just because most guys use them they might not be suitable for you. The most widely available non-alcohol product out there is Nivea for sensitive skin. There are a few out there as well but that one is still in my rotation.<br />Secondly, consider quitting the shaving cream in a can. Besides not being the most environmentally freindly stuff out there it winds up costing more especially if you purchase this razor. You do not want a thick and foamy product on yourface. At the rate I am using my cream it will take me years to use one tub of this stuff.The most widely available cream that I know of is Proraso (also marketed as Bigelow at Bath and Body). It comes in a metal tube like toothpaste. Very nice &#34;old school&#34; scent as well.
  1759. First things first, this shaver is obnoxiously loud(to the point where I can shave on the 2nd floor of my home and be able to hear it from the basement, absolutely nuts). The only other shaver I'd ever owned was a $40 Philip's Norelco(2 years) from Target. Comparatively speaking, I'd say the shave falls short of the Norelco, though the trimmer is a lot more effective(though more prone to cutting/scratching skin).<br /><br />Overall, I'm disappointed with the product. Definitely was not worth the price. I've learned my lesson and will be sticking with Norelco from now on.

I can't wait to see how well it performs once my head is used to it.<br /><br />Other pluses: It holds a charge well. Shaved my entire head thoroughly and it only used 20% of the battery.   1765. I am a life time user of electric shavers, almost 55 years. The Panasonic is the best.   1766. I used to use an electric a long time ago, have never been able to find another at a decent price that gave me a close shave without hurting/chaffing my skin. This one is a keeper! Battery lasts for several shaves/cleanings and even when it looks like it's about to die with one bar blinking (for those of us who occasionally forget to charge) I can still get a full shave, running on fumes as it were. I can think of nothing negative about this razor. Use it in the shower without any preshave treatment and works great.
  1767. Works much better than my older 3 blade Panasonic that was failing after less than 2 years of use. The battery was the problem with the older model. The main problem with any of these shavers is the wear rate of the cutters and screen. Once they get worn it takes twice as long to shave. I shave once daily and that should be less than the design standard for these shavers. Replacement of these items is nearly as costly as buying a whole new unit. Could it be that Panasonic does not want to sell repair parts? That being said, these are still the best thing out there for producing a clean shave with an electric.
  1768. Best shaver I ever tried. Faster than razor in the shower, less mess, cleaner shave. Best dry shaving & done in 2 min's.
  1769. Everythings is perfect
  1770. This was a gift to a man who is very hairy. It sure took care of his heavy beard and moustache!!
  1771. I guess I like a smooth shave on all my face and neck. This is probably the best electric shaver available without having to take out a loan to pay for it. It's just that these electric mowers take 3 times longer to get there than a good old blade. Now for my major complaint about his particular shaver. I'm like most of us,...lazy. How lazy am I ? To lazy to plug it back in to charge after every use. Well yea, it does recharge pretty quick but when your running late [always am] you can't just plug this in and run it off regular 120v power. Ya got to wait or go without.
  1772. After reading the reviews which said this was a great razor for men with a fast-growing/heavy beard and sensitive skin I ordered his razor for my son.   1773. MY OLD BRAUN IS BETTER, IT GIVES A CLOSER SMOOTHER SHAVE. NOT WORTH THE PRICE I PAID. BUY A BRAUN.
